review:
I can't stand ASCII games, I'm not that old.
But with the interface this game becomes addictive, fast.

Whether you're a sadist who likes hardcore, or a casual scrub like me, this game is both challenging and fun.
I'm still new and I know there's a huge pile of stuff to learn - but I'm making do learning on my own.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060199516', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 2761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2559, 'last_played': 1709440672}
review:
Es ist ein traditionelles Roguelike-Spiel aus Deutschland das es schon seit 30 Jahren gibt.
Das Spiel hat den Test der Zeit bestanden und wird immer noch von Spielern auf der ganzen Welt gespielt. 
Es spielt in einer riesigen, prozedural generierten Welt, in der es an jeder Ecke Schätze, Gefahren und Abenteuer gibt. 

Damals war es noch ein ASCII-Spiel.
Es orientiert sich am stärksten an NetHack, und ist nicht auf diesen Moria-, Angband-Zweig, es gehört eher dahinter.
Und es fängt sehr viel schwer mit mehr Rollenspielelementen an als viele andere Rougelikes.
Und es ist erstmal nicht Open Scource.
Es ist das Spiel von Thomas Biskup, und das bleibt es auch.
Das Spiel wird bis heute gepflegt.

Es ist eigentlich das einzige von den großen Roguelikes was nicht OpenScource ist wenn ich das richtig verstanden habe.
Und es ist tatsächlich von einer Person, dann aber mit großem Fleiß und Ehrgeiz über lange Zeit weiterentwickelt.
Ich muss sagen es lohnt sich heute noch da einzutauchen.
Thomas Biskup (a.k.a. "The Creator") macht eine Sache ganz krass anders, er macht 1994 ein Roguelike mit einer Welt, mit einem Land.

Und das war zu dieser Zeit jetzt wirklich für diese Art Spiel eine starke Abkehr von dem Grundkonzept.
Es gibt da Städte und Flüsse, und Ozeane, und Tempel und Hügel, und Berge.
Also eine richtige Landkarte über die du da läufst, eher so wie in den früheren "Ultimas".
Und es hat nicht diese Aufgabe das du hinabsteigst in ein Verlies, sondern hier bist du auf einer ganzen Welt unterwegs.

Und es hat mehr Story und Interaktion mit der Spielwelt, es gibt Quests die auf unterschiedliche Arten gelöst werden können.
Es ist anspruchsvoll und komplex was die Rollenspielausrichtung angeht.
Dann gibt es Chaos und Mutationen, diese Mutationen sind ein bisschen wie in der Warhammer-Welt.
Die Chaos-Mutationen, du kannst halt Mutationen bekommen und die können dir helfen, deinen Charakter stärker machen.
Sie kann aber auch deinen Charakter schwächer machen, oder mit einem Makel versehen.
Und das gibt hier, weil das eben ein Zufalls-System ist, ein starkes Element von "Emergent Gameplay" rein und definiert deinen Charakter stark.
Du kannst mit den Mutationen sozusagen an die Grenze gehen, und sehen das du halt immer wieder welche kriegst die dich mächtig machen. 
Bis zur einen die zuviel ist, die macht dann den ganzen Charakter nutzlos.
Das ist ein sehr starkes Konzept was den Charakter definiert.
Das Spiel hat "Permadeath", also geht es sehr stark um Entscheidungskonsistenz.
Das ist ja auch das was einen in manch modernen Spielen begnet.
Das manche Spiele versuchen das herzustellen beim Spieler.
Das du halt nämlich nicht, wenn du siehst `ah der blaue Trank den ich ausprobiert habe ist tödlich oder gefährlich, neu lädst und diesmal den blaun Trank nicht trinkst und wegwirfst.
Und das ist ja auch das was heutzutage noch manche Spiele haben.
Du machst eine Entscheidung, du gehst links, du gehst rechts, führst die Entscheidung durch, siehst welche Entscheidung besser ist und lädsts neu, machst gleich die richtigen Entscheidungen.
Das heisst du spielst das Spiel mit `Savegames`, spielst du halt durch mit einer Kette von richtiger Entscheidungen theoretisch, weil deine ganzen Fehlentscheidungen im Nichts landen.
Und hier musst du wenn du es im harten "Roguelike-Modus" spielst, mit deinen Entscheidungen leben und gucken das du sie wieder in gute Entscheidungen verwandelst.
Die Erfolge im klassischen "Roguelike-Modus" bei ADOM sind so triumphal, weil sie so hart erarbeitet werden müssen.
Es ist in dieser Steam-Deluxe-Version auch möglich das Spiel mit wiederladbaren "Savegames" zu spielen, doch dabei lernst du schlechte Taktiken und bekommst auch keine Àchievements", oder du lernst überhaupt nie und schießt dir damit im Endeffekt ins Knie. 
Dann spielst du zwar die perfekte Partie, aber mit schlechten Strategien. 
Weil du ja auch einfach durch wiederholen und wiederholen usw., also dadurch das du ja manchmal einfach nur den Zufall optimierst, durch das Spiel durchkommst.
Dann lernst du aber halt schlechte Dinge !
Das "Perma-Death" ist auch deswegen so spannend, nicht nur weil es diese Persistenz der Entscheidungen erzwingt, sondern auch weil es das "Lernen" erzwingt. 
Was das Spiel nämlich eigentlich möchte, ist das du gute Strategien erlernst durch wiederholtes Scheitern.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071775212', 'num_games_owned': 143, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 12376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12376, 'last_played': 1697182412}
review: ADOM is less a game and more of a pain simulator.  I discovered this thing when I was 12 years old, and have carried it with me over the years in my pocket on a flash drive trying and consistently failing to reach new milestones of success. This is the only game I've ever played that made me think differently about how I define progress and literally put hair on my chest. The feeling of accomplishment and pure bliss when I finally shut the gates of chaos for the first time is second to no other gaming experience in my life. And then they put it on Steam.... WITH GRAPHICS AND SOUND. So I went and beat it again a few times and it's great. If you liked the original ASCII version or even if you didn't, go ahead and buy this game because I would like Thomas Biskup to have your money and maybe just maybe one day you'll beat this monstrosity and discover what it means to experience true enlightening suffering.

TOP FUN THINGS TO DO:
⭐️ Dungeon crawling.

THE UNIQUES:
💎 All time classic.
💎 So many ways to play this game.

PLAYER GAMING REQUIREMENTS:
💼 Dungeon Crawler.
💼 Roguelike.
💼 CRPG.

PROS:
+ Extremely lengthy (a lot of exploration and trial&error required).
+ In-depth gameplay.
+ Requires quite a bit of planning and thinking.
+ Very challenging but rewarding.

CONS:
- Quite hostile to new players/very steep learning curve
- Once you die, you die and that's it (in almost every case). That can be off putting, especially if you put 25 hours+ in a single character
- Sometimes very random, you can get into some really unfair situations

VERDICT:
This is the type of game you pour your heart and soul into and still don't feel like you've gotten any closer to your goal, for most people, that sounds like a living hell, and trust me... it is. But this game gives you a continuous motion to keep playing. Sure, the some situation are a complete joke but if you manage to push yourself through those situations. There's a sense of achievement.

Just don't die at a high level, that will just leave you angry.
Total Score = 69/100.

GAMEPLAY:
The player's goal is to stop the forces of Chaos that invade the world of Ancardia. The game has been identified as one of the "major roguelikes". Most dungeons are procedurally generated, but once the game generates a dungeon, it does not change even if the player exits and re-enters it.

■■■■■■□□□□ 6 / 10
I died at level 35 and haven't returned since

RECOMMEDED SPECS
It'll run on anything.

review: 20년 넘게 해봤지만 아직까지 엔딩은 본적이 없음.. 레인져 엘프로 드래곤도 잡고 뭐 피라미드 가고 별 지랄 생쇼를 하고 공략을 쳐봐도 뭐 어쩌라는건지 알 수가 없음.. 너무 어려움..  학교 컴터실에서도 하고 집에서도 하고 노트북에서도 하고 군대 사지방에서도 깔고 하고 걍 아무데서나 할 수 있는 최강의 장점으로 진짜 수십 수백명의 모험자로 뒤져봤다..고양이를 죽이면 고양이왕이 와서 나중에 죽인다는데 고양이 안죽이고 다니는게 말이 되냐 ㅅㅂ..레벨이 졸라 올라서 드래곤도 드래곤 슬레잉 화살 몇발로 잡을 수 있을만큼 강해도 까딱하면 길가다 걍 3턴안에 죽어버림.. 대마법사 구하고 뭔 어뮬렛 구한다음에 아 나 존나쌔네 하고 다음층 바로 뒤진적도 있고.. 어느순간 엔딩보는건 포기하고 2회차 인생 살아보는 느낌으로 걍 게임에서 뒤질때까지 모험하다가 뒤지는 재미로 하는게임

author: {'steamid': '76561198073268469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1705112676}
review:
I understand that roguelike games are meant to be difficult, but the developer seems to have not realized there is a difference  between giving your players a challenge, and just flipping the table before shouting "fuck you, roll a new character!"

The game can and has ended two of my runs by throwing invisible enemies at me very early in the game (before level 7). This was a point where I had no chance of being able to detect invisible creatures, and thus was completely incapable of defending myself as they chased me through the dungeon and killed me. And at the time of writing this review, I recently encountered a floor where a seemingly endless horde of monsters had the power to NOCLIP THROUGH THE WALLS in order to surround and massacre me.

The in game information page is not very intuitive when it comes to searching the information you want, nor does it provide anywhere near as much details as it should. I have no idea what these additional numbers next to my equipment (such as Armor) means, because it doesn't explain it in game.

Also, spells have a finite amount of times you can use them before you [b]permanently forget them[/b] and then have to go searching through towns and dungeons hoping that you randomly find a copy of the tome so you can relearn it again. So if you were planning to roll up a spell caster class, you probably want to pick one of the races that levels up quickly, and grab the traits that increase your XP gain; because grinding is actively detrimental for you.

If you're playing a Weaponsmith, you won't be able to use your class abilities until you find a Forge, which you probably won't do on your first, second, third, fourth, fifth, or even sixth attempt, because most forges are randomly spawned into dungeons. The only one I can reliably point you to is in Dwarf town, somewhere around level 9-11 of the Caverns of Chaos. Even then, the guy running the forge charges you 2,500 gold every time you use it.

But that's probably not as bad as the Necromancer, who can't even raise their weakest type of undead minions until they hit level 16. I've been playing this game for a few days now, and I've just barely managed to reach level 12, even in the Personalized mode which lets you reload saves when you die. Even worse, creating undead drains your mana attribute [b]permanently.[/b] Well, technically, the game says your mana will regenerate over time, but makes it explicitly clear that this takes a very long time to do.

I'm sure there are other problems with the game I have yet to find in the few days I've been playing. But I'll say that to top it all off, the game seems to be deserted. The forums have been dead since I got here, with the latest posts being from months ago with nobody else seeming to be replying to them.

I'm not giving this game a thumbs down because it can't be fun. I'm giving it a thumbs down because it is unreasonably difficult, fails to provide you with essential information, and the steam community seems to be dead as far as I can tell.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993805040', 'num_games_owned': 852, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1700611055}

author: {'steamid': '76561198073773261', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1699621341}
review:
[h1] ADOM (Ancient Domains of Mystery) - Same game, new coat of paint [/h1]

As its developers are proud to tell you on the Steam Store page, ADOM is "one of the most successful roguelike games ever created." This is mainly due to the fact that the original ADOM came out way back in 1994 and was, for the time, one of the best and most advanced roguelikes out there.

The new ADOM is really just the old ADOM, but this time with graphics. And while the graphics are actually quite nice, it doesn't change the fact that the game is almost 30 years old. Roguelikes and roguelites have come a long way since, but the ADOM remake insists on still using the same obtuse and antiquated mechanics of the original.

I would only recommend this if you absolutely have to play the original ADOM on newer systems (you can even change the display to ASCII art for that real OG feel). Otherwise, just pick any of the million other roguelikes out there.

[b] TLDR: [/b] The remake of the 1994 ADOM, with improved graphics.
[b] Pros: [/b] One of the OG roguelikes.
[b] Cons: [/b] Absolutely antiquated by today's standards.

[h3] Final score: 4/10 [/h3]

author: {'steamid': '76561197996972957', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 1941, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1941, 'last_played': 1699489182}
review:
Adom.
Legendary Roguelike that did better job at being roguelike than actual Rogue. And now with very nice graphics.
So why thumbs down?

Well.
ADOM itself is like a 30 years old game by now. When it first came out it was better than anything else by a long shot.
Sure, there was no graphics. But there was on overworld, there were quests, there was smithing, there were character classes and skills and stats. There were multiple items with variable bonuses. Alignment system, food system - you name it.
By 90s standard ADOM was one of the most advanced games around, and I kid you not.

And this is the problem with this game, exactly. It was advanced by 90s standards. While the pretty graphics is surely a great thing and it does wonders for enriching your experience, everything else is still in 90s.

The game system did not evolved with Steam release. Graphics aside it is almost exactly as it was back then, and even back then, there were issues with it.

So, it is not really an open world game. Surface world is pretty much identical and very limited in scope.
Dungeons are also quite limited in scope and levels are quite small. Except of Infinite Dungeon, which has a bunch of problems on its own, like lack of extra features, there is surprisingly little variety to them dungeons except of few (always the same) unique locations.
Then there is food, which goes down faster if you wear artifacts, for example, and corpses sometimes grant you bonuses or negatives.
Then there are quests, some of which are mutually exclusive for no reason (like starting village quests, where you can have one but not the other). Then there is Danger Level that increases difficulty of dungeons by spawning stronger monsters. Then there is a level limit (Player Character is the only monster in the game with said limit).

This all sounds cool, but there are dungeons that do not spawn if you don't have quests for them. So if the quests are mutually exclusive... you don't get dungeons! And level limit being pretty hardcore and not applying to enemies means that you can easily run into trouble (namely monsters that instakill you, who are not 'special' monsters, just overpowered versions of regular ones).
Then there is totally random loot, so you never know what you will get and when you will get it. Then there are random item destroying effects, sometimes when you would least expect it, occasionally targeting your unique loot (not named but very rare drops that you need for game progression).
And there is no reloading savegames if you fail (unless you want to play with no achievements or save scum). So you don't learn from your failure, you just have to start over.

Generally speaking, the game does not play that well as it did almost 30 years ago. Lack of any in-game information related to many mechanics, for example eating corpses of monsters doesn't give you a note in Monster Memory about the corpse effects, inability to inspect items to show their proper descriptions (you need to cast a spell for that and even then you are not always sure what it does), lack of proper crafting system, lack of proper shops, lack of proper alchemy, lack of proper herbalism/gardening, lack of proper enchanting etc.

I'll be blunt. Having to constantly check online pages just for the information that should be available somewhere ingame is not fun. No, really, it is not.

The worst part of ADOM however is... it is repeteable. I know, sounds strange if RNG is such a big deal, but... does not matter what character you play, really, you usually aim at the similar set of gear, similar set of unique items, similar set of end-game conditions.
Ending may have few variations, but the road to these variations is quite similar.

And this is the problem I have with ADOM, playing it again that many years later: after RimWorld and Masterwork Dwarf Fortress, where with tons of mods these games could really captivate my attention for months at a time (sometimes I spent a week just generating the 'right' world in DF), ADOM does not do that. I know what to expect and when, RNG just affects if I maybe get that sooner or later. It's just the same thing every time.

My thumbs down is therefore a warning for returning players: I've expected more from Steam release, at least few more dungeons for example. A new village with an altar and smithy. Something, anything. If you are like me and you have beaten the Chaos God decades ago already, you may not neccesarilly want to ruin your old memories. If you are new player who never played ADOM before... go ahead and grab it. Just be warned that this game mechanics is really old and it didn't aged that well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111138517', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 4630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4537, 'last_played': 1703912049}
review:
Don't get the rating twisted, I loved ADOM for a long time and used to play it regularly. Hell, I might pick it up again in the future!

But the game is bad. Like...even so far as roguelikes go, it's just kind of bad.

I don't feel like I ever understand what I'm doing [i]mechanically.[/i] I am constantly checking a wiki or my personal notes just to understand whether or not I should even move towards an enemy or not.

The game is so packed with information and it's not staggered in the slightest - you have to absorb a bunch of things at once with little to no instruction. "Open world roguelike" isn't nearly as fun as it sounds.

Some things are also simply not telegraphed at all - it's not a matter of forgetting to check my journal, it's a matter of "there was simply no way to know this would happen until I failed at it."

Would I recommend ADOM? No, absolutely not.
Was it a fun ride? Yeah. I've had a good time, but there are many games better to have a good time with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060935142', 'num_games_owned': 1827, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5925, 'last_played': 1699242259}
review:
This game is easily one of my top rogue-likes. It does take a little tinkering to make it work perfectly on Linux, but it's easy enough to Google a guide for it.
The biggest draws for me are that you can
1) Customize how easy or hard you want it to be
2) Aren't locked into rigid play styles based soley on your class or race. Sure there are some benefits you only get from those, but you still have lots of flexibilty to play differently
3) The game is deep and complex, and there's a ton to learn and do
I strongly recommend to anyone that likes roguelikes, and you can play the terminal version for free to try before you buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198194996770', 'num_games_owned': 273, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1693542182}
review:
I'm heavily conflicted on ADOM. The more I play games that are either updated versions of ASCII classics or grandfathers of modern genres (or, in the case of something such as Dwarf Fortress, both), the more I keep people talking about how ADOM is as good as it gets with the roguelike genre or other classic ASCII-based games.

So, upon seeing it on sale on Steam, I decided to pick it up - and I both wholeheartedly agree with the people who love this game and the people who despise it.

I could go on about lots of different problems I have with this game. The fact that "Standard Mode" literally is not the standard mode of play (actually, it hides multiple major aspects of character building that you NEED to metagame to have a successful run). The fact that the tutorial, while a good starting point, needs to be expanded upon greatly. The fact that you HAVE to experiment in order to understand what's going on with unexplained items and systems, and in doing so can just... kill your own run.

But what is the greatest flaw of this game? For me, it's the fact that you are borderline forced into metagaming ADOM. If you don't follow a specific order of steps (depending on which of the like, 3 "viable" builds you're going for) your run will FAIL. PERIOD. There is very little room for experimentation, or testing out fun new strategies, or anything that most other roguelikes have.

The randomness of ADOM isn't what drives the player forward to victory; it's what you're supposed to overcome. There's not really any "boon" that I see with the randomness of this game - it's literally all roadblocks preventing victory. I don't understand where the "fun" is in that department.

"Losing is fun" only works when the player has felt agency with their actions. ADOM makes me nothing but frustrated at an archaic, needlessly hard system that punishes ingenuity and creativity. Where's the fun in that?

review:
This didn't appeal to me overall but I don't think it's a bad game. I found the controls charming and retro. The amount of interaction depth was interesting but ultimately the visuals, combat, and overall gameplay felt like a pack-in game that would come with my PC in 2004.

If you're looking for a game that feels like you're playing a solo OSR-style ttrpg, I think this is pretty close.

author: {'steamid': '76561198424613451', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 33630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25273, 'last_played': 1708188220}
review:
ADOM is one of the classic original roguelikes; like Nethack, it keeps the original spirit of roguelikes, by being a very difficult, unforgiving, and occasionally unfair game, with a steep learning curve, concerning both mechanics and progression. 

The Steam version provides several quality of life improvements, such as graphic tiles, tutorials, character and game mode customization, roguelite features such exploration mode (start with a Wand of Wishing), turn off permadeath (very handy to become familiar with the game), easier & harder modifiers (monster health, drops), and a bit of new content (when compared to the last version before Steam). It still has the ASCII mode for people that are already familiar with it, which also has some small improvements (like monster  health bar). 

If you are into roguelikes, you already know ADOM! Returning players will enjoy the facelift, fixes, and a bit of new content.

For new players, the graphical mode makes the game much more accessible, along with (some) added tutorials and references (along with the noted quality of life improvements). Nowadays there are excellent resources available for it too, such as the Wiki and the ADOM IGB (which has been updated since), that I would advice any player to keep handy and refer to often!  I would recommend disabling permadeath if you want to get to know and experience more of the game first (that is what I did 2 decades ago with a small shell script :P); but as with all roguelikes, the true experience is in the possibility of certain death at any time.

With all of that said, you should still be warned, this is one of the original granddaddies of the genre! It will play just as you would expect for a game of its era and style when played as intended: It will hurt, you will die, hopefully learn something from, and take a step forward each time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198178766427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1412, 'last_played': 1708882399}
review:
This game is brutally difficult, wish this also clocked my F2P version hours to validate my point that I've still never finished the game - but it is so. much. fun. It really is one of those games where the world happens around you, not because of you, abandon a quest too long? oops that person you were meant to save has carked it already, regardless of when you accepted the quest, better do that sooner ;). You want the true/good/perfect ending? BOY is your work cut out for you. This is one of those games that really feels like an adventure, with the amount of time you need to put into this game, learning the mechanics, people, quests, Alignment, equipment, curses, magic, guilds, skills, stats, the list goes on and on. 
I really feel like everyone has to try this game atleast once if they enjoy and a good adventure or wish to play an OG of the difficult roguelike genre, this game is seriously good and the devs should be proud of their work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198989036122', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 22940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18026, 'last_played': 1685367618}
review:
This game captured 300 hours worth of my interest but ultimately left me unsatisfied. A contrast this with Dark Souls and the other Soulslike games, which I played a similar amount of time  but left a warm feeling in my heart.

Still, I can recommend this game, but only with huge caveats. What I dislike might not be an irritant for you.

This is an old school roguelike game with a heritage from a different era. An era when masochism in gaming was a virtue. An era when finishing the game, perhaps, was not really the goal, but playing it regularly for years, perhaps, was. See, back then there weren't many games to play. If a game took 50 hours to play through and that was that, it wasn't really all that satisfying because, well, what other game were you going to play next? If a game took hundreds or thousands of hours? That game could become your favorite game to learn and master. Different times.

Maybe look at it this way: with games like Chess, Backgammon, any card game, etc., the point is an enjoyable pastime. Back in the 80s and 90s there were games attempting to be pastimes and not necessarily games that you played through and "won" and moved on from. This is one such game.

Do you like to fail a lot? Do you like to lose tens of hours of progress to stupid mistakes? Do you like death by RNG? Do you have no life? If so, you might like this game.

The game is not supported any longer. The developer has gone dark for many years, with the last blog post on their development website saying essentially "well, I'm now a VP of IT at my company and have less time so I'm going to focus on my other new game -- Ultimate ADOM." Ultimate ADOM has also gone dark, so you get the picture. An indie developer has gone dark. It happens, and I understand it. The developer tried and the games didn't take off, and he now needs to make a reliable living. Anyway, if on Linux you'll have to search around steam forums for a binary patch against the executable to get menus to display properly. The game doesn't work under Wine.

The game does have an active wiki, and even active players today, an a slightly active discord, etc., all of whom seem to be long time players for whom the game clicks with. There are some easier class/race combinations and some combinations best left to experts and true masochists. There is a well maintained wiki, and active discussions. People can speed run the game in a few hours but you will likely take dozens and dozens.

You gain power in this game primarily through items. Finding a great artifact weapon can mean that you "should" win the game. Secondarily, power is gained through leveling and stats. There are many interactions where simply your stat or level difference is a big part of the dice roll.

Secondarily, the above is a lie. You gain power in this game by learning the game yourself. Which enemies are safe to engage without much cause for concern,  and which ones have insta-death attacks? If you don't spoil yourself by checking the wiki for every encounter you're likely to need dozens and dozens of attempts to "win" the game. Also, good luck piecing together the many different quests and story lines without the wiki.

The user interface for this game is bad. It was developed in an era where everybody used full 101 layout keyboards with a number pad. Diagonal movement is accomplished by pressing the numbers 1, 3, 5, 7, and 9.  Also, you might also think that "quitting" meant "quit the game" -- and it does -- but not in the way you think. Simply pressing "Q" and answering yes effectively has your character commit suicide and DELETES YOUR SAVES. No confirmation beyond pressing "y" at the "Quit the game?" prompt. What you want is "Save" -- press "S" followed by "y" instead, and "Save" also quits the game in the way most everybody would expect.  I've lost two characters with tens of hours invested to simply pressing Q and answering yes without thinking much about it.

The game is full of little and big paper cuts like this. Some might consider this its charm, others like me might just call it unrefined and ultimately very annoying. 

A possible saving grace is that the Steam version includes a "standard" mode that retains save files on death. You do not get any Steam achievements playing this way, though. You can even play with "personalized" settings that make the game easier in various ways.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007343154', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 449, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1455903507}
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018277440', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 369, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1697849482}
review: These traditional roguelikes really really need to all have custom keybinds. I have been gaming for 38 years now and have played thousands upon thousands of games over those almost 4 decades. One of the ways this is possible is by adopting a universal control scheme for whatever gaming device I am using be it racing wheel, HOTAS, VR, controller, or keyboard and mouse. When a game deprives me of this option I find it the rank amateur in contention. I am paying money for a well realized and professionally made product, when I receive anything less it is deplorable. It is possible to change keybinds by opening up the game files and editing them, but this is not something I should be bothered with, and the ONLY reason its even VAGUELY tolerated here is because this is only one of about 10 worthwhile traditional roguelikes available on the market, so you get my $15 and extra effort in making your game playable.

review:
In an effort to combat my backlog, I've decided to try and play every game I own on steam, in alphabetical order for at least 30 minutes, and then give my first impressions. This is game #7.

I've never heard of this game before now, and that baffles me. While not my cup of tea, I can't express enough the freedom this game offers you to make your own story. And for a game from 1994, no less. This must have been groundbreaking for its time. Highly recommend if you're a D&D fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1673158742}
review:
ADOM (Ancient Domains Of Mystery) is a difficult game to write a review for.  Some things are good, some things are very bad.  About the game... this is a 1990's era ripoff of Rogue/Hack, but the developers kept on improving it by adding GUI skins and primitive 2D graphics to support the experience.  Like the Rogue/Hack games this is unabashedly ripping off, it's a Dungeons and Dragons like derivative RPG where you wander around the wilderness, dungeons, bash stuff up and die horribly to RNG.  More on the problems of RNG centric design later on.  You do get a huge array of different character classes, races, spells, abilities and so on, so you can build all kinds of gnarly characters and this is a plus.  It's a shame then that there's also design deficiencies that will (and have) deterred many gamers.

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

When you try for the best looking graphics, you'll find there's no options to change the resolution for the game (beyond fullscreen or window) and no meaningful ways to customise the graphics settings when you choose the graphical tileset modes.  All you can do is opt for the original ASCII style DOS character "art" the game originally had, which obviously removes the graphics.  Of course gamers will eschew that, but in the tileset mode there's no way for gamers to ensure this is running at the native resolution of their displays... there's no guarantee this game will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.  There's no way for gamers to try improve the low quality graphics.

The game tileset mode features simple, cartoony 2D graphics, of the type you normally expect to see in low effort mobile apps, and if you don't want those you have even less choice, you have to go back to pre-1990's standards.  I'm aware that in this case it's because this is a game from the 1990's... but it's not 1993 anymore.  It's 2023.  There's more competition for gamers time than ever before.  Considering this is being evaluated as a PC game, having the graphics phoned in like this isn't going to result in a high quality, visually impressive game that PC gamers are used to seeing.

The game features no proper overarching level design or game/story flow/plot, as they opted to try to use samey repetitive procgen algorithms as a substitute for adding such content to the game, to avoid doing the important job of level/map design.  As a result, the game doesn't actually have any content worth mentioning, just endless, boring, repetitive, soulless algorithmically generated sameyness.  Developers must learn that procedural generation is not an acceptable substitute for content.  Once more I know that's because this is a ripoff of Hack/Rogue, but if those games came out today, they'd die in a miserable, lonely heap.  It's not the 1990's anymore.  Games like Mass Effect and Baldurs Gate happened.  Content is king. 

Despite being a single player game, the developer infested the game with an anti-cheat.  That's unnecessary and quite an annoyance. 

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

Like I said this is a difficult review because this is one of the best Rogue/Hack ripoffs out there... but you can also see it does carry a lot of defects (in fairness, some of which are just from the ancient, outdated and obsolete game concept).  While it's a labour of love, it doesn't compare well to cheaper AAA games on Steam.  If you had to tell a gamer with $15 and his first bleeding edge gaming rig to choose between a 30 year old Hack ripoff that doesn't even have 3D graphics, and a game like Skyrim or The Witcher (and some change left over if they buy both on sale), what are you going to tell them?

ADOM (Ancient Domains Of Mystery) didn't appeal much to the people who own a copy of the game, either.  It has achievements, and they show us a very clear picture that the game didn't really capture any interest from gamers.  The most commonly and easily attained achievement is for playing the game long enough to die (pretty easy due to Rogue/Hack RNG), and only around 35 percent of players bothered to get that far before uninstalling the game.  Hardly a success story, gamers just weren't all that interested in the game on Steam.

Once more we see greedy devs trying to scam Steam gamers. On Steam, this is $15 USD, but it's free to play if you go to their website and download it.  The Steam version has just a couple of somewhat irrelevant features that don't come close to justifying this price gouge.  Remember, you can get Skyrim or a Witcher game for less than $15... so what are the developers playing at here?  Developers must learn Steam gamers are not here to be gouged, and can't be expected to pay a whopping $15 for a free game just because it's been lazily dumped on Steam.  This is unacceptable disrespect for Steam gamers.  If you really want to play this after all is said and done, don't buy it on Steam, just download the free version, but you have better alternatives.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968413283', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1670217140}
review:
Update 2024: If my original review of ADOM resonates with you for all the reasons ADOM sucks, look at [url=]https://store.steampowered.com/app/2399160/Soulash_2/Soulash 2[/url]. Seriously!

----

Skip this game if you're not interested in grinding your face against someone else's idea of "you must suffer to have a good time."

Googling indicates this game has anti-cheating mechanisms in place, which have no place whatsoever in a singleplayer game, not even if it does have some kind of online leaderboard. I started a game with a character who had godlike stats, but even the [b]first[/b] dungeon - the Puppy Dungeon, where you go to find a [i]lost dog[/i], was absolutely [u]filled[/u] with [i]absurd[/i] numbers of monsters, that kept getting tougher and tougher, until I got dumpstered by something that moved like greased lightning, Corrupted on hit, and tore my character (who had gone from level 2 to level 10 beating her way through that dungeon) apart in like two hits. So either that was the anti-cheat wasting my time, or it was some kind of Oblivion-style monster-escalation wasting my time.

Also, I chose to make a Dwarven Weaponsmith, thinking that I would be able to make my own equipment. I started with a 1,000-stone anvil in my inventory, but (a) there is actually no item-crafting system, only item-improvement, and (b) even though you have an anvil, you need to find a forge, and the only guaranteed forges one will find either charge a mind-blowing quantity of gold to use, or are in dangerous locations, leaving you with hoping that you find one, at random, in a dungeon, which is also a dangerous location.

I regret spending money on this game, and I regret "giving it a try" for longer than the two hour Steam refund period. This game is not fun, it's not designed to be fun, it's designed to be sadistic to the player.

author: {'steamid': '76561198180342335', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4073, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1947, 'last_played': 1702380327}
review: I've been playing this game since the 90's. I recall downloading the guides onto drives to take to my school library/computer classes so I could pour over them. This is a roguelike in the truest sense of the genre. You don't get progress points for death so you just have to plan your approach differently. I admit freely that I have never beaten this game and I am at the point where I likely never will, but it has always been an enjoyable adventure long or short. The gameplay is a bit dated but if you feel like a lot of the games you are playing lately are just sparkling cash grabs with no depth of gameplay then this is the game for you. This game just oozes depth and gameplay. I remember very fond moments of teleporting around dungeons because I managed to gain teleport control from eating a blink dog and permanent invisibility from drinking at a pool. if you don't like games that take you on an adventure that is 99.99% likely to kill you at the end then give this one a pass. Otherwise go for it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198260623754', 'num_games_owned': 3600, 'num_reviews': 200, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1666160294}
review:
[h2][b]太容易死了吧...[/b][/h2]
本作是將 1994 年的 ADOM 圖像化後的 D&D 類型遊戲。可以選擇的種族與職業非常多樣，技能種類也頗為豐富。個人沒有經歷過舊版遊戲的年代，但這款遊戲該有的 D&D 要素都有。骰子機制被隱藏在遊戲背後的邏輯運算，沒有顯示出來，這點就見仁見智。語言只有英文，不過只要你能看懂遊戲常見的單字，基本上玩起來沒什麼障礙。

然而，遊戲缺點非常多。首先， UI 操作也非常不直覺，遊戲中的各種功能被分配在鍵盤上莫名其妙的位置，完全沒有經過優化和統合。角色中毒難解，補血方式不夠方便。蟻穴無限量產螞蟻，放著不管螞蟻又會破壞地下城牆壁，強迫症玩家難以接受。掉落的裝備有 10% 機率帶有詛咒，裝備後無法脫下，但是只有當玩家脫下裝備時才知道該裝備是否帶有詛咒，非常噁心人。遊戲成就必須玩 HARD 難度才能解鎖，但是 HARD 難度又非常容易死亡，這導致我每打完一兩場戰鬥就必須備份存檔。

[h2][b]總結[/b][/h2]
有鑿於以上的缺點，個人不推薦本作給一般玩家，但如果你是喜歡 D&D 的硬核玩家，可以嘗試看看。建議入包或骨折價入手。

個人入手價格：約NT$ 22 (第三方賣 key 網站)

author: {'steamid': '76561197986406527', 'num_games_owned': 350, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 34445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31067, 'last_played': 1664751594}
review:
It only took 20 years for my first legitimate win. and no, it wasn't Ultra Ending or Nihilist Ending - yes, there is a secret ending where you destroy the whole world. Betcha you didn't know about that! I learned about it a day before this review.

If I'd get a real wish, I would wish that these playing hours weren't just the tip of the iceberg of my playing hours before Steam release. Soooo, If you wanna get married to a game, get this. It gets personal real fast.

I know, the interface is horrible and it might not feel worth it to learn it since there is so many better options these days for games like these. Personally, for me it was easy because back in the day I had this 486 PC which was slow as ass and barely ran Duke Nukem 3D on the lowest settings. This game quickly became my Baldur's Gate out of scarcity basically. Still, after all these years I still play it, not out of nostalgia, but for the real challenge and the will to beat it. I am still looking forward to seeing those other endings myself.

Just keep in mind that there is a free version of this game with graphics and sounds on the ADOM-website. There's of course the ASCII version as well if you just want to see the world burn. Or if you are a true nihilist world ender, you can also find all old versions of the game there as well, which don't have any quality of life improvements. I mean, this game doesn't have a limit on how hard it can be. It's like a buffet of punishments!

Anyway, get it if you want a never ending challenge for the rest of your days.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000626756', 'num_games_owned': 2642, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1690448624}
review:
Title screen background art was blurry even in 1080p...

There are a lot of typos in the instructions/help/dialogue, and it is distracting.

The *default* control scheme is needlessly redundant and overly complicated.

The UI/HUD is overly large while the map initially/oftentimes is surprisingly tiny, even in 1080p on a 90+ inch screen.

The tutorials tell you to read the How To Start section of the manual, but make this particular section of the manual annoyingly tough to locate.

The game seems to function horribly on Steam Deck in the five minutes I spent with it there. Half of the text is unreadable due to its coloration or its size. And the controls rear their ugly head yet again.

ADOM HD Deluxe is not different enough from better games in the genre (such as Caves Of Qud, primarily) to justify its price tag, despite being on sale for half-off at my time of purchase. If you yourself have even one traditional roguelike in your library (Caves Of Qud, Tales Of Maj'eyal, Tangledeep, Dungeonmans, One Way Heroics, Cataclysm Dark Days Ahead, etc., even things like Desktop Dungeons and Sproggiwood), don't bother with this one.

I did admire and enjoy the plea for a postcard for the dev(s) in the game's manual, though!

author: {'steamid': '76561198062355060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1942, 'last_played': 1693591214}
review: Been playing since it was strictly ascii, Tom Biskup is a fucking legend for asking to be paid in postcards

author: {'steamid': '76561198138173212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 63169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63169, 'last_played': 1574279512}
review:
The over 1,000 hours I've spent playing this game on Steam are probably less than half the time I've actually spent playing it, as I began with it many years ago when it was available online. I still play it in ASCII mode. Why? Because the graphics aren't much, but the depth of game play makes this one of the best games I've ever played. 

Freed from the need to animate everything, the game is able to provide complex, challenging, and at times bizarre levels of detailed interaction. It's got a broad scope, allowing you to range across a whole country filled with challenges and areas to explore. It's got a wide range of classes and races that you can mix and match and intriguing mechanics like farming, multi-ending quests, alignment effects, sacrificial altars, and background corruption. 

ADOM includes a wide variety of "challenge" endings as well; I've beaten the game several times, in different ways each time. It's role-playing tilted enough to let you really feel that you've built a character who is a person, and strategic enough that you have to make tough choices about what to pursue and when to go after it. It's a high-mortality game at low levels, but it's engaging, maddening, fascinating, and a world I have gone back to more than any other.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989680747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 645, 'last_played': 1662938882}
review: I can understand the corruption mechanic to a degree, but the fact that it doesn't catalogue the changes drives me up a goddamn wall. At least tell me why my stats are tanking so I understand how I am being killed for gods sake. The lack of clarity eliminates any possiblity of forming a counter strategy other than just avoiding shit IN THE FIRST DAMN DUNGEON!!! God damnit. Just play Caves of Qud.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058533366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 7170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1873, 'last_played': 1685681104}
review:
If you liked playing NetHack or Rogue, but you wished it had just a bit more depth or an open-world feel, you've come to the right place. ADOM is the evolution, perhaps even the apex form, of the classic top-down dungeon crawl.  It features open world exploration, NPCs with quests, a wide array of character types with unique abilities, and more! All of which gives ADOM nearly limitless replay ability. 
So, whether you're looking for a quick no-save run like Rogue, or a custom experience where you can save and reload, ADOM will amaze and captivate you. Fair warning though: You might soon wonder just where all your free time went. :)

review: 2 hours into a run that is going well, I accidentally cast a magic missile into the wall next to me in a narrow hallway. author: {'steamid': '76561198089564454', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 675, 'last_played': 1659444975}
review:
Куча искусственной сложности(хотя "куча специально созданных неудобств" подходит больше), которую преподносят как некий "хардкор".

Механика голода не нужна, вы просто ходите и жрете трупы врагов, любые пайки стоят копейки, скилл "готовки" не нужен, нет никаких рецептов блюд или вроде того, просто превращение гнилого трупа в жаренный труп, который гниет дольше.

Любые союзники(саммоны, миньёны некромантов, просто рекруты и т.д.) просто следуют за вами, они НЕ атакуют врагов, для этого им нужно отдать приказ, а для этого вам нужно нажать 4-5 РАЗЛИЧНЫХ кнопок и два раза навести мышку(сначала на того кому приказываете, а затем на место или врага) и так вы ОБЯЗАНЫ делать для КАЖДОГО рекрута/миньена/пета. Сами же миньены перестают следовать за вами если теряют вас из вида(что в данже происходит каждые 5 ходов), а переходят на иные этажи с вами ТОЛЬКО если стоят вплотную к вам. 
Также, если ваша скорость не дай бог становиться хоть немного выше дефолтной, можете смело забивать на игру через миньенов, они за вами просто перестанут следовать.

Теперь о магии. У любого заклинания по неведомой причине ограничено кол-во кастов, так что вместе с маной(PP) вы будете терять и "заряды" заклинания. Восполнять эти заряды можно прочтением того же тома, из которого вы это заклинание и выучили, вот только по какой-то РЕАЛЬНО НЕВЕДОМОЙ причине тома ТОЖЕ имеют ограниченные заряды. Также, книги по какой-то причине весят как полноценные тела гуманойдов, ну да ладно.

Автолевелинг. Мобы всегда сильнее вас(в плане лвл), как минимум такого же лвла в ранних данжах для новичков, конечно есть различного рода эксплойты, но обычно люди не хотят таким заниматься. Прибавляем к этому ещё тот факт что игрок ограничен 50 лвлом, а мобы могут поднимать уровни бесконечно.

Скорость респавна мобов. Сама по себе механика бесконечного респавна врагов нормально вписывается в игру, в которой куча искусственных ограничений, вот только в большинстве данжей последние этажи принято ознаменовывать резким поднятием сложности, само по себе это минусом не является, но иногда скорость респавна поднимают настолько, что некоторые данжи из-за своей корридорности становятся непроходимыми БУКВАЛЬНО, иногда мобы заполоняют каждый тайл корридора и респавняться быстрее чем вы их убиваете(даже если вы их ваншотаете), хорошо если такая пробка образовалась только с одной стороны корридора, но обычно вас просто запирает в толпе бесконечно респавнящихся мобов.

Поиграйте лучше в более современные роуглайки, благо выбор есть.

P.S. Совет чисто по личному предпочтению: присмотритесь к Tales of maj'eyal, игра не менее(если не более) комплексная и куда менее раздражающая, можно скачать бесплатно с официального сайта игры и затем привязать к стиму.

author: {'steamid': '76561198337758844', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 6258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1826, 'last_played': 1703279234}
review: I would give this game a 3 out of 5 stars and only the good of a rating because it is quite entertaining at first when there seems to be so much exciting stuff to learn.  But after a while you realize it is full of bugs and glitches... you just cant tell if its a glitch or bug initially (like say your character is suddenly gaining hunger at 4 times the normal rate so you figure you must have done something that is effecting it but later look at the log and nothing should have been affecting it).  Then besides the bugs and glitches it has a simply horrible concept called Vile Spirits that are enemies spawned from deaths of your previous characters, they are incredibly dangerous and seem to love spawning in the low level areas to kill off any new character you make. But despite how garbage I feel this game is at times... Its a love hate thing and I find it very entertaining.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054720674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 367187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284301, 'last_played': 1700341309}
review: I've played this game since the early 90s, and as far as I'm concerned, it has the BEST key binding set of ANY roguelike game. It's also delightful that improvements and updates have continued for this long.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991257362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 7595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7595, 'last_played': 1659996719}
review:
Brutal game and gets more of a slog later in game that imo makes it not as fun. (insanity).  It scratches the itch of a dungeon crawler but I would advise to read guides online.   I never finished the game (close) but just got to be a slogfest with the levels of "insanity" at deeper levels.

The game is meant to be roguelike but I cannot imagine most people playing w/o backing up their save games.  One specific spot in the game that is brutal for any player is their first encounter with a siren.  Unless somehow you are psychic to get some bees wax ear plugs (seriously) - it's an instant death encounter where the expectation is to start all the way from the start?  Absurd.  Too many events like this make not backing up saves foolish.  Other reviews state the fun in discovering things like what foods do by trial and error makes the game.  

Maybe if there wasn't such brutal results most of the time, but these risks are far more negative than the potential for a positive.

Other annoying things are being locked out of content because you didn't get to a dungeon by a certain level.  With "insanity" giving you negative traits, one cannot savor the environment and explore or take time to find secrets.

Most will go online and read walkthroughs to  get through the game. W/o doing this there is a better chance a teen will die of old age before completing the game w/o those guides and hints.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007278293', 'num_games_owned': 2539, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1662069858}
review:
I've played the original ADOM ages ago and it's still a lot of fun with plenty of discoveries to make... and horrible mistakes to make. I never could get very far in this game because of course I have to wear every strange bit of armor and eat the poisonous things so I get killed in the very beginning, but the graphics did make the game a whole lot easier to play.

You can still play it in the original ASCII art form, though, but I'd only recommend it to someone who enjoys difficult roguelike games and possibly has played ADOM before, as well.

review: A great game with a huge replayability potential - I've been playing it since 2000. There is some stuff that will annoy you: like grinding for an amulet of life saving or a wish, running away from cats, or sacrificing monsters to get pre-/post-crownings, etc. But there is also lots of fun stuff: when you manage to kill a much stronger monster upon finding a magical wand in your inventory, learning to play with a new race/class combination, finding a random artifact early in the game, deep-diving the infinite dungeon to retrieve the Sceptre of Chaos or kill Filk, or simply tearing through the Elder Chaos God with the axe of the minotaur emperor like he is no match to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131324232', 'num_games_owned': 1322, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8764, 'last_played': 1657352222}
review:
I've been playing ADOM since late 90's and never gotten far. 

The game is essential roguelike like no other. Every turn matters. You might end up throwing rocks like your neighbour's special case child, You might end up becoming the rock pelting god daemon the forces of chaos are afraid of. Or invisible teleporting troll. It's up to you. One of the best video games ever made. 5/5

The graphics upgrade is actually good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000697176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1651731934}
review:
No ability to customize keybindings? Forcing me to use a numpad which I don't have or my MOUSE to play a roguelike?? Yeaaaah, nah. I spent more time trying to find an "adom.kbd" file that would work for vi keyset than actually playing the game, only to find out it's not even possible any longer.

[h1]There is currently zero keybind customization in ADOM [i]at all[/i]. Either through config file or in-game settings.[/h1]

From what I understand from reading their forums & the community discussions, the devs removed the capability to customize keybindings via keybindings file or any in-game settings so-as to not "overwhelm" RL noobs. Supposedly, at least.

Most games I'm fine learning new schemes, but roguelikes? Nah. That's like giving me an FPS with numpad movement that you don't allow remapping. To me, at least, that's how it feels. I don't have a numpad and I really don't want to roguelike with my mouse. I'll stick with brogue, dcss, tome4, cdda, *band, IA, BAM, TGGW, CoQ, cogmind, ELoNA, etc... etc... or any of the other dozens of roguelikes that support vi keybinds. (I can't even think of another trad RL that I can't at least remap for vi-keys...)

I mean, I can understand why you simplified things, but really, what year is this? How much does it cost from a code-perspective to allow customization? Let us customize our own shit, please. Don't simplify at the cost of regressing things people use, especially for a genre so niche as this one. Keep numpad/mouse as default for laymen. That's totally fine, but don't do so in a way that locks out older fans of the genre that have a hard-ingrained traditional -- very common, even [i]standard[/i] -- preference & flow, please.

Comments enabled in hopes somebody can correct me and tell me it's possible to setup keybinds so I can buy it again and finally give the damn game a go in a way that traditional roguelikes throughout many years have trained me to enjoy. I have no doubt I [i]could[/i] adapt & enjoy with a mouse, I just don't want to.... Personal problem? maybe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090528543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 11604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10014, 'last_played': 1653066198}
review: Honestly this is not a game for modern players.  It isn't quick or easy to get into.  The graphics are practically early-90s, the sound likewise.  The reason I play it is that I've done so since about 1996, when I first got online, aged 15.  Didn't have much PC firepower or internet bandwidth, and there wasn't much out there anyway.  I got it on AOL's games page back in the days when they tried to offer you everything.  I still play today because I still enjoy the story, and the challenge it offers.  It's not fast.  It's not slick.  It takes a while to learn.  It's not for people with ADHD.  I don't have ADHD.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057731813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1649631576}
review:
A purposefully obtuse game where you will die a lot to shit that doesn't make sense. It's a fine time waster, but after the time I've spent in the game I've yet to make any meaningful headway. It's pretty fucking ugly, the game world is devoid of life and character, the story is way overhyped, the gameplay isn't particularly fun (especially when shit will just spawn right on top of you in a dungeon, a lot), and compound that it's a rougelike, so have fun restarting from the beginning when you randomly can't hit an enemy that spawned in a room with about 14 others and now you can't move because they have you surrounded. People claiming this as some masterpiece are high out of their mind on nostalgia. This ain't it. For the same cost, you could just play Morrowind, a better game in nearly all regards, with similar dice roll-based mechanics.

I get that it's supposed to be difficult but a quest you get immediately in the game is to kill a boss that is nearly unkillable for low level characters and this boss has a mechanic that will PERMANENTLY gimp any sort of melee combat focused character. This shit ain't just difficult, it's outright unfun. For the 1% that enjoy this type of game, I doubt any of my complaints really do much for you, but this game will be absolutely unplayable for the other 99%. Game has literally 0 appeal aside from masochists who like to spend hundreds of hours wading through garbage controls and UX just to tell others to 'git gud.' This game does absolutely nothing to make someone who didn't specifically buy the game for that experience to want to learn all the mechanics and nuances.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095200163', 'num_games_owned': 1003, 'num_reviews': 204, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1649523390}
review:
88% positive reviews... 30 FPS? WTF? (Nuclear Throne had this issue also, luckily a community member modded it while the dudes at Vlambeer were telling people off on their forums.) Unluckily that isn't an option here. I will not play your 30-40 FPS B.S. on a 3.2 processor, 8 GB RAM, 1 TB SSD, 1060 GTX. Are you out of your f*ccing minds?

This game's lore may be okay. I didn't get to any of the game's story. But nothing else about it is good. Anyone saying this is good is just nostalgic from their childhood. Which I was ultimately saved from because today is the first time I ever opened this dumpster fire.

If you gave me two options: 1. play this or 2. I would be executed by shotgun blast to the back of the head blindfolded and kneeling in front of a shallow grave....I'd choose the second option.

The graphics aren't THAT bad. I mean mediocrity at it's finest. But then there's these disgusting looking text menus that look like a Commodore 64 literally threw up diarrhea on to your screen that ultimately destroy anything else graphically in the game.

To put it in perspective...i killed myself on purpose DURING the TUTORIAL by drowning, just so I didn't have to play anymore. Ironically my brain and eyeballs felt like they were drowning in the pools of obnoxious sh*tty text colors.

Don't listen to the lies that this game is good. Perhaps 20 years ago this was ballin' like NBA All-Star weekend. But it's aged like a methed out h**ker that's been beaten half to death by the year 1989 while pouring out the bleeding @$$hole of the goatse guy.

I wouldn't open this game again if it were the last game on Earth. I'd rather drink Freon than open this POS. I'd rather Magneto rip all the Iron out of my bloodstream through the pores of my skin than open this. I'd rather get struck by lightning, I'd take a trip in an electric chair with no wet sponge than open this.

Before anyone does the "git gud" sh*t...1. I'm never opening this disgusting garbage ever again.(So no.) 2. THE TOP REVIEW IS SOMEONE SAYING "It took me 20 years to beat this" with over 1k hours. And I'm not talking crap about that player. Hell dude, 1k hours in this crap chute...wow man, you'd give Mother Theresa a run for her money in the patience department. But literally think about that for a second though, that's not a skill issue. That's Stockholm Syndrome in gaming. A 20 year beat down and still loving the game...Absolutely not happening.

Your time is better spent with some animals if you do not own any other games.

Uninstalled, hidden forever. NBD

author: {'steamid': '76561198055279214', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1585840889}
review: I bought the Steam version to repay the years that I played this ASCII version. Scum saved my way through 3 endings. This game is as extremely deep its numerous dungeons & full of fascinating lore. This was an open world before it became a catchphrase. My characters have fried themselves, gotten destroyed on level 1 of dungeons, drowned,  turned into a pile of goo, and I loved it so much that my bro & I began opening doors from a diagonal IRL.

author: {'steamid': '76561198796851430', 'num_games_owned': 927, 'num_reviews': 3717, 'playtime_forever': 6628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6628, 'last_played': 1649291878}
review:
ADOM 是一款角色扮演游戏，玩家在游戏中扮演一名勇士，探索一个充满神秘和危险的世界。

1. 图形和界面表现不佳：
游戏的图形和界面设计较为简陋，缺乏细节和视觉吸引力。游戏的画面质量较低，角色和环境设计显得粗糙，缺乏细腻的纹理和光影效果。此外游戏的界面布局混乱，缺乏清晰的指示和提示，使得玩家在操作时感到困惑。

2. 游戏玩法缺乏创新：
作为一款角色扮演游戏，游戏玩法并未能带来新鲜感，缺乏创新和独特的角色扮演元素。游戏中的任务和谜题设计较为平淡，缺乏挑战性和趣味性。玩家在游戏中需要完成一系列任务，但这些任务的设计缺乏深度和多样性，使得游戏过程显得单调乏味。

3. 故事情节和角色发展薄弱：
故事情节和角色发展较为薄弱，缺乏吸引玩家的元素。游戏中的剧情发展缺乏连贯性，角色之间的互动和对话显得生硬和空洞。玩家在游戏中难以对角色产生共鸣，也无法深入理解角色的动机和背景。

4. 音乐和音效单薄：
游戏的音乐和音效较为单薄，缺乏丰富的背景音乐和生动的音效效果。这使得游戏的整体氛围较为平淡，难以给玩家带来沉浸式的游戏体验。游戏的背景音乐单调乏味，无法衬托游戏的氛围，使得玩家在游戏过程中感到无聊。

5. 技术问题：
在游戏过程中，我遇到了一些技术问题，如游戏崩溃、卡顿等。这些问题严重影响了游戏的整体体验，使得玩家在游戏过程中感到困扰。此外游戏在某些电脑配置上存在兼容性问题，导致游戏无法正常运行。

综上所述，在图形和界面表现、游戏玩法、故事情节、音乐和音效以及技术方面都存在一定的问题。这些问题使得游戏的整体体验较差，难以满足玩家的期待。因此我不推荐这款游戏给广大玩家。希望开发商能在未来的作品中，针对这些问题进行改进，为玩家带来更好的角色扮演游戏体验。

author: {'steamid': '76561197963583718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 308, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1694487609}
review:
A marginal thumbs up here.

The good:
Endlessly replayable casual turn-based roguelike.
Lots of depth in character development.
Old school in a good way.
It'd run on a potato.

The bad:
The antiquated interface, christ. So many keys to memorize.
Interactions with non-combat NPCs are awkward. The stores are ridiculously primitive, and remind me of something out of EA's Adventure Construction Set for the Commodore 64.
Perma-death and nothing is carried over to your next playthrough. Yes, I know this is a 'modern' innovation, but I can't help wishing for it.

Verdict: This is one of those old school roguelikes (like Nuclear Throne) that I will probably always have installed on my laptop. That said, I got it in a bundle, and I would definitely wait for a sale on this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064012974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1344, 'last_played': 1645936698}
review:
A great new version of the classic roguelike adventure game. One of the best of its type.

So much charm, and so many mysteries and details to discover.

So many fun ways to die. Playing this game NOT on ironman mode is a horrible waste.

This game offers one of the answers to the question of what alternatives there are to save-scumming game design, and why permadeath is an essential feature. Every game becomes its own thing, with its own real stakes, as opposed to the endless savescum games out there where the only thing at stake is how much time you're going to waste on a foregone conclusion, pretending you've accomplished something while you cheat yourself out of a real experience of risk and reward.

My only real criticisms of ADOM are matters of personal preferenence - e.g. I don't really like D&D style game mechanics, high-hitpoint games, nor the ever-rising hierarchical power levels and dire challenges of the later stages of the game, though I do appreciate many of their charms.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087865124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1643685452}
review: I have played a number of roguelikes, and honestly just found this one unpleasant. The interface is hard to work with, but most roguelikes make up for that with depth of interaction, and extensive customization. ADOM does neither of these. The game clearly has appearance options, but they are randomly decided for you. The interactions with the world are minimal, with little beyond attacking, talking, or activating abilities. All in all, I would recommend effectively any other roguelike over this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561199079222408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1643627627}
review:
None of the reviews are actually pointing out that ADOM has issues on Ubuntu/Linux. The font issue that has not been repaired for more than a year, according to this thread:

https://steamcommunity.com/app/333300/discussions/0/2646360608736518971/?ctp=6

I bought the game in good faith, wanting to thank makers for over two decades of free installments of ADOM that still roam through internet as freeware. I had to request refund as a very disappointed fan of roguelikes (obviously, as my nickname states) and return to ADOM after a longer hiatus. 

This version however is not the case, as long as it is not fixed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171164763', 'num_games_owned': 240, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1642281862}
review:
Expansive game with decent combat and RPG mechanics.
My first problem with this game is that it's buggy and crashes frequently. I couldn't even launch the lastest stable release and had to revert back a few versions.
The other problem would be that this game is EXTREMELY difficult even for veteran rouge-like players.
It's difficult to the point of not being fun anymore.
here's some examples:
#Some random mobs even in the starter dungeon can kill you 1v1
#HP regen outside of combat is basically non-existent
#You get hungry after like 100 turns and food weights A LOT. but don't worry you can cook monster corpses. oh wait you don't have the cooking skill? Well guess you're fuck ed then.
#Did you clear a dungeon after dying countless times? Well guess what, dungeons never actually get cleared. they re-spawn monsters indefinitely.
#Managed to clear half of the map thanks to your Godly luck and gaming skills and stay alive? WELL congrats, your character is an old fart now. you get minus to all physical stats and might actually die of old age.
In summery, playing this game is painful (at least for me) and it's not for the faint of heart, So it can't be recommended to most people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032447372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 972, 'last_played': 1641973341}
review: I mean, I get that the game is old-style. I get the unforgiving and random nature of the game. So, I gave this game a considerable amount of time. Went through half a dozen characters. But I wasn't able to find a way to enjoy the game. I don't know what it is exactly. Maybe the game is too disconnected, too puzzling, perhaps. But, after my last character died, I simply didn't care to make another one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093531348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 87378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87157, 'last_played': 1711052232}
review:
Roguelike遊戲的王者，最早登場的時間上稍晚於NetHack，也受NetHack的影響。不過我認為比NetHack來得更豐富一點。

身為可能是臺灣個位數玩hardcore模式全破過的人，我完全承認這不是普通人玩得下去的東西。首先你要習慣英文，遊戲並沒有太偉大的故事，但訊息有很多「眉角」，不要求很高的英文能力，但要能夠習慣。

這是一個你去網路上查各種攻略(還滿多的)，如果沒有真的玩過體驗過，大概也不得其門而入的遊戲。我基本上是用查資料的態度去看各種攻略的。而我也完全不反對看攻略，那是二、三十年的智慧結晶，光是去看網上的各種guide當文獻在k就很有趣了。

這個遊戲的魅力在於世界的豐富性，這種豐富性的體現，倒不是故事還是長長的技能樹與build，而是在於你的所有行動都有很多「眉角」。要類比的話，這並不是那種「靠智力研究出無敵的build」的遊戲，而是像傳統工藝一樣慢慢累積各種小眉角，漸漸提升生存率，漸漸加快遊戲的進行節奏，漸漸知道世界有那些威脅而要準備那些應對手段的遊戲。眉角實在太多，小技巧多到一言難盡，幾乎永遠學不玩。

不過倒不是說新手就完全沒有樂趣，其實一開始不要把破關當成是目標，看能活多久就很好玩了。這個遊戲有一大堆死法是在其他遊戲看不見的，然後玩久了就會經歷過很多非常荒謬的連鎖意外，像是大概所有玩一定時間的人，一定都有施展strength of atlas讓自己背得動一大堆東西，然後法術時效過後沒有注意，於是就被自己的背包壓死這種搞笑的事的。總之這個遊戲要小心的地方非常多，樂趣也在其中。

Steam版的一個好處是有可以S/L的模式，過去是只能用賤招才能存檔的。雖然本格派大概都是玩真實死亡啦。

這個遊戲雖然不是大紅，但也有相當大的社群，其中強者如雲，幾乎永遠可以找到各種你沒想到過的眉角。只是因為語言門檻比較高，然後臺灣這裡只有幾個像我一樣的神經病，說中文的玩家我目前其實除了我的親友之外還沒看過其他人，我自己知道全破過的則只有我而已。如果你想要一個在臺灣「與眾不同」的遊戲體驗，然後有點自虐傾向的話，可以試試這個遊戲。

author: {'steamid': '76561198099457217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 650, 'last_played': 1639614646}
review:
As a veteran of roguelikes i do not recommend this game. 
It seems to have stopped in 1995, being unnecessarily clunky, even for an ASCII roguelike:
1. repetitive pressing of multiple keys instead of a hotkey and unable to set behaviors
-additional unnecessary key pressing as well. EG: with only 1 monster on screen, why do i have to keep on selecting the direction i want to pickpocket?
2. auto explore is unoptmized and auto pick up (extremelly unintuitive design) is impossible to customize (eg: you cant make it so your char does not pick something while an enemy is hitting you, thus wasting a turn)
3. there are many situations mutually exclusive and level capped that you do not know about unless you read about it before, making the game impossible to play without a wiki open.

As a much better reference and at least as much "detailed" is DCSS. It takes you a couple of hours to learn, but once you do the game runs like a charm.

author: {'steamid': '76561198963205868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 833, 'last_played': 1709738685}
review:
I've been playing ADOM on and off since the 90's.
Simply put, it's one of the best roguelikes ever made. It's immersive, has infinite replay value, no games are ever the same, each adventure is unique, each character, and action, matter.
I've always felt, whenever playing, that if this game had, say, a first person perspective and a big team of people working on it, it would be known and enjoyed by way more people.
Don't mind my hours on record, this game exists free on the author's site, and back then I would play it like that, preferring the DOS version over the Windows one, actually; heh.
It's not just the tactical gameplay itself, and the chess-like difficult decisions that have to be made, that make ADOM a gem, but also its story, its lines of obscure philosophy and poetry, a game that makes you wonder, as you strive to get your character to survive, become more powerful, and save the world... or destroy it altogether.
I'll close this short review, too short for now, for ADOM's greatness, citing one of its exquisite quotes: "In the land of eternal darkness, light must come from within.".

review: An absolute classic - one of the few games that have helped spawn entire genre of games. The steam version is probably a bit more accessible than the traditional ASCII one (I assume you can still download it for free though and install your own tilesets). With different race/class/starsign combinations it takes a dedicated person to try them all. Only have a few minutes to spare? Jump into the infinite dungeon and just kill stuff and try to go deeper. ADOM expert? Try the community challenges. Finished it all? Well, go get yourself Dwarf Fortress I guess...

author: {'steamid': '76561198889655485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 9009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6316, 'last_played': 1692993126}
review:
Долины древние, горами окружены,
Держат стойко во тьмы глубине
Старших демонов против нас оруженых,
Что пришли хоронить нас в нашей земле.

Пали наши герои-воители, и волшебники с ними сгинули
В алом Хаосе все судьбу свою встретили.
Рождены были будто для этого,
Чтоб спасти всех нас от Конца Времён.

Но пророчества нам говорят, из-за гор что спаситель придёт, 
Что мечом, заговором и силой своей в земли мир он вернёт!

Вот так выживет мир, раз желает один, тот, кто правит всея

Древними Владениями Тайны! 

@

Данный продукт очень сильно отличается от того, что сейчас принято называть rogue-like. Сложность зашкаливает, причем сложность эта - стратегическая, а не тактическая: вы должны знать, чего хотите добиться, какие предметы выфармить и для чего. Иначе - Ещё Одна Глупая Смерть. Так почему в это играют даже те, кто осознаёт, что завершение игры им не светит в ближайшем будущем (а может и никогда)? Потому что опыт попытки прохождения ценнее, чем результат. Всё дело в невероятной продуманности механик взаимодействия с подземельями (в отличие от Tales of Maj'Eyal), c его обитателями (врагами, временными нейтралами и торговцами) и необходимости продвижения в глубину Пещер Хаоса на основе того расклада, что есть именно в эту попытку (надеюсь, у вас был план прокачки персонажа...). Нынче версия в Стим обзавелась отличными тайтлами (то есть плиточным графонием, серьезно, это красивейшие тайтлы, которые я видел) и даже недельными онлайн-челленджами на очки. Есть легкий режим для новичков (и даже отдельный режим туториала), и по сравнению с руж-лайк режимом он действительно легкий.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983729222', 'num_games_owned': 1936, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1637838537}
review:
Died in the tutorial because my starting sword broke and I ran out of arrows - 10/10.

Seriously though, I spent hours upon hours playing Rogue when I was a kid because my PC at the time did have a 3D graphics card.  I would wander around the caves, delving ever deeper, chugging every potion, reading every scroll, zapping every wand... and taking the consequences of my actions like a champ.  I still adore roguelikes/lites to this day, but I never thought I'd find a game like the one from my childhood again... until today.

Just playing through the tutorial was the ride of a lifetime.  The game is incredibly expansive and I am already deeply, DEEPLY in love with it.  I have finally been able to experience the gaming nostalgia of my childhood that I've heard others speak about when they reminisce about games on the NES or SNES (we were too poor for home consoles, but dad used to bring home PC parts from work that were gonna get scrapped and would cobble the bits together to make a working computer for us).

There are so many intricate systems and I KNOW I've only scratched the very surface of what is probably going to become my new obsession.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067654596', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1702135175}
review: Interesting game so much you can do, of course I actually dont like roguelike games with permdeath lol I always hope theres some way around it. Doesnt seem to be so Ill play more ..someday.  I did like the game even though theres a lot to learn and im a lazy thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106496410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1124, 'last_played': 1634485922}
review: ADOM is a lot more fun that I would have given it credit for if I hadn't been bored enough to try it out. The game is simple enough to pick up rapidly, but would require a great deal of play to master. It's incredibly unforgiving and you will die and lose characters you like quite frequently so best not to get attached. Just start over and enjoy what you can!
