author: {'steamid': '76561198093315649', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1700325907}
review:
It's an amazing game, but I can't recommend it. The version provided by steam is full of bugs on linux, whereas the free version runs without any problems. Go ahead and support the developer(s) for making this amazing game, but stay away from this steam version if you're on linux.

Bugs I've found:
- Some menu text is completely broken, sometimes having the same color as the background, and sometimes showing up properly.
- The game is completely frozen unless you move your mouse or give some kind of input. The frames straight up do not advance at all unless you press buttons or move the mouse, sometimes the frames stop advancing in the middle of an attack or something so you have no idea what's going on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003755005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1633380302}
review: Ich kenne das Spiel erst seit dem verfassen dieser Rezension. Es mag damals ganz hervorragend gewesen zu sein in einer Zeit in der es keine Roguelikes als RPG gab aber zur heutigen Zeit gibt es deutlich bessere Alternativen. Man kann schon Spaß haben am Game aber es gestaltet sich sehr undurchsichtig und man muss sich über alle Mechanismen selber informieren was nur dann geht wenn man dementsprechende Skills auch gelernt hat. Habe Jetzt 6 Charaktere quasi hospitalistisch begleitet und kann für mich sagen das mir das spielen einfach zu klobig ist. Es hat mir dennoch Spaß gemacht aber empfehlen kann ich es niemanden außer Hardcorespielern.

author: {'steamid': '76561198217689948', 'num_games_owned': 1077, 'num_reviews': 219, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1632510083}
review:
[b]ADOM[/b] premierę miało w czasach, gdy nikt nawet nie myślał o rogalikach jako osobnym gatunku gier. Gdy wychodziło w 1994 wyglądało jak arkusz kalkulacyjny - co było typowe dla gier cRPG tamtych lat, które miały być odpowiednikiem gry w D&D. Grafikę poprawiono, dodano kilka mechanik, które ułatwiają grę, ale wciąż czuć, że gra ma 27 lat :) 

Jeśli kogoś pasjonują takie gry, tęskni za tamtymi czasami albo zwyczajnie chciałby zobaczyć legendarny pierwszy rogalik, to myślę, że warto ją kupić. Dla mnie jest ciut zbyt archaiczna - zaczynając od menu walki, ekwipunku, a kończąc na strasznie irytującym mnie przeskakiwaniem postaci po planszy za każdym razem jak postać gracza się poruszy. Gdybyśmy żyli w 1994 roku, to zapewne grałbym jak głupi, bo potrafię zrozumieć powody, dla których niektórzy potrafią w tej grze spędzić kilkadziesiąt godzin a nawet tysiące, ale niestety mamy 2021 rok i takie gry są raczej tylko dla purystów gatunku, ewentualnie ogromnych zapaleńców, którzy ubóstwiają spędzać trzy godziny na myśleniu w co zainwestować punkty z lvlupu :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198028500255', 'num_games_owned': 546, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 8809, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2962, 'last_played': 1677859706}
review:
Do you know this dream, when you want to be a paladin in golden armour? Or a sneaky thief fighting with two daggers? 
This is all possible. 
U just need to survive until your hero will reach like 20-30 levels - maybe then Acid Vortex will not one-shot you. 
Or your mist elf won't die while changing the armour because you forgot that impure metals are poisonous to him. 
Or your 34 level troll beast fighter who crushes molochs with his bare hands won't die due to shitty ghost bat's ageing attack. 
Or your mighty spell-slinging bard won't get mauled by his companion, coz he activated an explosive trap in the door and the companion got hurt... if u survive all that, ADOM is all there for you baby! 
This game crushed my dreams more times than I can count. 
Still, it's very good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141511961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1632368831}
review:
This game is like trying to turn on a TV only you can't turn it on by pressing the power button like every other TV. But the TV comes with minimal crappy instructions so you spend an hour searching forums for a solution. Then you find out that first you need to flip a switch on the back then press the power button for 5 seconds then flip the switch back down before pressing the power button again only to have it not work. 

If you put in the time to learn how to play, it actually can be pretty fun but the game play mechanics are just awful. It plays much different than anything you have played before and the tutorial is absolute garbage. Things that should be simple are stupidly difficult. Like buying stuff from a merchant. You don't just talk to the merchant then buy things from a list of items, no that would make too much sense. You walk in and the items are on the ground. You pick it up then you need to pay the merchant but there is no clear way of doing it. He just stands there blocks the door so you can't leave. You talk to him, no option to pay. you give him money, doesn't work. I had to search forums just to figure out how to buy stuff, and I STILL CAN'T!! The game could be good, but it's just too freaking confusing and gives you little to no guidance. There are too many other great games out there to waste time searching forums learning how to do the most basic of activities.

I'm frustrated haha

author: {'steamid': '76561197998598944', 'num_games_owned': 2059, 'num_reviews': 1151, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1632173117}
review:
This is a deluxe version of an old ASCII game from 1994.  There has been graphics added onto this, but the clunky controls from textbased computer games if the early 90s are all here.  If that sounded like a recommendation, it's not.  Playing this in 2021 is really painful and challenging.

Either you are super nostalgic for this sort of thing, and you already know what this is, or you stumbled here (perhaps because this was in a humble bundle.)  If you aren't sure you'll like this, you probably won't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026301248', 'num_games_owned': 685, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1642019537}

review: Combat is either mind-numbingly easy where everything dies in one click, or it's virtually impossible to kill something. I never found anything in between after playing for 5 hours. Also, one meal ration weighs as much as two entire orc corpses... what?

author: {'steamid': '76561198171540335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1631329070}
review: Grew up playing lots of old school ADOM having many adventures in ASCII land. This is a faithful recreation of the same gameplay elements with more a intuitive interface. Great for a quick, uncomplicated romp down memory lane !

author: {'steamid': '76561198034660430', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 43009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42025, 'last_played': 1709184366}
review: 700 hours is just what steam says, but I've played ADOM long before it was on steam. I love this game and have for the last 25 years when I first discovered it. Yes it has a steep learning curve, yes it's brutal, yes you could lose a character you love in some unfortunate way, but ultimately every game feels unique, while the story and many of the players involved don't actually change, the dungeons do. You will spend a lot of time in the dungeons, better hope you don't come across an ultimate doppleganger.

author: {'steamid': '76561198382624658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 74949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61570, 'last_played': 1709995076}
review:
One of my favorite games of all time. It is extremely replayable. With all the classes, races, and star signs to choose from, each game feels a little different. The game may feel a little overwhelming for a new player, but that's just because of the insane amount of depth in the game. As you continue playing, you will greatly appreciate this depth. 

Warning:
The ADOM Wiki will be your best friend when playing this game because a lot of things are not explained in the game. For example, you could find an item called a ring of searching. The game will not tell you what that means. You have to look it up on the wiki. Also, it is somewhat unclear where to go to beat the game. You may either want to look this up on the wiki or watch some gameplay of someone who knows what they are doing (my favorite streamer for this game is Yulgash on twitch). Also it took me over 100 hours to beat the game for the first time.

With that warning said, I still highly recommend this game for anyone who is interested.

author: {'steamid': '76561198203348496', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 93476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35458, 'last_played': 1653706536}

author: {'steamid': '76561198182686398', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1630717733}
review:
Почему нет
1. В одном и том же данжене куча разных мобов идут один за другим, причем особой разницы в их убийстве я не заметил и за любым поворотом может встретиться моб который внешне ничем не будет отличаться от перебитой уже кучи, но который валит героя с пары тычков.

2. Невозможно зачистить этаж - мобы бесконечно лезут хрен пойми откуда. Причем не факт что перебив их целую кучу сзади не навалится толпа еще больше.


При таком раскладе вообще не понятно как играть без сейвов (играл с сейвами и перезагружался каждую минуту). А то что рандом отличается не просто от игры к игре, а он различен в рамках одной игре (сейв-лоад я считаю за одну игру) - это просто капец. Героя валит куча мобов, на следующем лоаде в том же место стоит один но мощный, в следующий раз вообще пусто.

author: {'steamid': '76561198256910978', 'num_games_owned': 343, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1693415562}
review: You know that one of the first quests where you need to bring a cute puppy back to the little girl? I think I might have killed it accidentally... [spoiler]Or not, if that "cute little dog" corpse isn't actually a puppy[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198115286919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 2739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1701412631}
review:
Игра хороша и удивительна. Но кажется, будто десятилетия игровой индустрии прошли мимо авторов, когда они решили осовременить свою игру 94 года. И да, до сих пор игра плохо оптимизирована и часто испытывает трудности в своей работе. К примеру, попытки настроить разрешение экрана привели к тому, что я теперь не знаю как снова привести игру хоть во сколько то удобоваримый вид. 
И да, покупать игру стоит - хотя бы из уважения к искусству, которым вы не факт что сможете насладиться ввиду кривости стимовской версии игры. И, продолжая пребывать в двояких чувствах, я буду пытаться заставить игру адекватно работать. Может быть, что то и получится.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149338035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 75678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 167, 'playtime_at_review': 60050, 'last_played': 1712449987}
review:
Having officially hit 1000 hrs with this game, yes, yes I would recommend ADOM.

One of the greatest roguelikes ever made. 
Learning curve: punishing
Defeat: crushing
Victory: rare and elating

author: {'steamid': '76561198041929355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 4157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1628863231}
review:
The performance of this game is so completely embarrassing that Thomas Biskup should really feel ashamed of himself for daring to ask actual money for it. A 15-Euro sprite-based 2D game should not have an average of sub-30 FPS with regular drops to below 15 FPS in menus on a computer that can run games like Assassin's Creed Odyssey at 60FPS. Biskup apparently didn't give a damn about optimizing this release for modern systems *at all* and I recommend against paying for it on the sheer basis of what a sloppily made product it is, even if it's otherwise a really good game. 

I'd return it if I hadn't gotten it in a bundle, because that's really just ridiculous. I sure as hell won't be wasting any money on Ultimate ADOM, whatever *that* is about, just because of the risk that it'll be even half as much of an incompetent mess as this one.

If you want a game LIKE this but better, check out WAZHACK (which has a co-op feature), Dungeonmans (which has a legacy system), or Tales of Maj'eyal (which looks basic but is insanely rich character/build wise) or lastly Barony (which is multiplayer and really interesting.) author: {'steamid': '76561197972598267', 'num_games_owned': 1474, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1627460898}
review:
The problem with the free ADOM is that the ASCII interface is impenetrable, particularly to infrequent and/or new players.

That problem is not solved with this version - it kicks you back to ASCII for many menus, actions need a smorgasbord of keyboard buttons, the tutorial prompts are tedious, etc. It is a 20 year old game, and the interface feels like it.

So why pay extra for this version over the free one? I don't know. If it was very cheap (~3$) then it might be justifiable. If you want to support the developer, then that's fine (though with Steam taking a ~30% cut there must be a more efficient way to do that, plus it was a big kickstarter). But if you want a new game? ToME and Dreadmore spring to mind, both easier to get into, and you can get both for less than ADOM.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995106339', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1631382450}
review:
[u][b]tl;dr[/b][/u]
[u][b]Not a good game nor a good roguelike, just try something else.[/b][/u]

[u][b]Let's list the cons:[/b][/u]

- [b]The interface is terrible[/b]. I know that the game is originally an ascii game and that the graphics are just a layer put on top of that, and (maybe) that would be acceptable... if this was a sub 5€ purchase... for 15€ this is unacceptable (to me). If you want to ask for that kind of money all parts of the game should be made so they can live in the present era

- The tileset is decent but [b]items are hard to see on the screen[/b] and you often have to watch the ascii minimap. It's not too bad but annoying and unnecessary, a glitter effect for dropped items would be enough to fix this (but I imagine it couldn't be done because of the limits of the game, I guess?)

- [b]The randomization of the floors of the dungeons is boring and uninspired[/b], they always look and feel the same and are not really exciting, I have yet to find interesting secret rooms or weird layouts, it's always the same long corridors with empty small rooms

- Having to solve the same quests in the same order at every replay, makes this feel more like replaying, over and over, again and again, a [b]perma-death single player game[/b] with no saves, more than playing a roguelike (boring dungeon layouts makes this even worse)

- [b]This game feels unfair and unbalanced[/b]. In the other traditional roguelikes I have played I always felt like I learned something after I died. In those games, thinking back on my death it was either: my fault for being too reckless or, I had the solution at hand but didn't think of approaching things that way. In this game I keep on dying and can't see what the solution would have been.

I can see people arguing about this point so let me reiterate:
roguelikes should not be about knowing that precise and unique way to approach things, I should not die because of that monster that one shots me if I don't use that specific tool to fight him, I should still be able to beat him, but at the cost of burning 2 (or so) healing potions to do so. That would make me die later in the game when I need healing potions and I don't have anymore. Then that would make me think back about how to optimize things and burn less resources to do the same things I did but in a better way.
Long story short, [b]roguelikes should be about slow and long term optimization[/b] that comes with knowing the game better over time, not brutal trial and error for inescapable things that can be solved only in a precise way. This is the most important thing that makes this game a bad roguelike in my opinion.

- Linked to the previous point, I never like to look things up for a roguelike, because discovery is the best part of the genre, but in this game I just felt a lot of the time that things made no sense at all and [b]had to look up the wiki a lot[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197979940363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 2852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2852, 'last_played': 1627159156}
review:
Very fun take on Roguelike games.  Very challenging and plenty of RNG.  I love the depth of the character options as well.

Pros:  Probably one of the deepest rougelike RPGs I've seen...tons of dungeons, tons of pathing options, varied items that keep it interesting, and a pretty impressive arrangement of enemies to fight. Lots of interesting quirks for min/maxing your character if you are into that.

Cons: Once you've got a handle on what you need to do and how you need to play, the depth of the game falls of drastically.  There comes a point  where you've seen every trap, trick, monster ability, etc that the game can throw at you and it becomes very rock / scissors / paperish.  Enemies become bullet sponges that do more and more damage.

I got this from humble bundle and played over 40 hours which was a fun time. It is worth the price for sure if you are a fan of  the genre and have never played it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067054607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 355, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1675910077}

review:

This terrible game is choppy and laggy.  If that's not enough reason to stay away, the developer insults you by calling you lazy for not wanting to memorize 50 hotkeys because the UI is abysmal.  My advice? Get the cards and uninstall.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140435102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1626198961}
review:
Preview
The game is ruthless permadeath survival. I found High Elf Ranger to be the strongest. Prices for the weapon in the shop that are worse than the ones I found are very high. Badly balanced economy. There is also not an easy way to talk to people, as they constantly move and especially equipped with ranged weapon, I shoot them instead of talking, and all their friends attack me immediately. There seems to be no real story, just a few quests. It is mostly about slaying hordes of enemies, sometimes, there are tough opponents, some magical debuffs, requiring us to pray. When we get stunned or dazed, we often get to be surrounded. Enemies spawn in places we cleared the rooms. Dungeons are pretty long and there is one button auto exploration which stops at items or enemies which is cool. So the exploration flows fast and well. The combat is mainly good when you are using arrows instead of mouse, and mouse requires directional kicks. Other than that, inventory is controlled mostly by alphabet and is quite cumbersome to get around, re-equipping the items, some of the items are cursed, preventing me to take them off while they provide me negative stats. I discovered the whole map. It has around a dozen of dungeons with a lot of random encounters which I could easily evade but unless you like grinding, stay away. The game also does not motivate me well enough to fight the same enemies over and over. Replay value is included in a lot of variety between races and classes, giving me different abilities and I seem to be able to learn them from different classes. It is an interesting game but feels aged pretty badly. This would be a mixed preview if it was possible. Not sure how much better can the game get but the first impression is pretty weak.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031965885', 'num_games_owned': 773, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1626187882}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970761123', 'num_games_owned': 2960, 'num_reviews': 904, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1672774742}
review:
This game is currently in the Humble Bundle for July 2021. If you are interested in the game and it's before August 3rd, 2021, consider picking up the game as part of the current monthly bundle.

This is perhaps the first time I’m talking about a TRUE rogue-like, ADOM was released in 1994, and it is one of the original rogue-likes and one of the best of all time.  I could probably spend an hour telling you why it’s good. 

This is called a deluxe version with more graphical modes beyond just standard ASCII, adding mouse control, multiple difficulty options, and customizations and achievements.  It has all the great gameplay that a roguelike should, a ton of classes, races, and possibilities, and so many different and unique interactions you’ll be able to experience. 

It’s also frighteningly difficult.  Rogue-likes are not intended for one-and-done playthroughs but rather take a lot of constant effort to learn everything you can just hope that the player can one day beat the game with one of their many characters. 

Pick ADOM up if … well if you love true rogue-likes, or want a hard but interesting game. I’m a fan, but I will say that most people probably won’t enjoy this game, it’s a style of game that is not that popular and perhaps never was.  It’s focusing on a far more strategic style of play which is why I talk about rogue-likes and rogue-lites often. 

I’d probably not recommend ADOM to most people even though I am a huge fan of it.  But if you like Rogue, Nethack, or Dwarf Fortress, it’s worth a try, and you can play the free version which includes almost the whole game including the better graphics at the ADOM website. It’s worth a try. 

If you enjoyed this review or want to know what I think of other games in the bundle, check out the full review on or subscribe to my youtube channel: https://youtu.be/UqdMreTnUns

author: {'steamid': '76561198005359039', 'num_games_owned': 1904, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 757, 'last_played': 1625875642}
review:
So, you got the key from humble monthly and wonder if you should play this game?

lemme help you out.

don't

unless you are a deep,*real deep* roguelike nerd, there is nothing here you will find more fun than the other one such a ToME, Tanglekeep,Brogue,sword of the star : the pit , crown trick and some more.

 the curse item mechanic is unfun at best and the tactic aspect of the game is shallow. You will spam your normal attack/throw rock a lot, since beside spell there is just no special move. Which is very, boring.

it's probably not a bad game. But it's not a great game by today standard.

review: I've been playing this game now on and off for 20 years. The graphics have evolved but the underlying game mechanics have not. Nor do they need to. The dungeons layouts are random and each game never plays out the same.  I have never been able to finish the main quest which is fine... the game is enjoyable without a final win. A refreshing change from games that can be won in only one way.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971191353', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 60247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 112, 'playtime_at_review': 29498, 'last_played': 1712446116}
review:
I don't write reviews often, but as I approach 500 hours of play time I feel I ought to do something to give back.

As one of the founding hits of the roguelike genre, ADOM is a game in which you should expect to die often.  In other games that can be a deal-breaker for me, but much of the genius of ADOM is in starting a new character.  ADOM is a game of near infinite variation: 12 truly distinct playable races, 21 classes that vary in play style according to the race and alignment of the character,  dozens of skills and talents that also materially change the play through.

ADOM has been one of my go-to's for more than 20 (30?) years and I still find myself surprised by new and puzzling situations and combats in this sprawling fantasy world every time.

It really doesn't belong in the video game category for me anymore.  It's become a favorite relaxing pass-time of it's own, like crosswords were for my grandparents, that I may drop into while chatting with a friend or listening to an audiobook or a certification course or just to enjoy letting my mind sink into all the detail and variation to unwind.

As I said, I'm not much of a reviewer.  I guess this is more of a thank you note.  To ADOM and Thomas Biskup et al, thanks for all the years of scintillating play and relaxation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075064862', 'num_games_owned': 412, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1622436788}

review:
It's ADOM. If you know that name from your old school gaming days then you'll love this updated version. It's virtually the same game but with graphical improvements and some handy tweaks to character gen.

But if you haven't heard of it then don't worry. Just jump in, meet the fans, and find out why this game has a real cult following.

Just remember the golden rule: Kill them, eat them, take their stuff!

review:
Ancient Domains Of Mystery'nin belkide en büyük eksiği Türkçeyi desteklememesi. Türkçe yamayla bir şekilde hallederim diyor olabilirsiniz ama oyunun bir Türkçe yaması da yok.
Oyun bu türü sevenleri kesinlikle üzmeyecek bir oyun fakat dediğim gibi ortalama veya ortalamanın üstü bir İngilizceye sahip değilseniz almayın.

author: {'steamid': '76561198365387598', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1620389197}
review:
Henüz hiç oynamadım ama güzel olduğundan şüphe duymuyorum çünkü en sevdiğim yayıncı tarafından önerildi.
Türkçe kaynağı olmayan bir oyun , ama üzülmeyin youtube/vechiron (namıdiğer heumrage) her akşam yayın yapıyor ve yayınları da çok kaliteli. Kendisi "Türkiye Adom Başkanı" amacı ise bu oyunun verdiği tüm harika şeyleri size de tattırmak. Eğer oyun hakkında hiçbir şey bilmiyorsanız Youtube/vechiron yayınlarını izleyebilir ya da discord sunucusuna gelip yetkililerden Adom-Team rolü alıp her türlü yardımı alabilirsiniz , ses odalarında sürekli Adom yayını yapıyorlar. Dediğim gibi hayatınızda ödediğiniz en iyi 30 lira olacak.
Discord: discord.gg/vechiron
Youtube: vechiron

author: {'steamid': '76561198056327431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 10454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10454, 'last_played': 1618795956}
review: I was never a fan of Rougelikes, but this version has the option to turn off the things I hate about Rougelikes. For example, you can turn off instadeath and corruption. Even doing that, I still had to use Save Scumming to make this game function like a normal modern game that has save points.  Also, I had to use online guides to figure out exactly what to do to move the story forward. The game doesn't get fun until your character reaches a high level and you have accumulated enough gold, spells, food and other resources to be able to play the game without constantly having to run away to heal. So, the game only gets fun and addictive once you have a solid character with good resources that will open up multiple ways to complete various tasks. I enjoyed the modern graphic tile interface over the classic text interface. But, there are still some bugs and keyboard commands always work correctly, while using the clickable icons might not always work correctly. Bottom line is that this game is a must have for people who are interested in playing through ADOM without having to spend 25 years attempting to do it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041954665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1618768194}
review:
Complety overrated and unnessary complicated. The developer states he is unable to beat his own game without cheating, that alone should say enough. 

Aside from a quick tutorial, I did only one run. It lasted about 6 hours and was a pain in the... you know, just no fun at all. If I play I roguelikes I expect to die rather quickly in my first attempts, but still had some fun, learned something unlocked some stuff and are highly motivated to try again. That I game deinstalled right away and there's nothing to unlock anyway. 

Most of the time I was repeating complicated key-combinations over and over again, just to cast a single spell and another one to heal - I mean how hard is it to implement a simple skillbar where you put your most used actions? Even learning spells is complicated, it requires complicated key combinations and/or click sequences, that your character reads the spell book multiple times with a chance of random effects until the book finally disappears. And while you train a spell by using it, you will "forget" it at the same time so at some point you have to read a spell book for it again. Totally logical! I also wouldn't be much surprised if you can break your legs if you reading skill is a little too low when trying to read a spell book. 

A good chunk of the time I was looking things up in the wiki to understand what the game was trying to tell me with hints like "you are doomed!" or "you feel you will die soon". Turned out that I took the wrong way and instead of the early game quest location ended up ina  "special cave" where the enymies get stronger as you level up. That atcually was not even a problem at first. I got a powerful spell right from start and could easily wipe out the whole room of monsters that had openend up. And the next one. And the next one too. That got me instantly several levelups for basically doing nothing and that a non-caster class could have mostly likely not achieved.  I had a simple way back and choose to carefully move on - until I learned that the mobs in the dungeons respawn. Infinitly. Yes, totally interessing and logical! I barely made it out due to that fact but got like 5 or 6 levels. That took like 15 minutes of actual gameplay.  For comparison: In a video I saw before on YT, there was a guy saying he beat the game several times and in fact seemed to have quite some knowledge about it. He started a simple fighter, ran directly into a trap that destroyed his weapon and the next whole hour he could do bascially nothing other than running away and failing a starter quest.

For the rest of the time I played, I was in another dungeon, that took very long due to the tedious  controls and the game giving no useful information. I mean fine, there is a statue - what do you do with it? And why are there statues that move? And what does this "+aP" value on the weapon mean? Naturally you also have all the usual "fun stuff" from the early rogue likes in the game with a items beeing unidentified, half of them cursed, scrolls with random names and urging you to eat stuff that makes you sick. So I got sick, does the game tell you how long that will last? Nope, Sir. So I waited like hundereds of turns because sickness had some serious effects and there was nothing I could do against it. Then poison - the same game. When I reached the boss I learned that he is bascially immune to all magic and casting darkness that makes him hard to hit physically too. On top he got a lot hitpoints and was like full healing himself every few turns. Very frustrating. Not that I actually wanted to rely on spells or melee anyway. I choose to be a Necromancer. But could a raise single minion in 6 hours? Nope! In the wiki I learned you can either make minions from clay - which I didn't have, didn't find and couldn't buy - or from corpses - which I actually expected. But the latter only works of you have a chaotic  alignment and I had a neutral alignment with chaotic tendencies - big difference! I finally died because I was sick again and clicked on the wrong spell to kill a once again respawned monster in same tedious way. Turned out, walls can reflect electricity. Just great.

Edit: I totally forgot to allow comments, not a fan of 1-sided communication. I wonder what feedback would have been there meanwhile because my little review got more attention than I expected.:)

author: {'steamid': '76561198185316770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 12208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5533, 'last_played': 1635266886}
review:
I loved the text-only classic version of Adom, and now I'm enjoying the 2d graphic version even more.  It's incredibly complex with plenty of races and vocations for player characters.  The newer version has even more varied additions, including npc's created by fans.  Note that the game isn't open-ended.  You keep getting corrupted as time goes by, so eventually you either die, win, or lose by corruption.  Some people think the time limit makes the game more limited, but others think it makes it more exciting.  To soften the shock, there are easier modes in the latest version, even a kind of cheat mode for those who want to explore without mortal danger!

Still to be done :) ... Text to 2d conversion isn't quite complete: sometimes you see a message both in a colored window and in a b/w window behind it.  There are icons for some equipment, but not all, and they don't show up consistently in the inventory--or in the right location.  It seems like it would not be too hard to add a 2d graphic way of equipping things, showing how you look with all your armor, etc.  I wish there were a "personal journal" that doesn't go away when your character dies.  That way, you could base your entire epic on things you have learned yourself.  I used to have a little (paper) notebook where I recorded everything, but I gave up on it, and now just use online fan sites.

Overall: A great game for those interested in rogue-like rpgs with plenty of complexity.  2d version works well on Windows.  Hopefully, more improvements are coming to make the 2d stuff more appealing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179560647', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 771, 'last_played': 1617147221}

author: {'steamid': '76561198859298176', 'num_games_owned': 129, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 54513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53041, 'last_played': 1653110693}
review:
I first found ADOM around 20 years ago browsing for free games to play on my first computer. it was ASCII graphics only, extremely easy on the hard drive and highly rated so i gave it a shot and i am glad i did. I've still never completed a run, came close a few different times but never succeeded. its changed over the years to have nice graphical interface that helps with some of the more annoying aspects (visible herb patches make not picking a patch bare easier) and had some content added in. every time i play i learn something new, which is the main appeal of classic roguelikes; failure is necessary and key to finally winning. this game has brought me countless hours of fun although sometimes frustrating over the years. 

Note: the 800 hrs on record is not accurate for this account; i left it open one morning after work and my laptop went unused for a week or two with it open. i have probably played that over the course of my time with this game, its the only one i have had installed on every desktop or laptop i have owned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012395761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2941, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1748, 'last_played': 1615942118}
review:
I have played other rogue-likes (e.g., NetHack, UMoria, Angband) for hundreds of hours. After 20+ years, I am still not fed up with any of them. I remember trying out ADOM as well, but could not recall why I dropped it. It came back to me quickly when I started playing this shiny new version.

Good things: very nice tiles. UI and keybindings took some getting used to but worked quite well. Some nice quality of life features (especially the automatic exploration is swell.)

Bad things: ADOM takes the worst parts of old rogue-likes and combines them with fundamentally flawed, completely rogue-like-incompatible ideas. It is chock-full of poorly balanced and just plain stupid things (like disproportionate leveling of some monsters AKA the überjackal effect, artifacts that are indistinguishable from common items.) It has too many things that can ruin your game without you being able to do anything about it. It has too many things that are impossible to figure out on your own. It has too many grief mechanisms (like irreversible stat drain, casters forgetting spells, frequent item destruction, unstoppable disarming, ailments that are incurable for low level characters.) Its quests are not procedurally generated; they get really old really quick in a game one is supposed to play hundreds of times. It has too many extremely arduous things that MUST be done in every single game (if you live long enough.)

For a perma-death game with a very high RNG-fueled difficulty, ADOM is simply way too long, convoluted and tedious. It would require endless time and patience, and at least I lack both.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081168629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 1070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 359, 'last_played': 1620874242}
review: I have some experience with rogue-likes so I decided to learn on the fly on hard-mode(normal rogue-like mode) to start off. I am of course reading the parts I need at the times I need to. I have been having a blast so far. I have yet to get past my second dungeon because I always run into something(or somethings) powerful and malevolent that just wrecks me. I have been using the "fate" option on all my characters for all the choices, which essentially just completely randomized your character. I want to get a feel for as many builds as I can before I start making my own. The game is great. All the different builds are great in the way that they can change how you play and the skills you use. There are a lot of classes and I have not been through them all yet, but so far my favorite classes are the ranger and the mindbender?(something along those lines). It is a very difficult game but would probably be easier if you read the manual. If you have no experience with rogue-likes at all then I HIGHLY suggest reading the manual, as the game is not very beginner friendly. the game literally makes me feel like I am playing a single-player dungeons and dragons. I could see myself playing this one for a lifetime with it's potential replay-ability. You can turn of permanent deaths I believe but that really takes a lot out of the game. There is something fun and satisfying about dying and learning from your mistakes, and then getting that character that you finally get a little farther with then last time. Then you die again. Anyways, this game is completely worth the money and will suck you in once you learn the ins-and-outs. It will have you saying, "just one more death!"

author: {'steamid': '76561197972314262', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 3267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 13, 'playtime_at_review': 2884, 'last_played': 1711908306}
review:
As much as I love the grand design of this game, including the classes, dungeons, races, monsters and artifacts, the minute to minute gameplay trends towards miserable.

The creator has a rather singular vision he's not willing to compromise or "sacrifice" for quality of life.  Melee combat tends to be extremely swingy, which can be a problem when you're going to be mowing through thousands of monsters a playthrough.

Being forced to play intelligently is not the issue, fighting in corridors, minimizing being surrounded or making yourself unavailable to be target with bolt/line spells.  This sort of tactic is expected in any similar roguelike, it's more the fact that out of depth monster generation, monster special attacks, armor piercing (PV ignoring) attacks and the "UberJackal" problem exist.

A lot of the dungeons are thematically quite cool, but force you to have trap detection (Miserable, but not impossible for any character to get), and everything seems to be both a simultaneous battle of attrition AND a burst/crit fest.

It's certainly worth trying the free version (Which really loses nothing over this paid version) to see how Roguelikes have changed over the years, but honestly this game is too miserable to put any real effort into.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964229326', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1634514832}
review:
Oh, wow. I remember playing the free ASCII version of this game years ago, and finally picked up this version on Steam. It's just such a great game!

There are so many options to choose from when creating a character, and so many monsters and items to discover and learn how they interact. For instance, the fire bolt and frost bolt spells might seem pretty much identical, but fire bolts can burn items on the ground so you can't use them, while frost bolts can freeze water so you can cross over without swimming. Therefore the frost bolt spell costs more mana.

It can be a bit repetitive if you tend to die early on and you have to repeat the same quests over and over again, though. And the difficulty curve can be rather bizarre - you might plow through dozens of enemies with no trouble at all, then run into a boss that kills you in a few hits if you're not careful! It's probably best to be careful whenever you run into a new monster, especially one with a star by its health bar indicating it's unique!

Oh, I do need to mention the art in this game. The pixel art is very nice (though I do wish all of your character's equipment affected your avatar; hats in particular don't seem to, even though NPCs can be found wearing hats). Everything is easily recognizable and just looks good. And the music is very atmospheric; the levelup theme even changes depending on your alignment, it seems!

So yeah. Great game. A classic updated for the 21st century. Play it. 😁

author: {'steamid': '76561198073628017', 'num_games_owned': 65, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1643412750}
review:
This magical RPG game is immersive, but most importantly, challenging. For those who do not like the challenge, there are options to make the game easier, without taking away the aspects of the very atmosphere that ADOM gives to the player.
This game simply takes the very formula that the grand majority of RPG's where based upon and gives you a world, in which you, as the player, can create and mold your character to your heart's content. I can very much tell that the developers of this game poured all their hearts and souls into ADOM. The music matches all the atmospheres that the player could be in.
If given the chance, by playing it and sticking with it, this game will eventually draw you in and place you right into the shoes of the very character that you define and create. This is how an RPG should be. Hats off to the developers! I'll be watching, and purchasing, any further update and upgrades that you make to ADOM.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038071481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1028, 'last_played': 1558199136}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043861192', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 11908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6329, 'last_played': 1613185312}
review:
This game is a relic from an era in gaming that is long gone. An era in which terms like unlocks, meta progression, participation trophy, balance and hand-holding didn’t exist. Games were hard, oftentimes intentionally cryptic and held no punches. ADOM stands out as a hard and complex among those games. However, take into account that If you can put up with how ruthless and complex ADOM can be, you have here a game like no other. A game that is huge in every aspect: it has an incredible amount of places to visit, characters to create, creatures to kill, quests to do and ways to die.  It can at times be frustrating and/or irritating but at the same time it’s incredibly rewarding. Each cleaned dungeon or completed quest feels great, hell sometimes even leveling up is gratifying. This was the first rogue-like I played back in 2005 and since then I’ve played it countless times.  So, if you are up for a challenge, look no more: ADOM has what you need. 

P.s: if you aren’t one already, this game will make you a dog person.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061178400', 'num_games_owned': 123, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 24256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11249, 'last_played': 1638440822}
review:
Best roguelike and one of the best, most complex and most polished-up games ever. I play ADOM since 1997 (0.9.9 Gamma 4) and I love the additions of the latest builds and additional features of the Deluxe (Steam) edition.
Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044767135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 48560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25355, 'last_played': 1705280936}
review: An old classic, tough-as-nails, rouglike with high amounts of RNG, a deep knowledge needed to win, but addictive to play and enjoy. These attributes can act as barriers, certainly, but are also part of the charm. If you like NetHack type games with deep lore, this will hit the sweet spot, though more modern games are likely a better use of your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029120271', 'num_games_owned': 112, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2585, 'last_played': 1694014213}
review:
I've been playing this game since the 90's. I've never beat it. lol The replay value of this game is insane. This game is a relic from the past that didn't used to hold your hand but now the Creator has made it much more accessible to the new generation. Welcome to the brutal world of rogue-likes. This game helped push the genre forward just as much as nethack or the original rogue.

I definitely recommend this game if you are a new or returning rogue-like player.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019010022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 1529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1525, 'last_played': 1692134427}
review:
Well well well, as much as I like the game mechanics and the getting more and more powerful with each run, the very few NPC interactions and the level 17 Pyramid artificial 'get the artifact now or break the game' condition nailed the coffin for me.

I invested something like 20 hours in Roguelike mode in a character that had no problem surviving only to fail the whole game because an artefact must be obtained before being level 18 (no directions are given ingame about that)...

I understand some people will sink 400 hours in this game or even read obscure wiki walkthroughs to get the max out of the game but hey, I have things to do in real life...

I'll then go back to Caves of Qud or KeeperRL hoping that the latter mentioned don't have similar unfair (my opinion) intricacies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044273950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 46513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28371, 'last_played': 1670672065}
review:
И вот в очередной раз я сдох. Лет 15 уже играю и подобрался пока только процентов на 80 к _простому_ финалу игры. Не то чтобы игра была прям _настолько_ уж сложной, но она требует внимательности и сдержанности, которых у меня не хватает.
Но и без этого игра крайне интересна и очень разнообразна. Поначалу убить игрока может каждый чих, но когда осваиваешь основные механики, то проигрыши становятся в основном результатом рисков, которые игрок на себя берёт для того чтобы было "побольше драйва". Становится интересно создать персонажа послабее и провести его через опасности начального выживания... Тем более что обычно именно такие персонажи становятся сверхсильными к концу игры, а изначально сильные орки или тролли - наоборот страдают к концу игры от старости или неутолимого голода.
Игра хорошо сбалансирована, но главный кайф, конечно, от огромного, ОГРОМНОГО разнообразия комбинаций всего со всем, продуманных автором. Которых игроку только предстоит изучить.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211766859', 'num_games_owned': 444, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 12687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1708123550}
review:
My favorite game of all-time...easily.

Not for everyone, and despite all the in-game tips it's still a steep learning curve, but well worth it. I've easily put in a thousand hours into ADOM over the years, back since it was purely ASCII, and always find myself coming back to it.

Until you learn what you're doing, I'd recommend a troll with the candle birthsign...

author: {'steamid': '76561197978245668', 'num_games_owned': 398, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2587, 'last_played': 1608849770}
review:
Streamlines and scratches the Nethack itch just right and has a very nice tileset, if you had all the time in the world you could dump thousands of hours into it and still be entertained (however there's thankfully a wiki to abuse and spoil for those of us with less time/attention to give it with full time jobs and, well, lives).

What it could use: induce vomiting (don't ask), polymorphing, more interesting npcs/npc interactions, a few areas accessibility, less doom oh god there's so much dooming and it's so hard to get rid of.

^ when fine details like that are all you can think of to make a game of this scope better, it's a damn legend of a game. And, to be fair this is the sort of game where you need TONS of hours in for a legit thorough review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114284741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 7498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4994, 'last_played': 1709999225}
review: One of the four pillars of traditional roguelikes, ADOM is a game with incredible depth. author: {'steamid': '76561198142365868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1678746655}
review:
I played this game back when it was an ASCII game on my oldest computer. It was fun, addictive, and always throwing me off with each randomly generated dungeon and monsters.  One time I found a pool where I got a free wish, only to mess it up royally and lose my only chance of getting some good loot. This latest version is superior to the old version due to the graphics and frequent updates. 

I also like that there is an 'easy' mode for new players to practice getting to grips to the mechanics of this game. The old version of ADOM was brutal in difficulty, especially in the Small Cave and the Caverns of Chaos. If you want a real "old school" roguelike, with a massive amount of experiences, monsters that gain experience and level up just like you, some Easter eggs in the form of anagrams and slightly obscure references, then get this game. 

If you find too many attributes, game factors, and crushing difficulty to be a turn off, or you like your RPGs more action oriented and varied, then you had better look elsewhere for a game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037814352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 10568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9490, 'last_played': 1655312551}
review:
Лучший из рогаликов, нигде не было такой подачи сюжета, проработанной вселенной, глубоких механик.

Как и положено из прохождение в прохождение качается именно сам игрок. Если помираете часто - проблема только в спешке, все крайне логично и ожидаемо, остается только думать прежде чем действовать.

Графический и музыкальный уровень выше всех похвал, после Адома играть в другие рогалики тяжко, слишком уж высокую планку он задает.

Это просто божественно, непередаваемые ощущение от продвижения каждый раз дальше. Рекомендую всем, теперь это эталон жанра

author: {'steamid': '76561198030632623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 56419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34167, 'last_played': 1686085731}
review:
Pretty much *the* definitive old-school roguelike. The game began development in 1994, and it shows in the design - for good and for ill. If you enjoy a challenging game based around dungeon crawling, ADOM is a classic of the genre. Just keep in mind that you'll probably die a lot, and a playthrough is considerably longer than with newer roguelikes and rogue-lites.

The rebooted game (the Steam version) is much more accessible than the 90s incarnation of the game, but the game still demands a lot and doesn't explain the intricacies of its systems. But once you get past the tough stuff, it also offers many ways to use the acquired knowledge, and that can be immensely satisfying.

If you don't mind minimal graphics and the fact that you'll be spending a lot of time on wikis and in-game trial and error, and/or if you grew up on older PC cRPGs, ADOM will probably appeal to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198870320478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1224, 'last_played': 1604159708}

review: Guys hello does anybody know what may be the problem, when I run the game the screen is blurry and I barely see what is on the screen, when I first start a game it was okey, but sometimes it lagged and I couldnt read words, and when I changed to ascii mode it became impossible to read anything even from the first screen when you open the game....

author: {'steamid': '76561198053686458', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1601254465}
review:
I played this game for hundreds of hours as a kid, got all of my friends hooked. I love seeing that ADOM has evolved and grown.
This game is a challenge. It can be cruel and unfair, but where is the fun in predictability? Some things you'll learn to do carefully, like kicking doors down. Sounds cool until those runes explode in your face to shred all your best gear and leave you a singed, vulnerable mess surrounded by a hoard of angry rats. Other things, you might want to look up and research a little; there are story threads and choices you can make early in the game that can affect the ending you go for and what content you can access.
Good luck, be nice to kitties, and don't smack the rainbow.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970397001', 'num_games_owned': 1682, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 16452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9559, 'last_played': 1705422507}

author: {'steamid': '76561198052334607', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 978, 'last_played': 1626384820}
review:
"I am a female high elf I have blue eyes and light complexion and I am a healer. And... I just died. I am a male dwarf, I have brown eyes and tanned complexion and I am a smith. ...and I'm dead." 
"Wow, what is it that you are playing?" I asked my future wife. 
"Adom" she replied.
Few years forward and I beat ADOM. I was a male human, my only corruption was random teleportion (controlled) and I won the game and become the king. I was cheating with saves of course.
Several years passed and I kept using number of quotes from ADOM in my life. One day I said something about writhing mass of primal chaos and looked it up in curiosity. And I actually found a picture of it. That's how I found out that ADOM has actual graphic now. I always wondered what would ADOM looked with graphic and I also wanted to finally support the developer. I bought the game without hesitation. 
ADOM is very hard game. Almost impossible to finish unless you backup your saves. But for me it is and always will be an epic.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993468494', 'num_games_owned': 340, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 20934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3259, 'last_played': 1683318651}

author: {'steamid': '76561198060659972', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 9298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1172, 'last_played': 1694548797}
review:
If you have played this venerable game, you know how good it is. Now it has (somewhat) updated graphics, too, and the character sprites are rather cute, I think.

If you haven't played a true roguelike, this is a fun entry point. Try it out! Please note: You will die. A LOT.

Do me a favor: Try a Gnome Monk under the sign of the candle. Set your final values at Strength:15,  Learning:15, Charisma:1, and Mana:20. This should leave you with 1 build point left over. Leave it alone. With this setup, you will have a whopping FIVE starting perks! I always choose the entire "skilled" line, to maximize my skill points, and then start with Aware and Brawler (as a slightly survivable setup for Treasure Hunter on my second trait upgrade.) This setup will by no means ensure your survival, but I find it fun to play, regardless.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998954904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 915, 'last_played': 1597437452}
review: I love the genre of rogue-like, especially the old-school variety.  The reason I cannot recommend this one is that there are so many others out there that are better.  The genre is intended to be challenging.  Yes.  I like that.  I've played and enjoyed Dungeons of Dredmore, Tales of Maj'eyal, Rogue Empire, Dungeonmans, and others.  If you've played all of those and you just need something new (like I did), toss them some money.  There's plenty of frustration to be had.  The mechanics are too opaque for me, and the deck is stacked against the player a little too much.  I'll give you the example that made me uninstall the game and go back to TOME.  I had a caster going, and was doing decently well.  I opened a door to a dungeon and it was a "monster zoo" kind of place.  Sure, I've done this before.  I cast my trusty frost bolt and took a bunch of the creatures out.  I cast it again, and took a few more.  Went to cast it a third time, and it was no longer in my spell list.  I had no idea why.  Apparently, though it tells you nowhere in the game, every time you use a spell, you have an increasing chance to forget it at random.  I had six spells at that point, but only one was offensive, and the creatures were too fast for me to run away from, so end of character.  There are so many different ways that the deck is stacked against you that getting the right combination of things is such a factor of luck that even were I to complete the game, I would feel like it was an achievement of randomness rather than skill or intelligence.   Once I start seeing a game that way, it ceases to be satisfying to me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086228291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 22836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19478, 'last_played': 1685314248}

author: {'steamid': '76561198123051944', 'num_games_owned': 358, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 869, 'last_played': 1694347066}
review: Я могу надолго разлиться в тирадах, но просто упомяну, что это очень хорошая игра, достойная внимания всякого ценителя игр. Она отнюдь не так дружелюбна, как современные проекты, потому новичку в жанре лучше сначала приобщиться к ТоМЕ или другим более простым в освоении рогаликам. Впрочем, начать с АДОМа также можно, если есть на то ваша воля, ошибки в том я не вижу.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972268242', 'num_games_owned': 425, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 6763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1709445782}
review:
I used to play this game in the 90's when it was on his website for free.  It is WELL WORTH the $15.  The sheer amount of things you are able to do, if you delve into the game, is crazy.   You can go to town and do the missions, sure, but you can also settle down in a nice plot in the grasslands and plant crops.  Or set up as a merchant.  

You are going to die.  A LOT.  But that's how you learn how to get better.  Slowly but surely, you'll learn more and more until you're dozens of levels down in the Chaos Caves, getting extra eyeballs or the ability to teleport.  Be an agent for Order, or Chaos, or...don't.  And, you can sacrifice your enemies on altars to the Gods.  11/10 will recommend forever!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041766090', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5909, 'last_played': 1598334248}
review:
It's one of the best turn based rogue-like rpg dungeon crawlers I've played.  Very in depth, very technical, but there is a LOT to learn.  I suggest that possibly at first you put it on non-roguelike through customization at the start, and then you can utilize saves, then after you get the hang of it switch over to rogue-like.  

This isn't a game for those who get frustrated easily, dislike difficult games, or do not like to figure out mechanics who's instructions are obscure to non-existent.  

Four final notes:
1. The one possibly biggest suggestion I can make is if you can manage to exist long enough in the overworld map, it will give you a hint via a vague direction on which cave/dungeon to enter next.  It's highly recommended you follow this, you can go almost anywhere, and some of the dungeons are almost instantly deadly.  

2. When you are in doubt on your levels, power, or gear, dive the infinite dungeon, it scales evenly, and does not typically jump up in difficulty quickly.  The lower you go, the better gear, gold, and xp you get, and as long as you aren't too greedy, you can come out a winner.  Just remember going between floors ALWAYS randomly generates them, which can be a boon, and a bane.  

3.  Keep smithing stuff around, don't throw it out, this includes when you find an anvil.  It can help you enhance equipment even a little earlier in the game if you are lucky, but especially mid/late game.  Additionally, you can store this stuff, and any spare gear in the outlaw town near the beginning of the game in the thieves guild building.  I do it right where the master thief is, no one takes your stuff, and it should be there forever.  Nonetheless, I close the doors so randos don't wander in.  

Good Luck!

author: {'steamid': '76561198274269751', 'num_games_owned': 815, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 10720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9995, 'last_played': 1693839359}
review: 硬核是真的硬核，没心理准备的不建议尝试。经典Roguelike里算画面最好的了，当然画面不重要。期待Ultimate ADOM。

author: {'steamid': '76561197976259471', 'num_games_owned': 2541, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1598044288}
review:
After playing CDDA and Caves of Qud, I was immediately, strongly put off by the strange maps. They're very rectangular (long and thin) and extremely small, even for a traditional roguelike (imo). I'm not going to refund it, I think its been over two weeks anyway, but I don't know if I see myself dropping tons of time into it. 

I would much rather pay the same price for Caves of Qud (amazing, like Dune or Planet of the Apes as a roguelike, tons of deep mechanics, detail, and excellent writing for both lore and story), or play Cataclysm Dark Days Ahead for free (amazing zombie survival game, tons of deep mechanics and open-source), or even get Cogmind (pretty good part-based robo roguelike, more traditional though but some awesome tiles, effects, and weapon ASCII art).

I think this one is good if you want a VERY old school roguelike, or if you are nostalgic and played it along with Rogue or Nethack. But the ones mentioned above are better, more modern and open-world takes on the genre that are much more enjoyable. Who wouldn't want to make an RV into a Battle Bus like from one of those newer Dawn of the Dead movies?

author: {'steamid': '76561198060470451', 'num_games_owned': 202, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1595708143}
review:
OK. This is bad. Why have I wasted time on this?

This is more of an opinion then constructive feedback. I am not an expert in rogueliks but I played few. I dont mind graphics but I want fun. Plus I refuse to spend 100s hours on wiki to find out how to do things - game should show me game should teach me.

I got two characters to level 10, melee only. Most boring gameplay I ever had. No special attacks no special skills. Boring weapons. All you do is bump and T for shooting.

Finished a quest for the Elder in a first town - didn't get any reward...

Went to look for a puppy, bumped through 5 levels, found a river across the dungeon. Cool! I just found a book about bridge building lets try to build a bridge! No, game is not telling you how to build a bridge. This game is not telling you a thing. Lets check skills description from manual, I think I have seen something about bridges: 

Bridge Building
*************
This skill allows you to build bridges.

:D:D

I am sure the dev is proud on how old school this game is and how it is not holding your hand - but to me it is just boring and not fun. OK. I checked my inventory. I am overburden, got 15 things I dont even know what you can try with those since this game is not telling you anything.

OK. I am bored with bumping and swinging my generic axe. I got some unidentified scrolls - I am not going to play it anyway so lets read those. Read 3.... guess what? Nothing happen. Nice. You didn't disappoint me game.

Lets try potions:

potions of water - text in a log "potion of water tastes like a normal water" or something like that
potions of water take 2 = text in a log "this tastes muddy" or something like that..

Another A+ game...

One of other potions made me blind. I waited. Bump the wall for many turns wondered around and I am still blind... Am I going to be blind forever? How can I tell? The game is not telling me anything :)

There are tons of other better designed game. Games where the new player experience is over the roof. Take DCSS for example. OK I get it, it is slightly different you just go down and you fight but DCSS is a blast in explaining game mechanics and how things work to new player. You die, you learn so much that you want to just go back straight away. But this more "ambitious" project is boring as fuck. I don't want to be rude I can imagine that a lot of time went into it but something somewhere got forgotten. I don't even want a refund...

author: {'steamid': '76561198003202062', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5288, 'last_played': 1600020769}
review:
ADOM is an extremely deep turn-based dungeon crawler that is very punishing and rewards system mastery. If you always wanted to play old-style D&D where death is cheap and magic items feel precious, but never wanted to force your friends through the experience, ADOM is for you.

A caveat: the controls and menuing system are those of a game made before windows 95 was released, and are thus somewhat unintuitive for modern players and will require reading and re-reading the keybindings section of the manual to adjust to; also, a num pad is almost a must.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011443153', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1939, 'last_played': 1596486680}

review: This is a very solid rouge-like. Its complexity is ultimately rewarding. review:
344 hours (at time of writing) and I've never completed it. If I'm honest with myself, I've never even come close. And that's what I love about ADOM. It's so hard and I'm so determined to do it.

I should add, too, that I've been playing ADOM for about 15 years, long before it came to Steam, and I never completed it back then either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052244331', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2193, 'last_played': 1594397552}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972645811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2963, 'last_played': 1600639110}
review:
I'm still slightly in shock that ADOM is here. I used to play this back in the 90s on my Amiga, and here I discovered Thomas has continued to develop it for all this time!
There are a lot of "Rogue-like" games these days, but here's (In my opinion) a PROPER one. I've really enjoyed replaying this and seeing a mix of things I remember, things I half-remember, and most of all, so many scenes that I remember but now brought to life with the new art style (I'm playing with the tiles and not the ASCII :) )
Really pleased I picked this up. :)

review: Very fun game in general, but the beginning is pretty repetitive and piety sacrifices can add to that repetition. Amount of piety you get for sacrifices should be increased but the amount of times you can use one altar should be decreased (make the player have to go out and explore to find more altars.) Also maybe just get rid of live sacrifices, or narrow the beings that please your god instead of just any monsters of other alignments.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980951413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 8307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1945, 'last_played': 1641244655}
review:
The good: it is a classic rogue-like game, 26 years old now. It's can be very addictive at times, which is the mark of a good core game play loop. It's a very deep game. There is a lot to learn and it's hard to master.

The bad: There is such a thing as too much randomness. The game makes a point of leaving quite a bit up to chance, with tables galore and so very many random dungeon features and items to keep you busy. But this randomness makes the game feel downright arbitrary at times. An early random ring of invisibility can make the rest of a run feel too easy. Likewise a random statue or pool effect might essentially kill a character, even an advanced one. There's just so much randomness that there's a whole wiki dedicated to cataloging the RNG and finding exploits which the creator has intentionally left in the game. And so when you finally master this game by memorizing the exploits, the game begins to feel more like a spreadsheet that you know really well rather than a core game play loop that you like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044861358', 'num_games_owned': 132, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 24588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24115, 'last_played': 1645342370}

author: {'steamid': '76561198086803461', 'num_games_owned': 590, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 13824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2434, 'last_played': 1681121783}

author: {'steamid': '76561197997190694', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 8534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6091, 'last_played': 1612994643}
review: While the game is difficult to learn without reading through the built-in manual, it's been my favorite game for over a decade.  It manages to capture some of the best aspects of major fantasy games, in a way that's extremely fun to play.  The game is challenging, fun to play, and full of new experiences, with immense replay value.  Even if you've played one character for a week solid, and it doesn't seem quite good enough, I fully encourage trying a different race/class combination, because it will put a completely new spin on how the game feels as you play.  Few games have I fraught so much over the potential death of one of my characters as I have with A.D.O.M.  I suggest reading at least enough of the manual to know how to refer back to it while you're in the game;  also, take time to learn the controls, and the specifics of at least one race/class combination, and keep an eye out for the Postcard Quest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198306178967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2395, 'last_played': 1646749876}

author: {'steamid': '76561198151700770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 24734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24602, 'last_played': 1616832475}
review: ADOM has wasted more of my time than I care to admit, one of the greatest games I've ever played, up there with PlaneScape Torment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037787954', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 35553, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35553, 'last_played': 1591256668}
review:
Зачем вообще в это играют? Она довольно залипательная, можно с натяжкой сравнить с диабло, но враги и предметы способны сильно поменять тактику боя. Вообщем герой умирает за один ход, если действовать неосмотрительно. Окаменение и крик баньши убьют любого, не смотря на прокачку, а паралич отправляет на кладбище каждого второго персонажа. 

Играть в это без гайдов - особое удовольствие, но я бы не советовал. Однако у неё закрытый код, что является противоположностью NetHack (похожий рогалик вызвавший мой интерес историями про труп василиска).

Графическая версия на мой взгляд не удалась, стиль и ограниченный обзор вынудили остаться на ASCII версии, представлять иллюстрации к "Властелину колец" намного приятнее.

~

Прошёл на ультру, варваром, ну и душнина это была, с 20 по 45 уровень просто нечем заняться, тролль неохотно набирает экспу, конечно есть эффективные способы получения опыта, но их еще нужно уметь применять и да, возня в менюшках и их вызов - просто звездец, в графической версии может получше, но я уже говорил.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029092897', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2401, 'last_played': 1710801904}
review: Played this 25 years ago and saw it on steam a week ago - I am a seasoned GW and GW2 player and I get the same buzz with ADOM - VERY VERY addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121758068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4998, 'last_played': 1654463800}
review:
The game brings a lot of memories. A lot of screaming as your PC meets untimely end ( usually caused by your stupidity, hubris or just bad luck ). Some deaths are more amusing than others..

I played a lot of the free version and I believe the author should be rewarded. The game can be frustrating and learning curve is demanding, but a win feels like a true win. When you take out shadow wyrm, you feel a sense of accomplishment. The alignment is more than simply creating weak good/bad choice system. The characters will may not talk to you if you are chaotic, but they may present you with an artifact if you happen to be lawful.

The classes are interesting ( some unique to ADOM ); Gods listen and will be annoyed if you pester them too much. If you wish for a million wishes.. point is, there are tons of those little things that make this world seem more real than many other games of its time ( and frankly, of today ). Which is pretty impressive given that the game is all about magic, fantastic creatures, quests and saving the world..

I never beat it. I still have a save somewhere of a dwarven priest ready to storm the final level, but I just do not want to risk it. Maybe one day..

Try the free version and see if you like it. There is a reason it is a classic.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982132582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1004, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 689, 'last_played': 1590594888}

review:
This game is among the 3 best modern-day rogue-likes in my list.

Adom
Tome 
Dungeon Crawl (stone soup)

Adom is definately the hardest one of them all. Lots of replayability. Been playing this one since about year 2000 and I keep returnign to this game every few months - lose 5-10 tmes and forget about the game for another few months. Immediately bought ADOM once i saw it being released on steam.
No other game is luring me back these days.

P.S You are going to die a lot in this game.
