author: {'steamid': '76561198005197198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1523236930}
review:
ADOM; A game where you can rescue a little girls dog from a deadly cave.....or eat its corpse in front of her(And then give candy to negate the Karma loss!).
In ADOM you can choose to crush the true evil, seal it away or even become it with various ways of achieving any of these(With their own endings)

With an alignment system that means you can be gifted artifacts from a god or be smote where you stand(unless you can work out how to avoid it ;) ) ADOM allows you to do, within the games mechanics, anything you wish; from using a corpse as a throwing weapon all the way up to surviving an angered gods rage as a pacifist.

Equipment is plentiful for all slots with many base types, prefix's, suffix's, bless/curse and extraneous things such as rust. Not only do you have an inventory and equip slots so to do the monsters with some being smart enough to decide to drop their broken heavy spear in favour of a blessed two-handed sword of sharpness.

The only downside, for some people, is the graphics; With the choice between ASCII(text) or Sprite-based those that are looking for "pretty" wont find it here.

Don't trust reviews? Good, check out the latest free version on the Devs very own website (Warning: It's obviously a bit out of date)

author: {'steamid': '76561198038214105', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 29132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4068, 'last_played': 1633095813}
review:
So there are roguelikes, and then there are roguelikes. ADOM is a pretty venerable one, not quite as old or well-known as games like nethack but it's an important one. Why? Well, one thing people attribute to roguelikes pretty often is that they are hard and obtuse. To a certain degree this is true, but not always. Playing a valkerie and knowing how to write Elbereth makes nethack pretty easy, or you can play something like Dredmor or a Mystery Dungeon game to have an easier time. 

But ADOM takes being weird and hard to higher levels. Cats are a constant menace. Funny lizards make you think that wasn't a good idea. Why does this level have so many corpses in it and why does my mouth have tentacles in it? ADOM probably won't give you the answers to these questions without making you work for it. 

And yet we find ADOM here on Steam, with shiny new features that make playing an old fashioned roguelike a little more palatable for people who weren't doing it in the 90s. The updated tileset is excellent, letting characters have personality and making the screen much more clear than the old ASCII symbols while retaining the ability to switch back when you want to see the whole level at once. Perhaps the biggest change is the ability to save and reload (at the cost of reducing your final score, of course). This makes the many, many fatal mistakes that one can encounter in the Draklor Chain a little less punishing. It might not help you from starving right off, but it could keep you from losing right at the start in the Puppy Cave. Then there are the weekly challenges, to add spice to players who are constantly looking for new ways to play. 

All things considered, ADOM is a classic roguelike and the Steam release has a lot to recommend it. If you are a fan of newer roguelikes like Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup or Dungeons of Dredmor and want to dip into older titles, this is the place to be. Plus you can use it as an excuse to send postcards to strangers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005018153', 'num_games_owned': 2577, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 689, 'last_played': 1619084841}
review: Through ADOM I've found a window to the world of roguelikes many years ago and learn to cherish the simple graphics, I'm still rooting for those classics and I'm glad ADOM landed on steam and is still worked upon. Looking forward for more :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198089189498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 4280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3709, 'last_played': 1480253784}
review:
Плюсов у игры много однако через какое то время игры обращаешь внимание только на раздражающие моменты:
1. Игра очень скрытная - большинство жизненно (смертельно) важной информации и нюансов можно узнать только в вики, играя в саму игру вы никогда о них не узнаете.
2. Постоянно спавнящиеся монстры - стоит на пару шагов отойти, опять куча монстров, то есть зайдя в данжон и спустившись на 10 уровней, придётся возвращаться по 10-и уровням вновь набитыми монстрами - утомляет... зачастую смертельно для персонажа.
3. Сюжет крайне далеко запрятан, наиграв больше 50 часов, я даже не могу вспомнить, а был ли он вообще. Не критично, но всё же.
4. К интерфейсу надо действительно долго привыкать - почти всё управление как в редакторе vim

Рекомендовать можно для ознакомления только тем кто многократного прошёл Tales of Maj'Eyal за все расы и классы и ищет чего то подобного но нового.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071501932', 'num_games_owned': 990, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 3195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 29, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1711961005}
review:
I've been playing this game for almost two decades and still dream about one day beating it between my nightmares of angering the graceful white [b]f[/b] or running into bulky yellow ampersands. Many hours were lost playing randomised round-robin ADOM with my friends. When I eventually got the Steam version I was pleasantly surprised to see that significant development has been made since [url=http://www.adom.de/home/downloads.html]the latest free release[/url]. Yes, the game is a double-edged sword. It requires [i]extensive time and research[/i] to get into and the [i]learning curve is steep[/i]. Even so the complexity of the environment, the depth of character development, and the exhiliration of narrowly escaping death and enjoying great rewards is well worth it.

This is a true dungeon crawling RP experience: only play this if you can tolerate no monster memory between characters, running away from encounters often, frequently and often instantaneously dying from nasty traps, as well as working hard to develop your meta skills.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010745565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1477118075}
review: ADOM is freeware. You don't need a crack or serial number to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057518147', 'num_games_owned': 510, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 774, 'last_played': 1522257843}
review:
Adom est un bon jeu.
Absurdement complexe et punitif mais un bon jeu.
Niveau difficulté on est au niveau d'un Dark Soul (rien d'insurmontable donc) avec toutefois une complexité assez importante (mourir parce qu'on ne sait pas qu'il y a une commande pour s'essuyer le visage, c'est sale) mais rien de traumatisant si vous avez déjà passé un hiver dans Dwarf Fortress. Notez que tout les commentaires négatifs porte sur le nombre asurde de commande et sentent la loose et l'impatience à plein nez.
Et quoi que l'on dise les graphisme font la différence en rendant le jeu moins abstrait (même le personnage peu changer en fonction de l'équipement.
Après il faut avouer que le wiki sera votre meilleur ami, même à petite dose.

Sur ce, je retourne fracassé du monstre à coup de point et de pierre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018251251', 'num_games_owned': 892, 'num_reviews': 569, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1476151683}
review:
The game is overly complex. It might be fun to someone who used to play the original, back before computers had graphics but the added interface does nothing to the fluidity of this game.

You need to take a college course to be able to play and enjoy this overly complex game. 

I spent time in the tutorial with a wall of text every step with all the bs it had to throw at you. 

Stopped playing when my sword rusted 2 tiles into some regular water. I play games to enjoy them not calculate and study their mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099029761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 3850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1148, 'last_played': 1611958307}
review:
I must say - this is the BEST roguelike I have ever played (rogue, dcss, tome etc I have played too)

I made my runs long before steam version, became avatar of order and slayed AnCiEnT's. I was rather dissapointed when ADOM became paid game... And I fancy it will become free in some time soon...

author: {'steamid': '76561197988678841', 'num_games_owned': 374, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 14498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6331, 'last_played': 1697406758}
review:
ADOM is an incredibly in-depth and difficult roguelike, well worth the time spent coming to grips with the many intricacies of the controls and game mechanics. - mechanics such as, necromancy, mindcrafting, ventriloquism, appeasing your god, displeasing your god, smithing, crafting, gardening, spending time with lonely monsters, equipment cursing/blessing, an alignment system from chaotic to lawful, affected by the player's actions.

however, this game is not for the faint of heart, and bitter, repeated failure is all but guaranteed. a true classic, there is little hand-holding bar the tutorial which leads to a player experience limited only by your imagination. many epic adventures await, and many tragic insta-deaths. patience and security will lend you a rewarding journey, but be warned - it's not going to be easy.

here are some interesting ways the game will kill you:
-choked to death on your own vomit
-dungeon roof collapses upon you
-turned into a writhing mass of primal chaos
-crushed to death by the weight of your equipment
-old age
-slain by an angry pet
-drowned
-turned to stone by a gorgon's breath
-turned to stone by eating the corpse of a gorgon
-bolted by your god after gravely offending them
-being sacrified to another creature's god
-instantly killed by a death ray
-burned by impure metal as a mist elf
-eaten by a grue
-your worn ring of the master cat explodes because you killed a cat
-your worn platinum girdle slowly squeezing you to death because you sinned
-blown up by an exploding item after you polymorphed it into itself
-granted a wish and wished for death

author: {'steamid': '76561198041686787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1564, 'last_played': 1510779706}

author: {'steamid': '76561198119322234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 458, 'last_played': 1528400318}

author: {'steamid': '76561197973111564', 'num_games_owned': 234, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1784, 'last_played': 1660020272}
review:
ADOM is a long time favorite. I read some of the negative reviews - almost all of them mention the key commands as the sore point of why they didn't like the game. To be sure, there are a lot of commands for ADOM. However, all of those commands give you a great deal of control over the game. They do take some time to learn, but fortunantly the keybinding help is a quick ? away, and after a couple times of looking the command up, it's easy to remember.

ADOM is a great game, and exremely challenging. Don't let the large number of commands (many of which you won't use very often anyways) scare you away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123055853', 'num_games_owned': 417, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2813, 'last_played': 1527184283}
review: It's one of those games that will make you a better person. Been playing it for over a decade with no end in sight.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095297277', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 22342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3156, 'last_played': 1706576519}
review:
The farthest I ever got in ADOM was as a gnomish wizard. She was more than strong enough to end the game... but I had went to the Tomb of the High Kings and had my climbing set melted away.

This game is random, unrelenting and unforgiving. I love it.

This game is eight years older than me, and is still being updated constantly... that speaks volumes about the dedication the creator has.

The resurrection campaign's success a few years ago spoke immeasuably about the amazing community the game has developed.

Although ADOM might not be everyone's cup of tea, it's still a fantastic piece of art... and a spectacular game, to boot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967626206', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 62, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1473163926}
review:
Hesitate to give this a thumbs down - more of a thumbs neutral really... Here's the thing. I've been playing rogue-likes for more than 20 years. I love them. Never did get into ADOM much, but hey, I have lots of things on Steam, why not this too.

Trouble is, even when you enjoy other rogue-likes (TOME, angband variants etc) ADOM is still REALLY complex with the command interface. It's a whole other level of complex. If you know how to use Vi, then you'll probably love ADOM, the rest of us probably just get annoyed. It's just too steep a learning curve to be that enjoyable.

Seriously, at one point in the tutorial it says you can drop stuff on the altar, and to do that you can press 'd', or ':d' or '<ctrl>d'. WTF... And that's just one command... 

If you know and love ADOM, you'll probably love this version too. But I didn't. I'm under 2 hours, so I'm going to get a refund I think. I've been playing rogue-likes long enough now to know this just ain't for me...

author: {'steamid': '76561198027897834', 'num_games_owned': 594, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 71445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1326, 'playtime_at_review': 40644, 'last_played': 1712373183}
review:
[b](before reading, you can literally get this game free on the website: http://www.adom.de/home/downloads.html the downside is that its an older version and the UI isn't as fancy, most in-game stuff is the same)[/b]

I thought I would hate this game, first hour or two learning the keybinds I [i]DID[/i] hate it (you can just take a look at the negative reviews, most of them are people who gave up within hours because of the massive amount of keybinds and the non-use of the mouse), but now it's become the only game I play on Steam.

There is so much to do and so many ways to do them. A single run where I made it almost halfway through the game took me 14-15 hours (don't worry you can save). No two runs can be similar in any way shape or form; the story is always different. The Steam version is the product of [b]22 years of development[/b], and it just got an update recently. You won't find many games with more content than ADoM has to offer.

Keep in mind, however, this being an old-school roguelike, ADoM is by far the hardest game I've played in my life. It is 1 of the 4 "big roguelikes" as people like to honk about, the others being Angband, Crawl, and NetHack, which are not on Steam, but free to download as well.



If you can stomach the "learning how to play" aspect of the game, this is among the best games money can buy you.





[strike]updating review for the dank steam badge[/strike]
[strike]again[/strike]

author: {'steamid': '76561198045016378', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1683516827}
review:
Pearl Jam Radio on Pandora, ADOM, and a six-pack... heaven!

I've been playing this game for two decades, it's my favorite game and I owe more to it and its creator, Thomas Biskup, than almost anything else in my life. You see I fell in love with ADOM instantly while in middle or elementary school. To keep the story short, this lead to me being interested in game creation, which lead to learning programming and general analytical thinking, and that has lead to my education, my jobs, and who I am. Ya, I know, but this game is a huge part of the man I have become.

Thank you so much Thomas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084019881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 480, 'playtime_forever': 1438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1187, 'last_played': 1484110591}
review:
Интересный мир, замечательная история и масса возможностей умереть. Я понимаю почему у этой игры есть фанаты. Для казуалов теперь на неё накинули графическую шкурку, но легче от этого не стало. И да, не ешьте кобольдов!

[h1]GNU/Linux[/h1]
Порт GNU/Linux теперь работает без проблем. У меня в начале были претензии к долго летящим камням/стрелам (вплоть до заморозки игры из-за тормозящей анимации), но разработчики исправили эту проблему достаточно оперативно. Ubuntu 14.04

[h1]Обзор входит в список [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1103944566]Игры, Linux, Steam, обзоры[/url].[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198155540464', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 7393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 932, 'playtime_at_review': 1015, 'last_played': 1712354526}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045610535', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 44830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1688, 'last_played': 1694028474}
review:
Впервые играл в эту игру в 1999  году, скачав её по модему из сети FIDO.
Пожалуй единственная игра к которой я возвращаюсь вновь и вновь на протяжении вот уже 17 лет.
За всё это время прошёл её по-честному всего несколько раз )
Все эти картинки/звуки считаю не нужными - играю в ASCII режиме, чего и всем желаю - информации на экране умещается больше и воспринимать её значительно легче, как на мой взгляд.
Игра прекрасна.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049997985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1553222668}
review: A fun Rogue like RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025531975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 12208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2898, 'last_played': 1617382407}
review:
Cóż mogę powiedzieć. 

Ta gra ma w sobie coś, co nie pozwala się oderwać. Złożoność rozgrywki, losowość, za każdym razem coś zaskakuje. Aby w pełni czerpać z gry trzeba poświęcić długie godziny na jej naukę, ale warto przez to przebrnąć. Gra później się odpłaca z nawiązką! To nie jest typowa sieczka jak w nowych grach... tutaj jeden błąd kończy Twoją rozgrywkę. Bezpowrotnie. Dlatego ukończenie tej gry daje nieporównywalnie więcej satysfakcji, niż ukończenie każdej innej gry rpg. Polecam!

author: {'steamid': '76561197976122108', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 18128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2024, 'last_played': 1685668163}

author: {'steamid': '76561197962500440', 'num_games_owned': 863, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 9692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1855, 'last_played': 1601905333}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198025187751', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1470639395}
review:
I want to like this game. I really do. But I can't get past two things. 1. The mashup of mouse and key controls just doesn't work for me. I end up using the keyboard exclusively, and then I feel cheated because I paid for a GUI version of the game. 2. The graphics aren't terrible, but they are underwhelming.

I'm not going to return it, because  I want to support the developer, but I can't recommend it as it exists today.

author: {'steamid': '76561198198671678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1534817683}
review:
ADOM is a lot like a classic car. It was top of the line in its day and drove very well at the time. For a number of years, it's been sitting in a garage, and the owner recently decided to bring out the car, spruce it up, and get it back on the road. The paint has been touched up, the upholstery has been redone. The car was made before a lot of features you'd expect today were put in, so the owner has got seatbelts put in, and a new sound system, and some other odds and ends. But a lot of the car is still the same... it runs on a diesel engine, standard transmission, no power steering. It's a beautiful car, but it is still, in many respects, a product of its time.

ADOM is much the same. It's a fantastic game. It has more depth and complexity than just about any game out there, and is fiendishly challenging without being unfair (mostly). I've put in more hours into ADOM than probably any other game I've played, donated happily to the Indiegogo campaign, and look forward to the new developments as they come out. But if you've never played Rogue-likes from the 90s, you'll probably be in for a shock, much like if you've never driven without power steering, you'll be in for a shock the first time you try to drive without it. The interface is admittedly clunky, and despite the dev team's best efforts to modernize it, the learning curve is still pretty steep, and figuring out how to perform a given action (let alone when you ought to perform that action) isn't always transparent. I can imagine a lot of players finding this off-putting, and I think if you look at the negative reviews of this game, this is very much the kind of sentiment you'll see. This game isn't for everybody; due both to its difficulty and to its aesthetic, it will probably only appeal to a certain segment of players. Like the classic car.

If you've played ADOM before, you'll probably love it as much as you did then. If you haven't played before, and haven't played a lot of classic Rogue-likes generally, you might want to give the free version on http://www.adom.de/home/downloads.html a test drive first.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992234603', 'num_games_owned': 1798, 'num_reviews': 367, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1465046272}
review:
Started game and went to tutorial. 
Every step you take the game introduces 4 new commands you must learn to play the game. 
Went into a cave and found a wand, bow, & 40 arrows.
Saw an enemy across a pond. Game said to equip wand and use it, but didn't tell me what command 'use wand' was.
Started searching help files and after 3 pages of commands I found the 'shoot' button is 't'
Hit 't' and game said, "Try using a bow." Hit 't' again, "Try using a bow x2."
Decided to switch to bow, but when I tried to remove the wand, found out it was cursed and couldn't be removed.
Equiped bow in my left hand instead. Hit 't' again, "Try using a bow." 
Meanwhile game keeps poping up tutorial messages with more and more commands I need to know.
Hit 'Esc' to back out and try again, but 'Esc' brought up another list of commands, none of them were quit.
Finally jumped in the pond and swam around slowly dying while more and more tutorial messages continued to display.
Eventually drowned. Quit game. Wrote review.

10/10 Would die in tutorial confused, cursed, and alone again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198203988685', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1471, 'last_played': 1548390282}
review:
generate new character, die. generate new character, die. generate new character, ooooo lvl 8! personal record! die. spend 4 hours reading ADOM blog posts from the early 90s. generate new character, die. generate new character, die. generate new character, die. generate new character, figure out how to complete the carpenter quest, die. generate new character, die. generate new character, die. generate new character, die. generate new character, oh shit is that KEETHRAX?? die. generate new character, die. generate new character, die. generate new character, oh what the hay I've been a live forever, oh what was that? "did I kill a cat at any point in the game?" Catlord says die.

If this doesn't sound appealing to you, then this game may not be for you. If you want to just jump into a game and skip through all the pesky text that pops up on the screen, then this game may not be for you. If, however, you think you might enjoy learning from the most masochistic training program in the history of mankind, then ADOM might be for you.

Game mechanics rely heavily on DnD-type RPGs.

This game rules, but it also makes me want to throw my PC into an acid pit.

You have been warned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074369120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1461890163}
review:
This is not a review so much as it is the reason I did not play to the point of being able to review the game. I picked this up because I really enjoy roguelikes such as angband (and the variants, zangband was my favorite) and especially elona. This game however has a major flaw for me. The controls are completely user unfriendly, pointedly so. I know complex and user unfriendly controls are part and parcel of this style of game. But you don't have to go out of your way to make them more so. 
To be honest I lost heart and requested a refund when I saw the keybinding for cleaning your ears. Shift-e makes your player clean their ears.... Not as part of an action tree, not as a reaction to a particular event. For some reason you have to know that to clean your ears requires you to press shift-e... I guess I just don't have the patience I used to. I've spent thousands of hours playing roguelikes, but this won't be one of them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198162832529', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 845, 'last_played': 1500728482}
review:
這個tile做的是不錯，還有製片人系統，但是操作很多有些違和，確認命令時必須要用鍵盤輸y和n……要是說全程鍵盤也就算了，但很多命令都已經可以靠鼠標點擊實現，在yes和no上卻不行這一點很難受啊……原本還以為可以在平板上玩，果然還是算了

review:
I have played this game a lot before I got the Steam version of it. And I love it and hate it at the same time! not hate-hate, but more I love to hate the way I end up dying!! So fucking hilarious, but sad as well in the moment.. In the first run I died because I was sacrificed by a goblin to its gods... author: {'steamid': '76561197971025777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1460952271}
review: There are a lot of very enthusiastic reviewers of this game, probably because of its lengthy history (and obviously fun to play). If you are considering buying it, dont base it on only videos you see onscreen, but be aware that the GUI is basically DOS based - in other words, giving commands to your toon feels extremely esoteric (stuff like: ">" to enter a dungeon, "w." to wait and pretty every command is like this) and actually hard to remember unless you're willing to spend a lot of time learning. To me, no matter how fun the game might be to play, the interface is a major hurdle to overcome. For me it just wasnt worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025709523', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 45164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5634, 'last_played': 1647723998}
review:
I'm not here to write a review. Many have been written already, ADOM is an ancient game after all.
No, I'm here because I have this bottle of wine and this wonderful game and all I wanted, besides rambling on Steam, was to give my thanks. So here's to you Mr. Biskup! Thank you for a wonderful game! I'm too lazy to complete the postcard quest, but I can at least drink this glass of wine in your honor. 
I was struck by this compelling need to write a few words about ADOM while trying another game. I won't name it but it's also free and also highly regarded by many. I already had a bit of experience with ADOM but nothing to compare it against. I quickly decided that the 2nd game is not my cup of tea, but it helped me realize what a gem ADOM really is. I played it quite a while, first the free version and then the Steam version, and I am still charmed by its music, by its atmosphere, by its depth. Even the minimalist tileset is charming.
Now I have all this hunger to master the game. It's slowly becoming an addiction, trying to go deeper or further than the last time. I'm learning bits and pieces and having a grand time. It's like learning to juggle, every time adding one more ball to an already incredible act. Even death is sometimes fun. Last night I laughed as I died, heavily poisoned, right after emerging victorious close to HMV. The Gods were tired of my nagging to them and chose not to answer me. But who cares, one more ball was added to the juggle. 
Anyway, to all of you trying to decide the game's worth based on Steam reviews: get it, pour a glass of wine and join me in my quest to master this wonderful game.

review: This is one of the best games that I have ever played. I've been playing on and off for pretty much the entirety of its development. If you're looking for the cleanest and clearest roguelike on the market, try this one. You can play the ASCII version of the home website for free, but this release is well worth the investment. New stuff, cleaner interface, and more customization for the optimal experience. It's like playing DnD without having to organize a group.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014766672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 398, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1459172358}
review:
ADOM (Ancient Domains of Mystery)  is a roguelike adventure game, developed by a team of 5 people. This review is coming from someone who has not played the original games in the series and has no prior knowledge, and from someone who didn’t grow up playing this type of game either. Please bear that in mind with this review. 

Gameplay is like any other roguelike game, where you get to choose from an array of different characters, and develop levels, statistics and skills as you progress.  The game is played from a top down angel and is very heavily weighted towards stats and what choices you make in whether you succeed or fail.  The game’s tutorial absolutely bombards you with way too much information which personally left more confused compared to when I first started. The controls and UI are quite possibly the worst I have ever experienced in a game too. There is quite literally a different button for every single mechanic in the game. This game made me feel sufficiently stupid because of how much jumble there is on any one screen at any time. The game was telling me to use buttons that I don’t think I have ever used on this keyboard. I am surprised this is one of the most popular roguelikes ever just from going off the usability of the game thus far. 

The graphics are bad, there is no way around it and anyone who says otherwise is purely saying it from a nostalgia standpoint.  The pictures in the screen shots are definitely not what the game looks like on my screen, and I was playing the game in 4k. 

I am still stuck in the tutorial of the game, because of being dumbfounded with the controls and the amount of information being thrown at me but this game if you manage to get into it, will offer you hours and hours of content with a very high replay ability factor also being the main reason behind this. 

I am fully expecting this review to not be very popular given that I have reviewed it before even getting out of the tutorial; and I am clearly missing something about this game since it is so highly rated. But for me, having not grown up playing this type of game, and from someone who is not able to take in abundant amounts of information and learning the most whacky confusing control scheme, I simply cannot recommend it. It is possibly a generation thing, but if you mostly agree with my reviews and enjoy the same games I do, then you may want to eerie on the side of caution when trying this out as it is simply a game I did not enjoy at all. 

[b][u] Tom's Score Card[/u][/b]
1) Stay away
[b][u]2) Not Recommended[/u][/b]
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play
----
If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking [url=steamcommunity.com/groups/TeamTomsReviews]here[/url].

You may also be interested in checking out a PC gaming podcast, be sure to head [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/dlpcg]here.[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198016754959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 79787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1421, 'last_played': 1551662260}
review:
Been playing ADOM for over a decade now, and it's easily my favorite roguelike out there.

Compared to other roguelikes:
+More indepth game options(control permadeath, treasure spawn rates, monster difficulty...etc).
+Has an overworld(multiple dungeons, towns, and wilderness encounters).
+A main story quest with multiple endings, as well as several sidequests.
+A relatively comprehensive official wiki.
+Corruption system which grants mutations with both positive and negative effects.
*A dozen races and almost two dozen classes.

Compared to how it used to be:
+A starsign selector.
+Two new races and classes.
+Graphics options of Tiles + Minimap, or classic ASCII.
+Sound effects & music.
+New quests, areas, monsters, dungeon features, and bug fixes.
-Mindcrafters still can't mind control.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038354834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 10213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3157, 'last_played': 1704616372}
review:
[h1]TL;DR[/h1] Tough as nails for beginners, very rewarding once you learn it

[h1]Pro:[/h1]
[list]
[*][i]Extremely[/i] lengthy (a lot of exploration and trial&error required)
[*]In-depth gameplay
[*]Requires quite a bit of planning and thinking
[*][i]Very[/i] challenging.
[/list]
[h1]Cons:[/h1] 
[list] 
[*]Quite hostile to new players/[b]very[/b] steep learning curve
[*]Slow paced, not for the average "I want to shootz stuff!!1!11!"
[*]Almost mandatory to open the wiki every time to learn about the game (at least in my case)
[*]Once you die, you die and that's it (in almost every case). That can be off putting, especially if you put 25 hours+ in a                                                            single character
[*]Sometimes very random, you can get into some really [strike]bullsh[/strike]... unfair situations
[/list]
[h1]Bottom line:[/h1]
If you have the patience to learn it, ADOM can be such a rewarding game. The more you learn, the more you'll want to learn and play. Definitely a must have if you are not put off by its very steep learning curve. In case you aren't sure about the purchase, there is a free version at www.ancientdomainsofmystery.com , which is basically the full version but a bit outdated.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970567244', 'num_games_owned': 823, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 16338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8331, 'last_played': 1612134012}
review:
[h1]Ancient Domains of Mystery[/h1]
[i]Developed by: Thomas Biskup , Jochen Terstiege , Zeno Rogue , Krzysztof Dycha , Lucas Dieguez
Published by: Thomas Biskup
Released:  16th Nov 2015[/i]

[h1]Impressions and thoughts:[/h1]

ADOM is one of the 'Gods' of the traditional roguelike genre, starting as a MS DOS game in 1994, continually being  development to this day.  It features several dozen different dungeons, some with fixed layout and others randomly generated each time you play.  It also has an 'overworld' adventure map, which was an unique feature in ADOM's young days.

There are a lot of different character types you can make from a big selection of races and classes who can pursue multiple different endings.  Save the world from ChAoS as a Troll Paladin, or maybe take the place of the elder chaos god Andor Drakon as a Hurthling Farmer? Anything goes.

ADOM has always been and will continue to be freeware, downloadable from the developer site adom.de.  Recent features include the graphical Noteye tileset that vastly improves the visual appeal.

On Steam, the Deluxe version promises a slew of additional features, many of which at the time of this review several months after release have not been realized in the game.  This is a point worthy of critique.  The small development team working on ADOM have always done things in their own pace, which is perfectly fine for a freeware hobby project.  However with a Steam release comes expectations of promises being delivered on.  As much as I love the devs and the wonderful game they've created, this must be pointed out.  While ADOM is a complete game in its own right, the DELUXE version is far from complete.

That bit of complaining aside, ADOM is a beautiful game.  It is a brutal, oldschool roguelike with such a staggering depth that even with the community wiki on hand, it can take years to uncover all its tricks and secrets.  It will kill hundreds of characters, often just when you felt they were getting somewhere before you can even think about beating the whole game.  It has the replayability for the game to still be addicting to play for all those attempts, with all its character variations and random generated nature.  In fact, I recommend this game not for the story and reaching its ending, but for all the journeys your poor doomed characters embark on before they inevitably get crushed.

If you like turnbased dungeon crawling, traditional roguelikes with deep systems that you will keep learning new things in even after years of playing, ADOM comes strongly recommended.  However!  I would suggest playing the freeware version on adom.de first.  Unless you just want to support the developers of course (which you should!).  The Deluxe version of the game on Steam doesn't as of yet add much of features to justify a price tag.  Once implemented I think the Steam version will be safely recommended, as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025693569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1955, 'last_played': 1572804451}
review:
One of the major predecessors to the 'adventure roguelike' genre has finally come to Steam! I have been playing this game for more years than my 'time played' would suggest, and for people who love a good roguelike RPG, I can honestly say that I have yet to find a better one. A huge world (for a roguelike), many quests, secrets, Easter Eggs, character customization, achievements, challenges.... this game is an absolute *gem*. 

Be aware: like all good(?) roguelikes, this is not a game for the faint of heart. Even with an 'easymode' to it, it can have a very steep learning curve, and your deaths will be spectacular. A lot of weight can hang on the Will Of The RNG. The right weapon at the right time, or the wrong roll at the wrong time, can make or break a game. Be aware that while skill counts heavily, it's all too possible to find yourself in a situation where one mislaid trap can be the diffeence between life and death. 

It's a game I wouldn't trade for the world, though, and one that is worth every penny paid for it. If you're a fan of the roguelike genre, this is one not to be missed. Don't pass this up!

author: {'steamid': '76561197976664204', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 3583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2645, 'last_played': 1605677950}
review: One of the classic "big roguelikes" with a graphical overhaul and some UI convenience features added. One of my favourites and still a great game all these years later... you can still play the non-graphical version for free (and it's still great) but I think it's just worth buying this in order to support the developer and let him keep making this even better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985537279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 10977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8338, 'last_played': 1479297001}
review:
This is one of the most complete roguelikes out there. It is probably the game I have spent more time playing. Recently, it has undergone several changes that include graphics and a lot of gameplay improvements but the core is mostly the same.
The number of classes and races is staggering. There are several endings and several types of gameplay.
I like the fact that it caters for users of all backgrounds. You can set it up to remove the permadeath element (but it will tag your savegame and considerably lower your score) or you can create an even tougher version and increase your score.

author: {'steamid': '76561198266332138', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 33873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13269, 'last_played': 1532282745}
review: ADOM is the second roguelike I've played seriously (Nethack being the first) but it is the one I've returned to over time. It has the advantage of a developed storyline, aided by the persistent and mostly fixed outer world, and is generally more modern/newbie-friendly than other roguelikes. While most roguelikes' difficulty is heavily tilted to the start of the game, ADOM provides a reasonably reliable start via the beginning town/tutorial cave no matter how weak a character you roll. It also has a nice graphical version (NotEye) though with some substantial memory/processing flaws and is mostly playable with the mouse though keyboard tends to be faster.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035415501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1673843008}
review: I had to return this game. I know it is a good game...But, it wants you to type at lease 30 words a minute to play it. I didn't know this before purchas, the game has way to many key commands! I like WASD or controler options. Im new to rouge-likes and love em. I understand the history in this one. This game has a huge learning curve just to play it and I didn't want to memorize commands to do so. I know this game is goodtimes if you can get past that aspect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003730648', 'num_games_owned': 81, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3646, 'last_played': 1546365474}
review: The best roguelike, balancing depth of storyline and required knowledge with ease of play, is even better with graphics and sound—identifying dropped items at a glance is much easier, and the interface is more fluid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073491827', 'num_games_owned': 824, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1606191260}
review:
I started playing ADOM around 2000-2001 and it was the first roguelike I ever played, and no roguelike has even come close to living up to the standard that this game has set. Well except maybe Dwarf Fortress, but that is a whole different beast.
I played this game by myself and I have played with friends who had set up linux shells with this game on it and we would compete for high scores. I cannot overstate how much enjoyment this game has brough to my life.

This game is tough as nails and it has punished and brutalized me more times that you can imagine. 
And I loved every second.
I have put hundreds if not thousands of hours into ADOM. 
And it was all for free. 
I saw this on the store and bought it instantly. Not a second thought.

Hilariously, even with the new mouse controls, I still play totally with the keyboard. 
After all these years, I still remember every key. This game is in my blood.

I feel I must caution new players who might be thinking of trying this game out that you may find the learning curve a bit intimidating, but please persist. The experience this game provides when you are confident that you know what you are doing is just pure golden. One moment of carelessness may get you killed, but you know that it was your fault. 
Take every character's death as a teaching moment.

Thomas Biskup absolutely deserves every penny of my money.
I know how much effort he has put into this game, his labour of love.
He really deserves my money for all the laughs, the tears, the near misses, the terrifying moments, the foolish mistakes and miscalculations, the mystery, the discovery, the pain, and the joy he has brought to me through this game. 

Thank you Mr Biskup, even though I was never able to send you a postcard, I hope you can appreciate the gesture of my purchase.




Also, that moment when you open an exploding door and accidentally slay a feline. (>_<)

author: {'steamid': '76561198031551393', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 14828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5825, 'last_played': 1659106460}
review: My favourite roguelike ever, infinite replay value, always something new to learn, been playing for 7 years and beat it for the first time on the steam version, 15€ is well worth it for over 7 years of entertainment and some people have been playing since the 90's

author: {'steamid': '76561198161079154', 'num_games_owned': 443, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1786, 'last_played': 1484425947}
review:
I played this game A LOT something like 15 years ago. Even though this is available for free. I decided to purchase "deluxe" version, just for supporting development.

Be warned though: If you decide to buy this game, this game is difficult. This game is probably the most difficult came you'll encounter.  There will be countless number of in game deaths. As this is Roguelike game, there isn't thing called "checkpoints", or "reloading from most recent save point". You have to start over. You will ragequit, you will bang your head against wall, you will ask yourself why, you will swear not to play this game ever again... but you will come back.  You will remember what you did 'wrong' last time, you will try different things...  And at some beautiful day you will feel great satisfaction when finally manage to complete the game! After that, you'll start the game again, as there is still a lot of unsolved mysteries...

This game will offer you a lot of enjoyment for years to come, if you have enough patience to overcome very steep learning curve. Do you accept the challenge?

author: {'steamid': '76561198011657088', 'num_games_owned': 152, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 956, 'last_played': 1703669917}
review: ADOM jest grą niezwykłą. To chyba jedyny tytuł, w który gram (z przerwami) tak długo, bo już ponad dekadę przecież. Ten graficzny lifting w wersji steamowej zrobiony został z takim smakiem, że nie mogłem nie zapłacić wreszcie Biskupowi za tak wiele wrażeń, frustracji i uniesień. To jedyny rogalik, który zdał u mnie test czasu: może ze względu na unikalne połączenie fabuły z losowością podgatunku, a może dlatego, że do niego po prostu dotarłem najwcześniej. Wiem jedno: ta gra się nie starzeje, wcale. Gdyby pozostała przy semigrafice, to też bym w to grał... ale za te wszystkie ładne piksele bynajmniej nie jestem obrażony. Bo gra ciągle ma swoją duszę.

author: {'steamid': '76561198205753280', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1608803130}
review:
I was a fan of the original way back in the day, played it constantly. Wrote my own program to auto-backup the saves so I could cheat permadeath when I wanted to. I have played many dungeon crawl games, including Rogue, the OG of the genre. Out of them, this is one of the best. 

A large open world (for the genre) full of quests and NPCs. There is plenty to do and see in ADOM as well as a large selection of Class/Race combanations. The mechanics are perfect. This game was created based on PnP rpgs like DnD, and attempts to recreate this as much as possible. There are a ton of hidden rolls, and many are refrenced in the text. The text really makes it feel like a tabletop rpg, well written and really sets the tone.

ADOM is also Random and unpredictable. You may die on the way to your first town, killed by enemies you stood no chance against, or kick down a door  to find a large demon ready to rip your head off. With permadeath on it is a hardcore dungeon delvers wet dream come true. This game is hard.

But now there are options to turn certain features, like permadeath, off. This opens the door for people like me, who enjoy the style, but dont like always playing a hardcore character. It also makes it easier to really enjoy the story and world without fear of losing your character . The graphics are not cutting edge, and I for one am glad. This is the update the game needed. Havent fiddled with the other game modes, but I theres just so much to do. I am also glad development seems to be continueing, so there may be more content to come. 

So there you go, I love this game, totally worth my money.  If you are into old skool Rogue-Likes and value depth over fancy graphics I think you will too.



ps~Thank you Thomas, for all the hours I have played your game over the years, I bought this almost as soon as it came out on steam, and you deserve every penny. GG

author: {'steamid': '76561198102167083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 7987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1686683705}

author: {'steamid': '76561198010821953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 20624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11175, 'last_played': 1556412232}
review:
Since a new update came out recently, I wanted to revise my review for this game after playing it for a lot more.

This game is still an awesome game and I have enjoyed it a lot more than most modern games I've played these days.

Pros: 
Replayability
-Most areas are all randomly generated (save for a couple special places)
-Item drops and artifacts you get are random (you never no what you will get, good or bad)
-You can play the same character type again, and it will feel totally different from your first playthrough!


Tons of Content
-Many areas explore
-Plenty of quests to tackle
-Multiple endings (you can beat the game quickly or try and complete an ultra ending)

Customizability
-Many classes to choose from (ranging from easy to difficult in terms of playstyle)
-Many races to also choose from (you can be a Human, Dwarf, Elf, Drakeling, Orc and more!)
-The new point buy system is awesome and more improved! Make your fighter have lots of strength and toughness but little learning
-Different playstyles: You're wizard doesn't have to wear cloth robes only, have him wear plate armor and attack with weapons (assuming you got the strength for it ;))

Graphics/UI/Music
-The graphics and UI are very nice looking, especially after this update. The animations are nice as well, and soon there will character customization (I'm really excited for this one)!
-The UI updated also looks very good (although it does have a tendency to get in the way when your character is at the top of a map. Hopefully this gets fixed soon)
-The music has also been improved as well, and there are a lot of good tracks in this game

Support
-Game is still being supported years after it came out 
-New content is planned even after this new update (new artifacts, levels, quests; Go check out the adom forums or the creators twitter for previews)

With any good game, there are also some cons:

Cons:
Difficulty
-When learning how to play, the game can be rather harsh (hunger, corruption, etc.). The difficulty barrier isn't as large as something like Dwarf Fortress, but it is there. You have to be able to learn from your mistakes. If you can't do that, this game might not be for you. If you stick with it though, it's a rewarding game.
-If you do have problems, the community is quite helpful (as long as you are willing to learn). There is an active adom community in the steam forums as well as in the roguelikes discord chat. Feel free to stop by!
-You can also turn off certain things like hunger and corruption, or you can also play with reloadable games if you want to play that way

Key Bindings: 
-This game has so much in it, and there are a lot of key bindings that are somewhat unintuitive. If you might not be able to figure it out, it can be quite frustrating. The game does give quick hints now, so its helpful, but this complaint is one I see a lot from negative reviews, and I do agree with it. 

Bugs:
-Like many games, there are always going to be bugs you run into, and ADOM is no exception. The game runs quite well, but every now and then you will run into something that might be a problem. If that does happen, be sure to submit a bug report, otherwise they wont be able to be fixed.

Tedium:
-One thing that I might complain about is there is a small amount of tedium in the game. You have be constantly eating, sacrificing for piety, managing inventory, avoiding cats, going to certain areas at certain times etc. It's not a huge deal, as imo it adds an interesting twist to the game. However, it might be a turn off for some people, so I thought I would just bring that up.
-A lot of knowledge can be found from the adom wiki, which is maintened quite well by the community. 

Past these cons, I love this game, and would highly recommend it to anyone who loves roguelikes!

If you are on the fence about this game, there is a free version you can download from here: http://www.adom.de/home/downloads.html

It's a much older version, but soon it will be updated with some of the new content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198203189120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 11389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1629, 'last_played': 1697299816}
review:
This is my absolute favourite rogue like. I have been playing for at least 10 years and the new steam version adds some welcome changes.

I love this game simply because it has all the awsome features you would expect from a roguelike but with a world map.
The world map is always the same and features a lot of entrances to dungeons and villages, each being different in sometimes a variety of ways, and for the most part are randomized every game. this leaves you free to pick and choose which quests you want to take. Once you have figured out a lot of the early quests you can choose to skip the ones in which the rewards do not interest you.

My one criticism of this game is that the religion system sucks. It's not interesting, the rewards for becoming uber pious are kind of lackluster when i consider how grindy and unenjoyable reaching that point is. Fortunately it is not necesary to concern yourself with it. I compare this game in this regard to dungeon crawl and IVAN which both have interesting and fun religion systems.

Another aspect of this game that i like compared to other roguelikes, such as dungeon crawl, is that the skill system is very rewarding. some skills are passive and just buff your character but others have specific applications.
you can pick pockets, pick locks, build bridges, craft arrows, tame animals, brew potions, smith armour...
For me this adds a layer of character that helps me role play.

I recomend this game however if you do not have any experience with roguelikes i suggest you do some reading about the genre as this game is brutal and, other than the games basic mechanics, this is mostly a trial by fire. 
I am adamant about not using guides or cheating, however this game is so brutal that despite knowing all i need to know i have never managed to win even a single time despite using the adom guidebook and perusing forums for additional insight.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011300382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1453151601}
review: extremely dated game reskinned with new graphics. controls are clunky and require a lot of memorization. you will probably be frustrated unless you already know the controls from the old game. most of the positive reviews have a lot to do with the nostalgia factor, but this game is extremely hostile to new players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028439184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1701343959}
review:
I've been playing this game since the late 90s. My friends and I had a running joke about it: Anytime you see someone stealing a usb drive, a floppy disk, or CDROM in a movie, we would say it had ADOM on it. 

It's a fun, deep, and fulfilling game BUT it does have a wee bit of a learning curve. All old games had one. Learning how to play it was part of the fun.  ADOM comes from the era of gaming where you need to read the manual. Invest some time familiarizing yourself with the system and then go ahead and enjoy your adventures around Ancardia.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969391607', 'num_games_owned': 754, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 7511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2002, 'last_played': 1644872319}
review:
Once you get past the interface, this is a great game that rewards patient play with a very ghood risk/reward payoff.

I would say though to download the free version (it still had the new interface) first from the adom.de website and learn how to control the game.
There is an immense depth to this game and it can be a little hard on new players.
If you're struggling, search for the ADOM guide book, but be warned that it does contain spoilers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031234916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1610908529}

author: {'steamid': '76561198010737305', 'num_games_owned': 2001, 'num_reviews': 349, 'playtime_forever': 1464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 646, 'last_played': 1682094854}
review:
I've always loved Roguelikes and ADOM was one of my favorites. I was always terrible at it, but now they added tiles to see which monster is which easier, and they also added a simplified action menu, so, I'm still terrible at it, but it is more fun to be terrible. 

Only gripes I can think of are that the HUD and menu are akward (which he said he will work on) and I think it is till too overwhelming for a newbie. Thank God for the ADOM Wiki. Use it. Use it often.

Overall, one of my favorite Roguelikes, favorite games altogther is still here and looks beautiful.

Besides maybe Nethack, you won't find a game this nuanced and intricate. Just buy it and play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105670824', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 5595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1955, 'last_played': 1492985326}
review:
Very solid game with extremely in depth mechanics. 
This game is very unforgiving, so newbies to the RPG gerne beware.  If you haven't played many "classics" like baldur's gate, icewind dale ect. You will maybe feel a bit alienated on the D&D based mechanics. None the less, once you understand the system it is very logical and mathematic. 

Anyone who has played a decent amount of RTS games or MMORPG's will not have a hard time learning and memorising the different keys used to play the game. There are quite a few different commands and key combinations, it can seem intimidating at first. Honestly, there's only about 10-15 commands you will actually use early game. You learn everything fluently as you play by occasionally going into the help menu for key bindings.

The game is quite unforgiving and does require a lot of trial and error. It will teach you to be careful and methodical. Also with the perma-death feature, you will have to learn how to leg it. All in all I feel the game is very fair. There are occasional frustrating deaths like getting critical hit by a rat who you thought was absolutely no threat but most of the time it is your own fault if you died. 

I would definately recommend this game to anyone who love's very indepth and challenging RPGs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962550502', 'num_games_owned': 1702, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1216, 'last_played': 1466802031}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993956149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1056, 'last_played': 1609284452}
review: Classic roguelike game that's relatively friendly to newcomers compared to others. Been playing since it was still ASCII only and the port over to tile graphics makes it a more convenient and enjoyable experience. Very replayable and easily immersive if you've enjoyed any roguelikes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198199475769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 29078, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2297, 'last_played': 1662387262}
review:
我就简单谈谈我是怎么死的。
		                             ---- 一个新入坑的冒险者，

打不开的门强行踹...卒。
不会擦脸，两眼一黑...卒。
刚入行时心宽，吃了一具哥布林尸体...卒。
曾在晨曦之门进修武艺，自信残血反杀蚂蚁...卒。
新来那会不懂解毒，呆呆地看着中毒，掉血...卒。

前辈曾说，吃亏长记性。不同于ToME提供的各种反杀的机会，ADOM让我经历了年轻的冒险者渐渐变得经验丰富的这个过程。
知道踹门会死，下次就悠着点；知道大虫子喷一口毁好几件装备，下次就别近战打他；知道2层有蚁穴，下次就绕着走咯...

总体来说非常有吸引力的，可玩性高；
操作十分方便，没小键盘的笔记本都能很舒服；
系统里面内嵌帮助（包括键位，查起来很方便。
当然，都是英文的，国内没什么圈子也没汉化...

若有入坑的，欢迎加我好友哟。

author: {'steamid': '76561198006776975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1567874995}
review:
ADOM is a missed opportunity. It could have been great but instead it is a nostalgia bait, ridden by emacs-like keybindings, featuring Steam bells and whistles only to justify it ridiculously high price.

There is no reason to buy this version other than supporting the author and only then if you played it - like me - fifteen years ago. If you are a new player, I'd steer away from it or, at least, try a free version which is obtainable from Mr Biskup's site.

There are better roguelikes (like: true roguelikes, not rogue-lites and whatnot) out there, that are more fun and much more forgiving more newcomers. ADOM won't tell you a thing on what to do and what to expect; as such, I perceive it as constant stream of frustrating attempts to plunge one cavern deeper only to learn game's intricate mechanics. If it wasn't for spoilers, it would take tens of years to complete the game; with spoilers, you may expect to win the game after few years of intensive playing (and by no means this is an exaggeration).

It was fun then. It is not fun any more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993435536', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 10326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5159, 'last_played': 1542336609}
review:
I suggest you try this one for free before buying here as it is definitly not for everyone. There is a steep learning curve that will leave you scratching your head if you don't take the time to look up things, both in game, and from other sources.   

The steam version is different from the free version, you can change a lot more in the initial setup of the world making it tougher or easier on steam than you can with the free version. but other than that they are the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038177374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1695512155}
review: I've been playing this game for over 10 years and have never once gotten bored with it. Very well made.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067791736', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1684030520}
review:
个人感觉比tome4好玩，但是操作实在是...有中古的操作方式和现代的鼠标操作，但是两者没有很好的融合在一起，导致各种没接触过这类游戏的玩家很难上手，这点tome4就做的很好，操作基本跟暗黑一样，但是抛开这些不说游戏素质和游戏的进化真心很棒，由原来的ascii码变为现在的title，游戏内容也十分丰富，而且有一定的场景互动，每种职业玩法也都各有特色。当然丰富的游戏就带了各种丰富有意思的死法（笑）。

总之这是款真正喜爱“游戏”的玩家不得不买的作品。

评分 我给10分

p.s:主界面的bgm真好听，有时候打开游戏，总是在主界面循环一遍再进游戏

author: {'steamid': '76561198012466367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 8208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1198, 'last_played': 1710902456}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004517600', 'num_games_owned': 731, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 2539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2212, 'last_played': 1512419712}
review:
A classic roguelike from german developer Thomas Biskup that has been around since 1994. Enough has been said about it, this is truly one of the biggest and most beloved out there with countless hours of fun*.

Note that you can get this game for free, but the Steam release has some cool features like a more streamlined interface providing some needed assistance for beginners. It also has some platform specific stuff like a crowd mode where the game adapts its difficulty to the number of people playing or dead characters from your steam friends showing up as potential enemies in your game (Fuck you Burnalot).

*death

author: {'steamid': '76561198131312504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 96024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 20, 'playtime_at_review': 62330, 'last_played': 1711494700}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027567339', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1032, 'last_played': 1451912050}
review:
Наверное лучший и наиболее глубокий рогалик из существующих. В достимовскую эпоху играл в него долгие часы. 
Теперь с нормальной графикой ADOM в 10 раз опаснее. 20 из 10 - очень рекомендую.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989077181', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 80884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2965, 'playtime_at_review': 12617, 'last_played': 1712408278}
review:
I have been playing this game for nigh on 18 years. It has given me more enjoyment and more play time than any title I have gotten my mitts on in that time period. My only regret is that I couldnt throw piles of money at the developer when he put the indigogo project up for the revival project. 

To new players to the game dont be discouraged if you lose many characters in the very beginning. Some you will lose to the difficulty, Many you will lose to ignorance or stupidity, some losses will be heartbreaking and others will be hillarious. But no game will fill you with more personal satisfaction then when you get your first character to close that damn portal...... dear god it took me 15 years to win, many came close but hopes were dashed on one monstrous boss or another.  

At some point in the near future I will finally be able to complete the IRL postcard quest and pay my respects to this shiney golden god of indie game development. Thomas my hat goes off to you. I would recommend this game to anyone with a pulse, I have played this game longer than anything else over the years and it will continue to be my most played game for many MANY years to come. 

PS for the love of god and all that is holy, kill as few cats tigers and lions as possible - the catlord is a vengeful sort and gets spooky as hell if you kill to many. If you are good enough to avoid killing felines though that invisible killing machine is more than kind enough to give you a god tier ring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155088578', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1451639767}
review:
ADOM is the first steam game I have ever returned.   I typically read many reviews beforehand - so it's not necessary to return games.  In the case of ADOM, most of the reviews fail to mention any of the issues associated with the numerous keybindings required to play the game in an enjoyable fashion.  I didn't notice until after returning the game that most of the negative reviews were unfairly down voted for mentioning critical issues associated with poor mouse controls.

The controls are clunky and the game requires too much memorization of key bindings to play.  Most of the positive reviews posted on Steam are likely from long time players who memorized the long list of key bindings a long time ago.  For new players - this will likely be a highly unpleasant experience because of the aforementioned poor user interface and reliance on key bindings. 

There are free versions of this game that you can try out before buying.  I highly recommend any new player to this game to download a free version and try out the controls first hand before purchasing on Steam.  You will easily discover if the controls bother you or not.   Like the other reviews that mention ADOM's outdated reliance keybindings and clunky controls, I expect my review to be down-voted.  I'm okay with that if it means saving other Steam users money.  The limited time listed of me playing this game is actually overstating my time spent on this game.  90% of that time was actually spent reading up on one of the many outdated keybindings required to play before deciding to uninstall the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037601734', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 6, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1711401637}
review:
I had a character that needed to cross a small lake.  Didn't have the bridge making skill.  Didn't have the swimming skill.  So I froze the water to walk across.  Bridge collapsed half-way across.  Started drowning. Pirhana's attacked. Began doing my best to "swim" to shore. Pirhana's attacking the whole way.  Died on the shoreline.

10/10 would play again

P.S. Been playing since 2000, don't let the game time fool ya.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030892825', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1620583335}
review: I have been playing this game for about 16-17 years, several thousands of hours before bying this Deluxe Version on steam. It's not just the best roguelike game ever made, it's the best RPG. The depth, the mechanics, the YASDs... I still kind of prefer the AscII version, but am warming up to the graphical alternative. Anything negative about ADOM? It's probably hard to learn, though this new Adom is more newbie-friendly than the classic Adom. And it's VERY hard to master - it took me 10 years to win the game the first time - and that was the easiest kind of win, which I've only managed to repeat 3 times since then. But it's well worth the time. Most games will be forgotten after a few decades. ADOM will be played by people 50, 60, 70 years from now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006963653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1525, 'last_played': 1662847699}
review:
The counter shows that I've spent 28,4h with ADOM on Steam. That is only partly true. The truth is that I've been playing this game since August, 1998. So it's basically like... 17 years. Soon my playtime will be permitted to buy alcohol and smokes. I remember the time when with my best friend we sent a postcard to the creator, Thomas Biskup, because back then ADOM was "postcard-ware" - when you wanted to thank the developer, you just had to go to the post office and send a postcard. It is worth every penny considering the game's been free for over 20 years and you can still check the free, older versions at adom.de

Now ADOM is on Steam and for ~15 euro you can experience one of the hardest, most challenging, vague (in terms of "what should I do now?") and merciless games of all time. ADOM is one of the legendary roguelike games. That means permadeath after 30hrs of game, that means all your scrolls getting soaked because you forgot to grab that damned blanket, that means drowning, because the ice you created with ice bolt just cracked and you and all your belongings are gone, that means getting burned because one of your fire resistance rings isn't blessed, that means almost crying when you see game message stating: *THUMP*. Finally that means checking every class combination and getting acquainted with ADOM Bible or some other, newer guidelike stuff, because you think that there is some magic formula, a cheat, a "best class combination -> enter google" that will allow you to "win". That if you create a trollish healer born under the Candle star sign, you will magically plow through the Caverns of Chaos and win the game. 


And then, on level three of some random dungeon you stumble upon undead vault.


ADOM went through a lot during over 20 years of development - now you have graphics engine, you can choose a lot more during character creation, finally - you have a "cheat engine" so to speak, so you can try to go through the whole game without permadeath - as far as I understand, I've never tried this mode, because ADOM is in a way something that games like "Dark Souls" aspire to - you die, you learn, you die again. After a thousand deaths, you die once more, but you try again. 

During the "ADOM hiatus" a lot of other games emerged - ToME, Elona, and finally - a lot of lighthearted roguelike(like)s. 

I never thought I would live to see this day. The king is back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063863033', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1069, 'last_played': 1599076763}
review:
For the gamer with too much time on their hands ; )
A good game made truly great. Personally I have no problem with ASCI (Dwarf Fortress and Cataclysm: Dark Days Ahead for the win!!!) but the inclusion of a tileset (read not ASCI graphics) helps to elevate the game.
Now we get to see just HOW hideous a cannibalistic, female Orc berserker carrying around rotting dead bodies truly is.
A nice selection of classes, races (not the car or horse kind), a birth sign system and randomly generated dungeons combine into a time sucking gem.

EDIT: The game might be challenge for some players, in particular those new/fresh to rouge-likes, and can at times seem unfair. There is mouse integration, although as to its merits I currently don't know as I tend to use the built in keyboard shortcuts to play. If one has played Dwarf Fortress Adventure mode, or Tales of Maj'eyal (both fantastic games, check 'em out : ) ) you will find yourself a little more comfortable with the controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988971915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1421, 'last_played': 1451772403}
review:
I have played this game since 1997 and completed the postcard quest multiple times. Easily one of the most brutal and fun games I have ever encontered. I managed to finish the ASCII version THREE times (altough with the worst possible ending for two of them) and all of them were amazing and completely unique.

The game is fun and unforgiving at the same time - just an amazing expeierience.

If any of that changes between the current version and the free ASCII version I will update this review - but right now it has 23 out of 23 stars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052357996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1451516425}
review:
Honestly, this is one of the best games for those who enjoy pain, suffering, and survival against overwhelming odds.

It feels like I'm playing D&D solo and the DM is more than willing to let my character die if I mess up. It's a rush and even as I go easy mode with saving alot and toggling hunger, I still find myself worrying about what new threat my Drakeling Barbarian is going to find himself up against.

Also, be careful with wands. They can really mess you up if you use them on yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104205132', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1560938593}
review:
每次，我都觉得，这个角色可以活很久。
每次，我都觉得这个开局肯定能让我无人能挡。

然而：

被老鼠咬死，
被淹死，
食物中毒而死，
不小心打了村民被群殴至死，
踹门踹断了腿，失血至死，
被自己的法术反弹至死，
被不知道从哪里冒出来的隐形怪打死...

如果你喜欢RL，买
如果你是第一次接触RL，买
如果你喜欢挑（zuo）战（si），买

不论是画面还是音乐，都可以让老玩家感到赏心悦目，让新玩家感到通俗易懂。

author: {'steamid': '76561197990804132', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 12204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1839, 'last_played': 1703790168}
review:
I played the game since v. 9.9.x which was about 10 years ago, and right now it's still the best roguelike on the market, with no other title even coming close.
Several totally different races and classes that matter and shape your gameplay experience. you can really see the 20+ years of development in this title.

Just imagine somebody made a title like Diablo, without focusing on the graphics engine for 80% of the time and instead it's 95% of time spent on developing the mechanics, lore and making the experience absolutely the best.

just remember to print out the keybindings or just write the most useful ones down. In current version you can tap "Enter" to get a list of rational commands which can be used at this time.

Is it worth the 15eur? Yes. Especially since I love the art direction they went for. Totally fits the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009383387', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1451573540}
review:
Ok, I didn't play this very long.  My gripe about this game is that the UI is absurd.  Imagine that every key on your keyboard does something different.  Uppercase and lowercase matter.  Then add shif, ctr, and alt modifires.  Think that is bad?  Now add character sequences as well. 

Sure there is in game help, which you need to "scroll" through using arrow keys. You can spend a huge amount of time trying to navigate through the help on how to do basic things. 

Perhaps this is a good game, but I really do not have the paitence to learn the ui behind this game.  If you do, then perhaps you can take a chance on it.  I have better things to do then memorize a bazillion key combinations.
