author: {'steamid': '76561198019271689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1546052048}
review:
Current Review, January 2018:

"A top, polished Roguelike" - TL;DR

(First off, my "offline mode" time doesn't seem to show up...) I have been playing the ADOM 3 beta and now the final v3.0.6... Man, what a total overhaul and awesome set of improvements! The UI now scales to whatever size screen you have, and it works great on my WQHD Alienware 13R3 to my rMBP to my little tiny GPD Pocket. Next, the simplification of the key commands is huge - it makes the game much easier to play. The sound and graphics/animation are improved, the questing has nice pop up text, and in general everything is much more polished. There are more game modes, etc. This is easily one of the most polished Roguelikes on Steam now - and there is a lot of competition. (Frankly quite a few are also worth playing, a testament to the dedication of their creators and the benefit of us the gamers.)

Previous Review, October 2016:

As of the latest beta, R71 in October 2016, I re-purchased this game and have played it a few hours. While I have only played it on an 11" MacBook Air so far, I can say that all my complaints about the previous version have been addressed. The game looks good and operates properly as soon as you run it. It has a steap learning curve, but that's not entirely unexpected in this sort of game. The tile graphics are reasonably nice.

Original Review, December 2015:

This was the first ever Steam game I returned; it's that bad, at least on my Mac. First, basic computer program sequences didn't work. For example, I couldn't figure out how to quit out of the game and the standard Command-Q and menu items did nothing. I eventually pulled up the "Force Quit" menu and killed the program that way (equivalent to kill -9 for Unix users). Second, the fonts and window don't scale properly, and there are about 37,000 settings for these things, none of which produce a nice, usable look and feel on fonts unless you leave the window a tiny thing on the screen. On a 2560x1440 or 1920x1080 screen it is just insanely silly. Third, the tutorial is more annoying than helpful. It randomly pops up a super-small text box that is ridiculously difficult to scroll through telling you things that are generally irrelevant at the time. Sure, it's a roguelike and so there are tons of commands, but at least list them for me in some sort of importance order on the side of the screen or something.

All in all, I've been playing Roguelikes since, literally, Rogue in the 80s and this was one of the worst experiences ever. I returned the program to Steam and downloaded the free one. I've spent a few hours with the free one and found no way around any of these problems above. If you want a truly great Roguelike to buy here on Steam, look at ToME instead. It's cheaper, easier to learn, much more beautiful, and "just works."
developer_response:
Thanks once more for updating the review. Constructive criticism like yours help us greatly in trying to improve the game more and more. We are very happy to hear that the latest release seems to have been another huge leap forward (as we hoped).

Have fun playing the game while we will work on the next batch of improvements :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198053705869', 'num_games_owned': 346, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2459, 'last_played': 1654971261}
review:
I don't usually write reviews, but this game is good enough to warrant writing one. I haven't played this game before it came out on steam, so I'm not really blinded by nostalgia goggles. But this game is good, only it's the toughest learning curve I've ever experienced, even harder than X-Com Long war mod. To those expecting to play something where it's possible to win as long as you play right, turn away. However for those willing to preservere through tens and eventually hundreds of character deaths this game is rewarding. It's sort of like crossing a minefield, where the signs are all in a different language, so you don't know where the mines are or what to do. And take my advice, the tutorial isn't that good, it's better to wiki everything, unless you are really really masochistic and wanna learn everything through dying.

But once you learn the tricks of the game, it's enormously fun. For example, I kept starving to death, because I didn't realize you could eat corpses and nobody minds. No karma lashbacks, and no getting sick, unless you eat something poisonous. Then I finally got past the third dungeon. That's right, I've died multiple times and still hadn't gotten past that third beginner dungeon. Then I made the mistake of wandering into a random dungeon and getting killed by a room full of giants. 

Anyways the perks of this game are:
 1 it's very difficult, sort of like demon souls. 
2. It's a delight for people who like to imagine what the fights look like instead of seeing it. Like when I accidentally wandered into a water trap with a fluff ball in my backpack and gremlins started appearing out of nowhere. I was like "Oh, ****" and they constantly multiplied around my Monk character. Hundreds of dead gremlins later, the floor was flooded with blood and my monk had came through unscathed. 
3. There are many, many, many different ways to play the game. You could be the unarmed monk,(my favorite), the untouchable wizard(too frail in melee for my tastes), or the cunning assassin(kept dying, cuz he doesn't start with heal) and much much more. Apparently there's a race that starts with the spit acid ability or something. 

Oh well, this reviews getting a bit too long. In short, this is a good game for those willing to put up with how hard core it is and are willing to put up with the ridiculous key mappings.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960445532', 'num_games_owned': 720, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 2587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1905, 'last_played': 1545494531}
review:
For me, this is a classic game that's improved by a tileset that expands the playability for new and old players alike.

This game is part of the big three formative roguelike games that set the benchmark for this type of packrat, dungeon crawling, permadeath that's so wonderfully additctive. The three consist of Angband (specifically T.O.M.E and its predecessors for me), Nethack and (of course) ADOM.

ADOM was probably the game the least like the others in terms of how everything worked. It allowed for extremes of overly complicated OR remarkably simple gameplay and has a depth far beyond any roguelike from its time and for that matter most roguelikes ever.

Once you've spent some time getting sufficiently spoiled (you kinda have to to finish the game), you'll end up chasing ultra endings and then you can pretty much kiss your free time goodbye. I'd definitely recommend this game provided you understand that there is a learning curve and you take your time to get into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049556803', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1377, 'last_played': 1696426418}
review:
This is the first video game I remember playing.  Ever since that point when I was a child (in the mid 1990s) attempting to comprehend the crazy game which is ADOM, I have been sorely dissappointed by nearly every other video game which crossed my path.  
Do you like Skyrim?  Fuck you!  That shit is mediocre as all shit as far as plotline is concerned!
Do you like Fallout 3?  Fuck you!  That world is tiny and stupid because you have no possibility of failure or ever getting past a mere 30 levels!
Do you like DCSS or Dwarf Fortress?  Those are great games, but ADOM is even better.
Look, you need to buy this.  Seriously, just buy it.  Screw money, screw having a girlfriend, screw rampant alcoholism.  Buy ADOM!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009516676', 'num_games_owned': 1622, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 2734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1443, 'last_played': 1506389430}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009160613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 926, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1599502308}

author: {'steamid': '76561198021971552', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 656, 'last_played': 1509454995}
review:
По правде говоря, это даже не Rogue-like, это ADOM-like. Потому что ADOM - не меньшая классика, чем собственно Rogue. При этом, в отличие от своих современников, живет и здравствует до сих пор. Обзавелась музыкой, графическим движком (в котором можно и вид из глаз включить, если очень надо) с добротными иконками, контекстными меню и прочими атрибутами времени.
Конечно, ADOM не так удобна как современные поделки. Здесь и отпугивающее новичков многокнопочное управление, которое никто не будет вам разжевывать (хотя в новых версиях вроде пытаются сгладить порог вхождения), и сотни непонятных, весьма ситуативных, навыков и талантов, и, конечно, смерть буквально за любым углом. Думаете в других рогаликах легко умереть? Это вы ADOM не видели. 
Всё это компенсируется тоннами веселья, огромным количеством возможностей и уникальным геймплеем для каждого класса, расы и даже добрых/злых героев. А еще обширным миром, эпической историей и медленным превращением в демона (всегда интересно, что на этот раз у вас вырастет).
Где еще увидишь классическую игру, которая обновляется до сих пор? И это не сиквел и не ремастер от чужих людей. Это та самая ADOM. Здесь всё прекрасно. И отлажено декадами любовной разработки. И чем дальше - тем лучше. Присоединяйтесь.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964420271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 981, 'last_played': 1489155390}

author: {'steamid': '76561198013373653', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 18123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2967, 'last_played': 1451610980}
review:
Just bought this to support the developer.  As I write this review, I have 5 mins played on record on steam (the minimum needed for steam to let you write a review) but I've played it on and off for 20 years, so I am more than happy to give back to Mr Biskup.

Rogulikes; I've played pretty much all of them.  Nethack back when it was a game only played on unix servers (solaris and the like, before linux was even a thing), original rogue on a 286, angband/moria/zangband, ToME, crawl, and countless more.  Out of all the rogulikes and related games, I would rank this up there with the original nethack, and Dwarf Fortress, which is high praise indeed.

Basically, if you recognise and enjoyed any of the games above, you will love this.  If not, the nice tileset and the work which is being put into making the UI more accessible makes this an ideal entry into a genre of games which has a history going back some 35 years now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057615874', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 40185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18847, 'last_played': 1690000244}
review:
If you do not invest yourself in this game, it will not present itself to you.
This game is a boon of the patient, a friend to the wise and an onslaught towards all.

Theres somthing alluring in a game you cannot beat, but which gives you information every time you die. Another tidbit on how to win, another clue on how the world works. This is an awesome game and probabily the only game I'd need for the rest of my life (not that I wouldnt fight for all the rest). Its also the only game I can play without a mouse or internet connection. 

I havent used the graphical mode because I cant tell what anything is, dispite everything being more detailed.
I want monsters to be shown like the @ symbol in the the art. I want monsters displayed as shaded letters, in high definition. I want several of them, and I want them now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012111498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 11275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1833, 'last_played': 1585228577}
review:
I had been playing the graphically simplified version available at the original since 1998/1999.

It was one of the best ASCII roguelikes then and now, with all the new stuff it has become just THE game I am playing all the time...

But let me explain WHY do I not need any other games.

ADOM at Steam gives me the true feeling of constant growth, immersion, improvement, a shifting challenge system that changes constantly and is always just a bit less difficult than the impossible...

The graphics and sound are there - no less, no more. However, for an old ASCII fan like me, they create a nice atmosphere in a quite smart way as they are no less and no more than a formal aesthetic addition to the already complex, deep and well implemented game system.

What I do not like - actually what I HAAAAATE is the fact that I had to set the autosave backup file to 50 game turns, as - but for save scumming - I would have lost EVERY save file I had tried to recover... unfortunately, the game would often crash while trying to save the game. Some forum members say it is just a paranoidal behavior, but should I choose between frustration and safety, I definitely aim for the second one.

What I do like - nothing less and nothing more than all the features of the good old "Ancient Domains Of Mystery" from the late '90s, that is many locations, tons of stuff to find/get/steal/buy, many skills divided info combat marks, spell specialization levels, morrowind-like main skills, naturally changing mental, physical and miscellaneous attributes... Simply every game is completely different, full of surprises.

What everyone should like: every time you achieve something the game rewards it to you. Maybe it won't tell you that directly, but after a few (hundred/thousand...) deaths the world shouls start resembling a living organism that is constantly growing and modifying its contents...

This game is for the patient and strong of will ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198075988666', 'num_games_owned': 4004, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1498511693}
review:
Greetings fellow gamers! This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) from the Echo Army YouTube channel! Today I am bringing you a review of indie rogue-like Ancient Domains of Mystery (ADOM). ADOM was released on November 16, 2015 on Steam by a team headed by Thomas Biskup, including: Jochen Terstiege, Zeno Rogue, Krzysztof Dycha & Lucas Dieguez. 

(NOTE: This review was produced by using a key for the game that was provided by the Developer/Publisher)

Video Review:

https://youtu.be/zMMjOCStQfE

The "Too Long, Didn't Watch" Review:

STEEP learning curve. Sky high difficulty. Permadeath. TON of replayability. Short on Graphics, Audio.
3/5 but a MUST if you're a rogue-like fan. 


The "Meat & Potatoes" Review:

This has been a very difficult game for me to review. It is a solid game. I am totally getting the hang of it just fine and enjoy the genre. However, these controls are still stuck in 1994. The graphics and sound are too. But wait, there is a LOT more to this game. First, the character creation alone is immensely deep. It's really great. Oh sure, you can randomize your hero/anti-hero (yup, you can be evil. why not?), their class, race, stats. You can also choose them yourself. There are quite a few to choose from. Even better, you go through a nice little quiz (or you can randomize this too) to determine some things about your character. This makes for tons of different combos and ways to play the game. I absolutely LOVE this aspect of this game. It is straight RPG with it's abilities, talents, etc. right down to rating them by dice roll and modifier. The controls though. It takes a long time to master these controls. SO much going on all over the keyboard. I feel like some of this could be somewhat simplified, but maybe I am wrong. There really is an crazy amount of depth to this little rogue-like. Fully fleshed out tons and NPC's to be found. All in all, for your average gamer there is a lot to consume here. This is not light gaming at all. More like a Paradox game or Wargaming (a la Ageod games, etc.) there is a lot to master before being able to fully enjoy this game. As you unlock all of this though, it is very rewarding. 


Avg. gamer score would rate out at a 2/5. If you take your time with this one and learn it well, or are already a fan of real rogue-likes though, you'll find this to be a 4/5. Let's split the difference and call it 3/5. 

Happy Gaming!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026389984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1637450787}
review:
ADOM ist nicht schlecht, aber ich finde 15Euro doch schon ziemlich happig für das gebotene.

Ich persönlich hatte eigentlich wenig spaß und mehr frust.Ich mag roguelikes aber sie müssen gut gemacht sein.
Ich hab immer noch Angband auf meinem Computer (nicht die aktuelle version, die ist murks) und verglichen mit Angband
ist die Spielbalance in ADOM ziemlich schlecht. zB mein lvl 5 Troll findet eine neue Waffe aber die ist dummerweise verflucht. Das wär ja alles kein Problem wenn es entsprechende Shops mit Spruchrollen oder ähnlichem gäb.
Die gibts vielleicht irgendwo auf der Karte aber bestimmte Klassen können offenbar garnicht lesen. D.h. natürlich wiederrum das ich diese verfluchte Waffe nicht mehr loswerden kann...  game over....seufz
Da gibts bessere Spiele in diesem Genre zb TOME oder Dungeonmans ....

author: {'steamid': '76561198025281907', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1614021624}
review:
ADOM is one of the big classical roguelikes, with 20 years of development. I had played it before the kickstarted campaign for the graphical version and had enjoyed it then, and I enjoy it now even more. It just offers a lot of depth and complexety, I can really dive into the game. The world really feels alive. I also enjoyed TOME, the other great classical roguelike, but somehow I always preferred ADOM. TOME just feels more like game, with its MMO-like skills, while ADOM has the typical quirkiness and complexety of games like nethack, just with a persistent overworld and an actual story, which for me is more immersive.

I like the music, the tilesets and the many possible options, the mouse control. The loading times are pretty much non-existent, which isn't the case for TOME for example. But it still expects much the users to use the non-intuitive outdated old keyboard-shortcuts.

ADOM is hard and unforgiving. The new ingame tutorial doesn't change that. I would recommend reading the beginners guides on the wiki and the ingame manual. It's a game for people who have a lot of patience and are prepared to die early. I contrast to most rogue-lites and also many roguelikes, such as TOME, I always grow attached to my characters, so having them die is even more painful.

Tl;dr: ADOM is still one of the best games for roguelike fans who like depth and are prepared to die a lot and I am positvely surprised of the technical overhaul. But it's still nothing for people who simply want to explore a world and don't like reading manuals.

author: {'steamid': '76561198261245776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 22640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2069, 'last_played': 1675540442}
review:
I learned the basics of this game about 1,5 years ago and have since then been playing it fairly regularly. Haven't managed to finish one yet, but the great thing about this game is that it doesn't really matter that much. It's not about winning. It's about your character, that you'll be scared for, that you'll pray for, that you'll coddle up and train. You'll be angry at fate, god or just the rng, you'll laugh at stupid deaths, you'll get surges of adrenaline at the sight of that out-of-depth monster around the corner and be immensely relieved when you make it to the next staircase without being followed. Pride when you get out of a situation that looked completely desperate by using your wits, disbelief when you finally identify your stuff and see that you've been carrying around 2 (!!) amulets of life saving, anger at yourself when you lose that really promising character just because you didn't stop playing in time (when you noticed your eyes started itching and your vision got a bit blurry, but hey, you just couldn't leave the game at that point, no way...)
I'm really no game expert, I don't have any comparison to other roguelikes or any other computer games for that matter. But what I love about ADOM is that it's creating stories. Of course there is the ingame storyline, but it's also creating stories in your mind. Even in plain ascii mode, maybe especially there. Your heartrate goes up at the sight of a yellow & and you start hating the sight of any kind of f. You just have to admire (and love) the simplicity of that!
I'll admit that it takes some time to get into it and figure out all the commands, but that's only a small price to pay for everything this game has to offer!

author: {'steamid': '76561198040604465', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1645043890}

author: {'steamid': '76561198154874674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1612, 'last_played': 1629791462}
review:
This is my first ever review.  I have held out waiting for that game that provides that virtual endless adventure.  Procedurally generated dungeons, tons of equipment, many races and classes, and that little something that is missing in alot of games now, CHANCE!  From the very begining of character generation you have to adapt to what star sign you are born under, allocating certain abilities.  Do you still make that thief? Or do you change up your character strategy to better fit your star sign?  

The loot is the best though.  Do you try on that better piece of armor because you've been getting slaughtered, knowing that it could be cursed, or do you hold out for an altar or identify scroll? 

I haven't made it past level 11, and I keep coming back for more.

If you enjoy rogue-likes, then this is all you will need.  Is it pushing any enevelopes? No more then the original, but it is has more personilaization then most of the supposed cutting edge games out there.....but then again I'm a loot whore ;}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028728900', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 11752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6430, 'last_played': 1658861076}
review:
Imagine that you're a powerful warrior, raiding a dungeon. Enemies falling under your blows left and right, it doesn't even matter what type of beast you just encountered, they all go down just after one or two blows from your greatsword. You happily hoard treasures while mumbling something about having no real challenge. Then as you raid another of the countless rooms you suddenly see a ghost. Easy you think, you fought many of these and they are more annoying than anything. But then pops up another and another and another... a whole horde of ghosts. You fight but it's no use, each time you slay one, several others drain you with their touch. You turn to run but you cannot navigate the the tight corridors as well as these incorporeal beings. It is only a few seconds from there that you drop dead... drained till you collapse of old age.
That's one way an ADOM game goes.

In another you are a powerful mage, having no trouble burning, freezing or electrifying whatever you encounter. That is until you meet an enemy that commands even greater magical powers and easily no-sells whatever your arsenal of spells throws at it. What now? Drink a potion? Use a scroll? Run? Too late in any case. As the only tunnel leading away from the enemy already has an angry giant blocking it. Struggle or go out swinging?
And that's another way an ADOM game may go.

But perhaps you won't even be this lucky, you might be a looser who eats the first kobold, realizes his error once vomiting the contents of their stomach and then be unfortunate enough to meet a ghul, becoming paralyzed by its touch and choking on your own vomit.

Or you'll explode attempting to perform alchemy. Or you'll get bit by something poisonous and realize that without antidotes you're just on a timer to your death. Or you'll read a cursed book at a VERY bad time. Or you'll decide to stand on an obsidian altar while a particularly religious orc is in the same room. Or if you're really lucky you'll live long enough to die attempting to challenge a physical god.

In short ADOM is great for creating an emergent mini story of your own character's struggle (and likely death), offering a ton of freedom and depth, but also demanding patience, dedication and application of one's own brain to learn the game. Those who can handle it can expect a deep and rewarding experience as it is a much bigger achievement to beat superpowered bad guy when you're just a frail mortal who can be blown away at every wrong step.

Now if the game had more polish in terms of graphics and animation and a much friendlier UI I'd have no trouble to recommend it to pretty much everyone, if only for the hillarious ways one can meet their demise. This way, expect to invest a hour or two just to get the hang of the basics and then the rest of your life mastering the rest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075612256', 'num_games_owned': 967, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 18389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3785, 'last_played': 1518787669}
review:
ALERTE: Excellent jeux !

ADOM est une perle. Un petit bijou vidéoludique, qui ressemble pas mal à mon jeux préféré (Tales of maj'eyal, TOME,  pour ne pas le nommer). C'est un magnifique Rogue-like.

Un petit avertissement tout de même: ADOM c'est comme une voiture. Il faut apprendre à l'utiliser. Et au début c'est difficile, on pense qu'on y arrivera jamais. Puis après, comme pour le voiture, on fait 50km en pensant à ce qu'on va faire à manger, et la voiture se pilote automatiquement.
ADOM c'est pareil. Les commandes sont assez barbares. En plus il y'en a des dizaines (marcher, parler, prier, tremper des objets dans l'eau, envoyer des sors, utiliser des torches, manger, etc... etc... etc...).
Il ne faut pas se laisser intimider par ces commandes barbares. Elles deviendront à 99% automatique.

Attention encore à une chose, ADOM ne vous prend pas par la main. Je ne vous cache pas qu'au début vous ne saurez pas trop ou aller, dans quel ordre aborder les dongeons. Alors là il y'a 2 écoles:
1 l'expérimentation. A force d'essais et d'erreurs, vous aurez une bonne idée du parcours à faire (ou à éviter).
2 Le wiki d'ADOM. Il est super bien fait. Et il permet aux impatients (comme moi) de gagner un peu de temps au début.

Dernière chose, le jeu est en anglais. A ma connaissance pas de patch FR. Mais il y'a vraiment peu de texte à lire (surtout description des sors et des talents). Un niveau d'anglais très basique est largement suffisant pour profiter à 100% d'ADOM.

Bon voilà, c'était les côté "négatifs" du titre. Maintenant pour le reste.... Ben c'est que du positif.
Déja la durée de vie... A 30h de jeux, j'en suis au début du jeux (je commence à survivre régulièrement jusqu'à la ville des nains). Et je prends un immense plaisir à découvrir les subtilité du jeux.
Les différentes classes sont intéressantes, et il y'en à vraiment bcp.

En plus n'étant pas du tout un habitué des jeux de rôle à l'ancienne, je découvre aussi le système d'alignement (loyal, neutre, chaotique), ainsi que le système d'objets bennis/maudits/non-maudits.
C'est très intéressant.

Franchement ADOM c'est comme TOME. On y pense toute la journée, et on se jette dessus dès qu'on rentre à la maison.
Très peu de jeux m'ont fait cet effet dans ma vie.
En parlant de TOME, il y'a une différence notable avec ADOM. La gestion de l'inventaire. Dans ADOM, l'inventaire n'est pas illimité. Et il dépend de la force du personnage. Il y'a aussi la gestion (basique) de la faim.
Même si cette gestion de la faim est problématique dans les premières heures du jeux, une fois les bases assimilées, ce n'est plus un problème.

Le nombre d'ennemis est très varié pour le moment (je suis au "début" du jeux). Et j'en ai rencontré des dizaines de différents. Humanoïdes, bêtes, insectes, dragons, démons et autres machins fantastiques font parties du zoo ADOM,
Le nombre d'objets est aussi impressionants. Batons, haches, épées, dagues, massues, arcs, fouets, etc... etc... etc... 
A ce sujet un petit regret. Notre équipement n'est pas toujours représenté sur notre perso. Certains objet le sont, d'autres non... 


Bon, j'ai assez perdu de temps. Je repars dans affronter les dongeons obscurs d'ADOM ! (en mode de création de charactère aléatoire, car ça me permet de découvrir pas mal de classes/combinaisons sympa).

author: {'steamid': '76561198048841878', 'num_games_owned': 22, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1010, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1010, 'last_played': 1449278198}
review: Cannot recommend highly enough. The perfect mix of linear and non-linear gameplay and storyline. Been playing for about 15 years and the graphics definitely makes a difference.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993666313', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 39627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 920, 'last_played': 1710515474}
review:
This is the top banana for Rogue-like games. I've probably put more hours on this game than any other in my life. The replayability is phenomenal, the interface is solid (if bulging with commands), the gameplay is challenging and rewarding on multiple levels consistently.

If you don't like this kind of game, no loss, but there are far more people who will fail to give the game even though they might love it.

WORTH IT!

author: {'steamid': '76561198040193963', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3257, 'last_played': 1514439537}
review:
So after 52 hours of play I'm finally writing a review, and then giving up and moving on to something else.  There is a small list of reasons, but it comes down to the fact that the game just isn't much fun.  Perhaps that's a symptom of being 'roguelike', perhaps not.  

Pros
- easy to get started, play a while and then stop.  ei no load times, no startup ads to watch, no fancy graphic splash screen

Cons
-  Vast majority of games end in you dying.  Since this is permadeath all the time invested is lost.  Period.
- Most of the things that kill young characters (hunger, traps you can't detect on doors you must go through), poisons you can't cure, monsters that one-hit-kill and who are also faster than you are) you have no possibility of avoiding.  The game doesn't attempt to balance things, it mostly just rolls RNG's and eventually you die.
 - Your character rarely knows anything about the equipment/potion/buffs.  You could die with a potion of healing in your possession and have no possibility of finding out.
 - Even if you choose a class that allows you to see cursed/uncursed status, the game has undetectable cursed items to saddle your character with usless sh*t.
 - Game does a very poor job at allowing balanced characters.
 - Too many things completely invulnerable to player attacks/spells, and very little chance to determine what could be effective against them before you die.
 - If you need something (food particularly, healing, a decent weapon, an identify scroll) you will never find it.  If you don't need it, the stuff drops like rain.  And of course this lack is going to kill you.

Pretty much the game is more of a fancy RNG, rather that someting that is fun.   Some will find this fun, most people will find it frustrating and unrewarding.  And the fact that it kills you repeatedly without any possibilty of not dying makes it more fruitless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080640211', 'num_games_owned': 33, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1571232514}
review:
I have played ADOM more than any other game: on and off over the span of 18 (!) years.

The game's complex dynamics, rich world and variety keep me coming back. There is something unexplicably charming about this game, and it never stops being exciting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103594180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1448624291}
review: my old love

author: {'steamid': '76561198037431554', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 3494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2329, 'last_played': 1449058458}
review:
Мнение об этой игре у меня скачет с тех пор, как я начал ПЫТАТЬСЯ ее пройти - то она мне нравится, то начинает невероятно бесить. Это, наверное, самый ебанутый и беспощадный рогалик из всех, что я видел. 

Игра напоминает минное поле, по которому игрока пускают гулять без миноискателя. Умереть тут можно практически от чего угодно - враги не являются непосредственно главной проблемой. Вполне можно быть убитым... дверью, которую вы пытаетесь выбить, потому что у вас нету нужного (именно нужного) ключа или заклинания, взламывающего замки. И если в некоторых случаях опасностей можно избежать благодаря осторожности и внимательности, то иногда все совершенно выходит из-под контроля. Вы можете наступить в ловушку с ядом, который будет травить персонажа до тех пор, пока тот не испустит последний вздох. Один из моих персонажей страдал от отравления больше 500+ ходов, пытаясь перебить эффект яда навыком "первая помощь", использовав при этом 2 раза помощь своего бога для восстановления здоровья. Но все было тщетно. Хорошо, если есть средство, которым можно снять отравление, но порой такие проблемы возникают в самом начале, когда под рукой обычно ничего нету.

Еще один неприятный момент - это местные тайлы. Это, пожалуй, ЕДИНСТВЕННЫЙ роуглайк, в котором у меня появилось желание переключиться в ASCII-режим. Местный визуальный стиль очень яркий, "пряничный" и, на мой взгляд, не соответствует игровой атмосфере. Но это, конечно, дело вкуса - проблема здесь в другом. Сами тайлы очень неточные. Довольно часто описание монстра или чего-то еще не соответствует его изображению. Наткнувшись на бородатого гиганта-качка, не удивляйтесь, если в тексте будет сказано, что это женщина. Тоже самое с описанием игрового персонажа - у него могут быть голубые глаза и рыжие волосы на бумаге, а на деле и то, и другое коричневого цвета. Я не думаю, что человеку, отвечающему за создание тайлсета, было бы сложно сделать несколько тайлов под каждую комбинацию волос/глаз, так что причина их отсутствия вводит меня в небольшой ступор.

Еще хуже дела обстоят с местными зонами. По описанию они очень разнообразные, конечно. Тут у нас и пещеры, и различные подземелья, крипты, даже подземный лес есть. Но на самом деле, все, что находится под землей - это серые кирпичные коридоры. Неужели так сложно ХОТЯ БЫ просто использовать другие цвета в разных данженах? Это уже было бы лучше чем то, что мы имеем на данный момент. Сильно был удивлен, увидев другой "лейаут" в пирамиде, выполненной в египетском стиле.

С управлением тут тоже не все гладко. Куча неудобных хоткеев, которые вам придется запоминать и использовать всю дорогу. И ладно, если это одна буква, так нет - бывает и такое, что надо нажать что-то вроде "w?" (это, кстати, команда для авто-исследования местности - максимальное "удобство", ага). Некоторые команды можно было запросто сгруппировать на одну кнопку. Например, закрытие/открытие дверей. Но нет. Складывается такое впечатление, что в подобном садистском подходе к управлению был замысел создателя. АДОМ, на минутку, делается еще с 94 года. Очень грустно, что за это время ничего не было предпринято в данном направлении.

В общем и целом, игра явно не рассчитана на новичков жанра. Если вы как раз такой, но хотите приобщиться - начинайте лучше с чего попроще: Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup или Tales of Maj'Eyal. Последний даже есть в стиме, и он очень нуб-френдли. Для тех, кто все-таки решил взяться за АДОМ, знайте - вас ждет боль и порой невыносимая фрустрация, но вместе с этим лихие приключения, веселые проигрыши (да, такое тоже бывает) и НЕВЕРОЯТНАЯ глубина геймплея. 

А я надеюсь, что став получать хоть какие-то копейки за свой труд, Бискуп всерьез займется банальным удобством и, конечно, запряжет человека, отвечающего за визуальную часть, чтобы тот хоть что-то уже сделал с местным убогим тайлсетом. 

Я хочу поставить здесь нейтральную оценку, но ее нет, поэтому я остановлюсь на негативной.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067228862', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 22056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1694628738}
review:
ADOM is very much a old school style rougue-like. You can tell because even the tutorial doesn't hold much back, instead providing simple instructions. Hell, even the second monster in the tutorial can completely destroy you if you don't play your cards right.

If you're not into the hardcore first-dungeon-you-enter-is-full-of-blinding-traps-and-pit-deal-with-it-punk style dungeon crawler then don't bother with ADOM. If you want to get into rougue-likes then I'd recomend a free dungeon crawler like Stone Soup's Crawl or a more jokesy game like Dungeons of Dreadmore. If you take to to those then congradulations! You might have what it takes to handle ADOM.

Either way, ADOM is a great delve into a world of fantasy, fighting, drunken fools and a never ending stream of death.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997731594', 'num_games_owned': 625, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 14521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3571, 'last_played': 1561739594}
review:
First things first: Be prepared! ADOM is a demanding and difficult game with permadeath coming at you around every corner. Several secret handshakes that you just got to learn about the hard way. And it's not even really fair at all times. Also you will be consulting a wiki often.

However,

The sense of reward in this game is unparalleled. When you kill that Ancient Chaos Wyrm with one tremendous blow from your Vanquisher, getting revenge for those five other promising characters who died to him. Or when you finally get that one race/class/sign combo running properly that you've been trying for ages. 

There is a lot of death in this game no doubt, but the huge variety you can have with character creation added to the general randomness of the game makes every adventure significantly different. The replay value of this game is immense. Dying means that you get to try something new once again!

As you start out, you might be spending as much time reading a wiki as you are playing. That's okay, there are no real spoilers in this game. Knowing everything beforehand does not really affect your experience in any negative way. And there is a fun sense of mystique; even after years of play you'll be learning new things.

The steam edition packs this classic of a game in a neat and functional package. Definitely worth the price when it comes to amount of gameplay. Also worth it for the veterans. Though if you are very particular to ascii graphics (though you can play this version in ascii aswell), you might not find enough new features as of yet.

Definitely one of the better games ever made!

author: {'steamid': '76561197976523877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 4050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3699, 'last_played': 1534639467}

author: {'steamid': '76561198019734235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 3706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1464, 'last_played': 1592274070}
review:
J'adore les roguelikes, j'adore le hasard, j'adore apprendre de mes erreurs, ce jeu propose tout ça. Je suis un casu qui joue plutôt à la souris avec seulement quelques raccourcis clavier mais d'après les retours d'autres joueurs les contrôles sont assez compliqués si vous voulez jouer au clavier.

Les graphismes sont soignés et vous pouvez choisir de jouer en ascii. Chaque personnage a son histoire, la création du dit personnage est assez varié, avec un "signe" qui est choisis au hasard, une race et une classe qui vous feront une façon de jouer différente suivant ces paramètres.

Il y a quelque bugs, mais les devs ont l'air de bosser dur pour régler ces problèmes. J'ai toujours rêvé de jouer à du jeu de rôle papier, avec des "skills check" et ce genre de choses, ce jeu propose cette expérience, mais en solo.

9/10 Je veux bien mourir à nouveau écraser par une porte ou étouffer dans mon vomis :D

J'ai enfin réussis ma première quête au bout de 20 heures, saloperie de chiot...

author: {'steamid': '76561198005815710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1957, 'last_played': 1570648570}

author: {'steamid': '76561198060275835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 8965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1690354636}
review:
I posted a review within hours of release. For some reason it isn't on here, so I'm trying again.

This game is to roguelikes what Baldur's Gate is to CRPGs. After playing for over ten years, I can safely say that this is one of the best games I've ever played. The reason for this is it's strict dedication to its core mechanic -- you, dying.

One of the best descriptions I've ever heard of game mechanics was concerning Dark Souls, in that (paraphrased) "this is a game that is fair to the player -- always FAIR -- and the difficulty does not surprise you if you pay attention."

ADOM is like this. Sort of. Instead of there being ways to see what's ahead and then killing you a la Dark Souls, ADOM's core mechanic isn't actually dying. That's the means to teaching you. You will suffer legitimate losses of equipment, stats, companions, or everything you have in a gripping, slow or numbing, painless death. Then, you are expected - required - to learn from that experience in your next character.

This shows in everything that the game does. RPG classes in 99% of RPGs are meaningless. In ADOM, some are similar to eachother, but every class has at least one unique quality to them that will change the entirety of the game. Races are the same, with each having a sort of opposite, such as the Mist Elves and Trolls; M.Elves have unstoppable magical capabilities and dodging, but Trolls have towering health WITH regeneration (the MOST coveted skill in the game) and can massacre just about anything (can I just say Troll weaponsmith w/sword of sharpness? Yes, I CAN say that!) (... right before I died).

I've been playing off and on, but the adventures have been memorable. I was introduced to the game by scumming and knew too little to understand that this was NOT as the game was designed. Once I found the ADOM Guidebook online, I started playing rogue (with a little experimentation). My first winning playthrough was a Human Fighter, Phaeton; he ran into a vault of Greater Molochs. It took me HOURS to kill just one, but once I did, my level rocketed and I was able to kill each one easier until my 100 Courage could take on 2-3 at a time, hitting lvl50 in no time. The Balors at the end nearly killed me, but I desperately used a scroll of familiar summoning and hit the jackpot -- a Greater Flame Elemental killed literally everything but me on the entire floor. I just followed it around and picked through the carnage. My second playthrough was a Wizard, Gafgarion, that died in the duel with Nuurag-Vaarn. When 1.2.0 was released, I dove in head first with a LOT of attempts, but finally got a High Elven Paladin, Matthias, and for the first time I got Justifier. For those who don't know, this may be one of the best non-minmax occurrences in the game. I edited my sprite to epic proportions, turning Justifier into the Master Sword from Zelda, and mopped through every dungeon. You think such imbalance isn't fun after while... until your save loads a JSON error and corrupts, thereby losing everything.

Now that I'm done rambling, here's what makes this Steam version special. You can remove all of what I just talked about. However, that's not such a bad thing. What the Steam release signifies is a willingness to accept new players. The depth and complexity of content in ADOM is such that I probably haven't seen half of it. And it's probably only going to get bigger. Therefore, it makes sense to have ways to let players explore it. There's still tons wrong with it, as one review brought up the online-only functionality. This doesn't really bother me. Unless he's travelling in the bush (doubtful), turn on hotspot on your phone for 5 mins. The act of getting ADOM on Steam in a saleable format was probably a Herculean task, and so I expect errors. Any aspersions against customer sales disrespect are fallacious and made by people who have clearly never perused the forums or seen comments made by Thomas Biskup. Since Morrowind modding, I have never seen such a dedicated community of collaborative effort.

It has never been a better age to get into roguelikes, and this game is one of the best. If you've been poisoned against rogues by the more recent entries in the genre, give a classic a try and see what made them great to begin with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040856904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 18863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4216, 'last_played': 1696397626}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042138166', 'num_games_owned': 634, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1511816320}
review: Can finally select the "Skilled" talent without crashing the game. All praise The Creator!

author: {'steamid': '76561198061391580', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 13684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6330, 'last_played': 1598290979}
review:
It feels good to buy the game and support The Creator even though I've never sent a postcard. (Shame on me.) 

I have no idea of the changes made since I last played the game 3 years ago, the extra dungeons on the overworld is awesome, especially the noob dungeon at the beginning. This may have been present in version before Steam but I don't mean to digress.

The tileset is fantastic, however it can be a bit difficult to spot items on the ground, this is offset by the minimap.

I'm really happy with the changes implemented that were promised; the exploration mode and option to turn of corruption effects were highly anticipated in my younger years however as my skill has grown I have yet to even use them.

The new classes are absolutely fantastic, well thought out and are much more fun to replay than say... a farmer or a merchant.

The one thing I have a beef with is the hand animations, when playing a drakeling or an orc, why do they have white skinned hands?

A postcard from Texas will be headed your way soon Thomas!

author: {'steamid': '76561198107939318', 'num_games_owned': 810, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 18244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5501, 'last_played': 1533106980}
review: I've been playing ADOM since 1994.  It is a traditional roguelike, and one of the very best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198125919667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 85558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 8, 'playtime_at_review': 424, 'last_played': 1711254427}

author: {'steamid': '76561198017657330', 'num_games_owned': 2154, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 28023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1688222648}
review:
While this game may have a steep learning curve to figure out all the details, the general play is a lot of fun. The best part to me, is that the world gets harder with your level.
If you have been looking for a challenging rogue-like, this is the one you should get. While my hours are low, I used to play the free version back in the early 2000's, when it was only ascii. It has only improved with time, and remains the number one game if I want a challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972785116', 'num_games_owned': 552, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1629978098}
review:
I finally played the game again and was now able to recommend it as it seems to have gone through many updates since I played it last. The game does still wear the skin suit of its old self, and while it can be fully mouse controlled, there are gaps in the seams where the flesh of the old keyboard driven game pokes through.

It's a nice update to the classic version of this game, but beware! This game is an abyss of such depth which you'll be hard pressed to find anywhere else (perhaps Dwarf Fortress). If you dive in, you will either scramble to get out as fast as possible, or perhaps never leave...

author: {'steamid': '76561198169547970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 973, 'last_played': 1448282685}
review:
EDIT: by now, the feature I disliked the most has been removed so you can play the game offline. while I still don't think the differences between the free and paid version are very substantial, it is not an inferior version of the game anymore. my advice: play for free and get the paid release if you like it to support this old, complex and fun roguelike.

old review below:
------------

ADOM itself is a great game but the graphical version is still very buggy. also, the game has a free version which has almost all the features of the paid one (minus some minor stuff like crowd mode or challenge of the week) while not having the annoying always-online requirement. seriously, it's a single player game. it should allow me to play when I'm offline.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997213984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 21642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 6, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1711737194}
review:
'You find yourself in the bowels of a dank dungeon, your robes burned to ashes, bleeding from your wounds.  The dread beast that inflicted the wounds upon you lies smoldering before you, the last of your power expended upon its ruin.  Through the doorway that led you to this chamber, you hear a thunderous 'HARUMPH'.  This can only mean ruin.  You frantically search your belongings, desperate for salvation.  You pray to your God, but the ground quakes at your request, a stern denial from your patron deity.  A tremendous stomping grows nearer, and you fear that your time is short.  Sweat pouring down your bleeding face, you find a Wand of Digging in your pack, intact but depleted of charges, alongside your Wand of Door Creation.  Like a man gone mad, you plunge the Wand of Digging into your only potion of Booze, and cry out when the wand glows once more.  You fire it behind you, creating a vast tunnel wherein you dash for safety.  You zap your Wand of Door creation behind you, and with your faintly regained power Magically Lock the summoned door.  You run down your new corridor, seeking escape, only to find another dead end.  The impossibly heavy steps of the impending creature grow close now, as you huddle in the corner of your shelter.  The steps cease, you hold your breath in sheer terror, silently attempting to gather yourself in meditation and regain power.  An explosion of splinters erupts from the other side of your corridor, and the many eyed horror that approaches from the gloom freezes you in your place.  You think of Terinyo as the horror steps toward you, you think of the home you left behind.  Your fear gives way to darkness, the darkness to silence; Ancardia's greatest hope extinguished like a torch in the rain.'

You die.  You survive.  You learn. ADOM is a game that offers you a canvas upon which to design your own adventure.  Are you a hero?  A villain?  Do you aspire to seal the forces of Chaos away, or reign over it a mad God for eternity?  Are you a simple farmer, far from home?  A gambler, seeking the highest stakes casino in all the world?  Call it a roguelike, call it a fantasy role playing sandbox, call it a sadistic RNG exercise, ADOM is all that and far more.  No experience is perfect, games crash, characters are lost.  ADOM is mysterious, and you may puzzle at the Scroll of Dark Predictions in your inventory, or the Tract of Chaos you see on the ground.  You may wander to the Tower of Eternal Flames, and enter without caution.  You die.  You survive.  You learn.  ADOM is a game of mystery, a game of skill, a game of chance.  Distinct from its peers, beloved by its fanbase, and better than ever here on Steam.  Don't fear the learning curve, if you've whiled away hours exploring Morrowind, Baldur's Gate, Fallout, this game may be the gateway to a genre you've never given a thought to before, as it was for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028955417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1620461622}

author: {'steamid': '76561198026488684', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1468553987}
review:
First off, I'm not a fanboy.  This is the first time I've played ADOM, but not the first roguelike I've played.  I've heard about ADOM for a long time but never played it.  I heard it was coming to Steam, so I thought I would give it a try.  So far, it seems very good.  There are a lot of options, things like your character's backstory are very well done.  I have to say, I really enjoy the tileset.  To me it's nicer than Tome's tileset.  Tome's tileset is almost too detailed to sit well with a roguelike, it kind of gets into the "uncanny valley" territory.  ADOM's tileset is HD, yet stylistically better.  The details are smooth and well done, but it avoids the mistake of trying to put too much detail into a tile.

If you like games like Caves of Qud, Tome, or roguelikes in general, this is a great game and you will enjoy it.  The devs seem very eager to improve the game and listen to their community.

The only complaint I have is there are a lot of strange key combinations that maybe would be better off in a menu (like if you push esc).  It's not bad by any means, but the UI could use a bit of streamlining.  Key combinations (like CTRL+nm) are just really archaic and not really acceptable in this day and age.  Other than that minor complaint, it's a damn fun game and I recommend it to roguelike fans.

review: I have played roguelikes since pre-nethack days of Rogue. I've always enjoyed them, but haven't found myself as hooked on them as I used to be, until now. ADOM was great when it came out, but I think it's even better here on steam. I'm loving this game, and highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002863764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1277, 'last_played': 1602253572}
review:
Death by minotaur attack. Check.
Death by fire. Check.
Death by starvation. Check.
Death by drowning. Check.
Death by poisoning. Check.
Death by trap. Check.
Death by back-firing of magic. Check.
Death by sickness or fever. Check.
Death from overexertion. Check.
Death by old age. Check.
Death by piranha attack. Check.
Death by exploding door. Check.
Death by falling (including from stairs). Check.
Death by electrocution. Check.
Death by explosion. Check.
Death by acid. Check.
Death by blasphemy. Check.
Death by eating weird shit. Check.
Death by carrying too much shit. Check.
Death by READING A GODDAMN SPELLBOOK. Check.
Death by chemical experiment. Why not? Check.

Every new game is a learning experience, how will you die this time?

I think this sums up my years-long experience with this game. Highly recommended if you love details.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971602025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1609787783}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001505748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 9482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 723, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1712439104}
review:
The early game in ADOM constantly asks you to make risk vs reward decisions. Whether to stand and fight, or run away and heal. Whether to kick down a door and risk activating a trap, or come back later with a key. Whether to risk delving one level deeper, or travel to a safer location. Making the wrong call will often lead to an early death, but negotiate these issues and your character will be set up for the challenges that follow.

For newcomers to the game, I advise choosing a stong melee character (e.g. an orc fighter), and start in the tutorial dungeon to get used to the basics of moving around and hitting things with swords. This is what you'll be doing for the majority of the time, regardless of class. You can then let the complexities of the other mechanics seep in over time.

I used to play a lot of the ASCII version, but not so much recently. I'm already impressed with the new graphical tileset and other features which are in this version, and the game underneath is still the exciting combination of exploration and danger it always was.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166133679', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1814, 'last_played': 1702736350}
review:
Finally steam release. 

Been playing it like for a few last years on a regular intervals of a 3-4 months, though version 1.1.1b4. Now gotta readapt to this new version, especially vile ghosts, that in truth aren't exactly my kind of fun feature, more like annoying and little bit too strong for most characters, though it may be that I just like playing rather weak combinations so idk just right now. 
There are some things that shouldnt make it to steam release, like black screen on settings (just a screen that you have to push any key and it goes where it should be, but still...), or crash(v62 gave no change) when no focus on ADOM window(thats definitely to fix fast) or the way stats are displayed isn't not saving(I like it the classic way).

Can't really be better, though still 1.1.1 with its 'features' feels nicer, but that also can be my personal taste or it can also be, that I'm still not 100% convinced on this better(newer) version; gonna play till a few wins at least.

For those who come here for a casual game: be warned;
You got to have some time and patience to get this game right even with improved guidebook.
You gonna die and die hard, die every minute, die inside, die of anger and frustration.
Till you win, and then you can only improve.

If you like games pretty hardcore, or you think that u got what is take to win this game, that play it, but remember: dying of broken leg that's bleeding isn't all the reason to make a negative review.

I just cannot leave a negative one, especially, as I've been playing it for like 5 years or more though its older version.
It's still the same game, just with a few more features.

Cheers

author: {'steamid': '76561198032900102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 4353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2072, 'last_played': 1491831487}
review: I'm so happy ADOM is on Steam with nice graphics and sound effects! It's a great roguelike with many quests, large world map with many types of dungeons and  large variety of classes and races. There is a lot of small details that make your character seem like a real person - aging is very amusing, you lose appearance points and strength but gain wisdom :) Your moral or immoral actions directly affect how the enviornment reacts to you (certain quests unavailable, monsters hostile). Finding desired loot is difficult, thus good items are more meaningful. I absolutely love the magic system (as opposed to other roguelikes such as Stone Soup) - you learn spells through books which you don't have to carry around (you cast them from your memory for a limited number of times e.g. 700- which can be increased with other books), the spells get better as you use them. Finally the game has a lot of secrets :) I highly recommend purchasing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960950284', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 21388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1628912993}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030719001', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1903, 'last_played': 1530824487}
review: All I can say is: this is one of the literally two games I found myself buying outside a 75% sale. Yeah, I know: I'm a thrifty beggar. Still, having known ADOM since I don't know how long ago, I wasn't going to 'insta-buy' it until I read some user complaints. The complaints were all trivial, but the way Thomas Biskup, the game's creator, answered them showed a dev attitude I felt compelled to support. Seriously, in this day and age, a guy that civil (and not at all corporate-customer-relations-like civil, mind you) deserves a bit of a bonus! :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198051717580', 'num_games_owned': 988, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 13815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6994, 'last_played': 1704556591}

author: {'steamid': '76561198012276748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 14059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1702057497}
review:
Why are you reading reviews? Why have you not bought this already? Why am I subtracting from my own ADoM time to write this?

P.S. Hurthling necromancers will always win. They can cook corpses, animate corpses, and animate [i]cooked[/i] corpses. That means that they will make your dinner attack you. Have you ever been attacked by an undead foie gras? And that foie gras ghul can paralyze you before killing you. What a way to go. Watching helplessly in abject horror as a goose that had been force-fed grain for several months kills you to reclaim its bloated liver.

P.P.S. When you go to pay for stuff, you actually type in "pay" to pay for the first item -- that always amused me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026782701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 8974, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1956, 'last_played': 1552694160}
review:
For starters, I'd like to menstion I have 15 years and god-knows-how-many-hours total in all the different iterations of ADoM, so my Steam time definitely isnt accurate.

Ahh, ADoM. Its what most roguelikes aspire to be. Its a *Hack, as opposed to ToME, which is an *Angband. So you can't really say one is "better" than the other because they are very different mechanics. Every Roguelike fan has their preference, over *angbands or *hacks. Mine is ADoM and UnNetHack/SLASH'EM. (and if you don't understand the previous sentences but claim to like "Roguelikes" - you actually have no idea what a roguelike is whatsoever).

 ADoM is the grandchild of Rogue, and the great granddaddy of all those f'n games out there that seem to think "roguelike" means "permadeath with random generation". Nope. THIS is what a godd*** roguelike is. If you like the genre, you probably already have a copy, one of the free ones. Why buy it on Steam when you can get Version 60 for free? To support Thomas and his team to keep adding to it, cleaning up bugs, making more options. I did. Its totally worth it for any die hard fan. It has full tiles, done really well. But it also has the capability for the old school ASCII that was all that existed until just a couple years ago. Its deep, its awesome, its everything a Roguelike should be. It and a few others pretty much defined the genre in the early 90s. If you dont have a copy, you have no right saying youre into Roguelikes. Get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052593402', 'num_games_owned': 659, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 2022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 977, 'last_played': 1509425206}
review:
11 hours in and I have died many more times than I care to remember. Most recently was after I completed the first quest for the first time. I thought, "Oh boy! I can finally begin the adventure!" I got a wand and a spellbook as a reward and thought, "I'll take the time to study this while safe in town! Finally a spell to add to my arsenal!"

I read the book and wound up by a lake, confused. Since I had no means to battle confusion, I waited until my character inadvertently drowned herself while the heartless peasants looked on, presumably enjoying the spectacle.

Would drown after reading a gift I got for being a hero again.
10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198008423537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 1171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1624528952}
review:
I can't recommend this game! Yes there are tiles set but that's about it, for the price! Story mode??? You can only have one save file and, yes if you die, you can restaure your game. So is you are in a dungeon and you are caught in a hard situation, then even your save file won't help you! Plus the fact that in some dungeon like a cave and, after having cleared the level, you go down and back up, the level you just did is gone and in its place, a new one with monsters that often are harder then when you got through. 

Also, why are the level so simple; they are just a narrow rectangle. Not very interesting to explore! Now about the controls: Keyboard control and not very logical. Why are there not mouse options for every thing you could do. Same for inventory: to sell something, you have to go to your inventory, choose backpack, scroll down to the item, drop it and then, the merchant makes you an offer which you say Y or N. Then you have to go back to your inventory and repeat the above to sell another item. Now on a 27 inche monitor, trying to find what you are suppose to type in is a challenge! Just like finding how to play the game in story mode, well search your screen for that little interrogation point way at the very button of the screen when the main box is two thirds up. And you will do a lot os screen search in this game! 

I have tried this game but I have gone back to Tales of Maj'Eyal!

author: {'steamid': '76561198117100356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 14736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 569, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1712278240}
review:
I completed the postcard quest 15 years ago before ADOM 1.0 -- and I still play this game. It feels silly to write a review for ADOM because it's almost like writing a review for a classic novel. Buy it to support one of the greatest computer games made to date. With the nice graphics it's actually a lot easier to get into now, so it's worth the money from that perspective (back in the day it took me 20 minutes to figure out the controls. The graphical overlay makes it much easier to get into the game)

And it's written in *C*. How hardcore is that?

author: {'steamid': '76561197972711573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 7634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1234, 'last_played': 1659844085}
review: I first played Adom back when it first came out in the mid 90's and its still my favorite roguelike today. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001194174', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1447791121}
review:
Though there is a great level of complexity and depth to this game, and replayability, a lot of the game is based highly around text.  The learning curve requires a lot of reading, and even character creation requires a lot of reading.   Everything you do requires reading basically.  The combat system is pretty basic and simple, despite a proclaimed deep tactical system in the description.  The controls are overly complex to the point of being unnecessarily complex and having different unique key strokes and key combinations for everything you can do, to the point where you barely remember how to navigate your inventory.

I could see this game being enriching and deep if you are into a lot of reading, a big learning curve, using primarily keyboard commands for everything, and a lot of figuring everything out for yourself or reading tons of help menus.  It's not that I am opposed to text-based RPGs, it is just not what was advertised, and I was expecting a lot more action-packed adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055976195', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 59318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1754, 'last_played': 1687188343}
review: I've played the game for years and I was glad for the opportunity to help support a game that I love.  The added features aren't that big of a deal on top of the public free release IMO.  The one plus in my book is that you can play the game in story mode where you can save and restore whereas on the free release it's a hassle to savescum. The thousands of hours I've played outside of steam speak volumes for how fun the game is.  I still haven't beaten it, but I still love playing it.  I've gotten down to the final temple before the Chaos gate, but I keep dying to stuff I had no idea would just destroy my characters despite having what I thought were godlike stats (40ish on average). It's a blast, but the learning curve is pretty steep.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985727392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1515299304}
review:
ADOM was the defining game of my childhood. Biskup's little project established the framework for so many of my preferences in gaming and game design for years to come. While my tastes have since drifted, there was an *immense* and overwhelming feeling of nostalgia opening up this remastering for the first time. My hand still intuitively knew all of the hundred-odd keybindings necessary to really play the game effectively. This, I knew immediately, was something that I was going to rack up an embarrassing number of hours on.

Or, I would, at least, if it were more stable. An hours worth of attempts at play lost me several characters due to crashes. That part is definitely new. While I think everyone should give ADOM a spin, I recommend giving it a little while after launch to sort out its issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080166114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 111595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2885, 'last_played': 1711214137}

author: {'steamid': '76561197975611233', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1982, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1006, 'last_played': 1690547767}
review: This is probably the only rogue game that I enjoy playing eventhough I have never managed to finish a dungeon before I die. One thing that I would like the developer to fix is that the game freezes when I quit the game. Sometimes I had to restart my computer in order to quit the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005733306', 'num_games_owned': 468, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 3054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1079, 'last_played': 1604675845}
review:
Been happily following this game and I'm so glad to see it finally reach to Steam. Coming from someone who's been playing Nethack and Roguelikes since I've started PC gaming, this game is a wonderful treasure. I've known friends to lose entire summers to this game back in 1998/1999 and so many more hours poring over notebook pages of stats and abilities and trying to come up with THE BEST character combination.

Pros:
+GUI. No more ASCII. If you come from the old-school, you remember how much time was taken up by trying to remember every monster in the ASCII alphabet. Be all the "purist" you want but not everyone likes remembering each monster type and name by a symbol and color.
+Characters and monster sprites change according to what's equipped. Sure! Leave that suit of Chainmail on the floor for that Goblin to pick up...see what happens...
+A significantly more detailed FAQ and instruction booklet and questionnaire. Praise be to Kormak! 
+Tutorial added. Never played a roguelike in your life? TOO BAD! We'll explain it to you!

Cons:
--Oh the crashes. The crashes. The CRASHES. Somewhere in this game's code is a terrible memory leak that causes the game to go from running to utterly unstable at random and there is something punch-a-baby-rabbit-to-death infuriating at losing 2-3 hours work without a Save and Resume OR saving, game crashes mid-save and coming back to find your savefile and your backup file gone. Hope the devs fix this at some point.

Review is a WIP. But so far...I'm satisfied with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132975293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 23000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1775, 'last_played': 1682865628}
review: So far I've seen complaints about three things: the graphics, the UI and the price. As far as graphics are concerned, it comes down to a matter of personal taste. I happen to love them, but if you don't, you can always play in ASCII mode. Either way, don't let the graphics deter you from playing this game. It's so much deeper than that. There's a reason why this game is still being played 20 years after it's release. It has nothing to do with graphics. The UI is totally fine, and has seen major improvement over the recent months. Yes, there are a lot of commands to remember, but again that just speaks to the depth of the game. The learning curve of this game is steep, but rewarding and totally worth it. There's a free version of the game on the ADOM website if you're on the fence or you can't fork out the money for it. Go try it out. You'll love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968311616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 5383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5236, 'last_played': 1562477773}
review:
I will start with the con (just one) in this game: The learning curve / keybindings are tough on this. You need to be patient and learn/ list lots of commands on the keyboard.


I first played ADOM around 2003-2004. We had a crappy computer which couldn't handle many games at all, but my brother had ADOM on it. I tested it and was instantly hooked: So much to explore, so hard! Only one life? The merciless roguelike system where the game is permanently over when you die made me curious.

The added graphics are quite nice addition to the game and I imagine it's easier for new players to get into the game. I use only the keyboard controls for the game, as it is much faster (and I've played it for years so it comes natural). I recommend tackling the keyboard commands if you want faster gameplay.

There are so many ways you can be good (or bad) at this game. The game has been around for decades so it is well-balanced, but also still very challenging. I haven't still finished this game without "cheating", that is what was known as save scumming, where you copy the save file in case you die and continue game from there. I died just once to a stupid mistake which I don't remember anymore, but it still annoys me, even after multiple years. I'm fully determined to finish ADOM in the near future...
In a nutshell, the reasons I enjoy playing ADOM:
- Challenging enough
- Addictive - you'll probably end up screaming like a maniac for dying, swear you had enough ADOM for a week, only to find yourself trying a new character 10 minutes later
- Variable - Dozens, if not hundreds of ways to play the game (race, class combinations + different endings, quests to pursue, places to visit)
- Unpredictable - You might get mighty lucky early in the game, or really unlucky (dying to a random stone block trap early on for example), or both at the same, or neither. Just like life!
- Bang for your buck - If you end up liking this game, you will probably enjoy it for years - I estimate that I have played more than 1000 hours pre-steam

If you decide to buy the game: Don't totally spoil yourself reading guides beforehand - just go to places, explore them and read late-game guides only if you get stuck to some place. Trust me, you will enjoy the exploration more on your own.
