author: {'steamid': '76561198001385795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1509382979}
review: ADOM is one of the best (if not the best) roguelikes out there. It is the classic hardcore RPG style with stupendous amounts of depth. Strangely enough, getting far in ADOM is one of the most rewarding gaming experiences available presently due to the sheer effort it takes to get that far, just look at the other reviews, this is NOT and easy game. This is likely one of the hardest games on steam, so if you just want a challenge, I challenge you to even complete this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031107654', 'num_games_owned': 2722, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1669495792}
review:
"I am the Troll Mindcrafter. I have the Big Stick. I will blow your mind with it"

I played this game for free since 1996, and it's amazing. So I bought it without second thoughts. The new graphic options are good, but I think that after I will complete F4 - I will return to that perfect world of ASCII.
The game is rogue-like RPG with permanent death of your character. But it's very deep for that kind of game and very free in the possibilities. It can be called something like "one-man-skyrim", because you can actually play as you want - Race and Class is only the basic of your character, than came gods, potions, corpse-eating, powers of Chaos and many more things, so you can find your orc barbarian trying to learn the Wish spell from the book.
And he actually can do this.

10/10 fried ancient dragons.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995127638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1677029612}
review:
I had to think hard about whether or not I wanted to recommend this game or not. Its one of those "two-and-a-half to three stars' moments. 

Now I have to explain that I'm one of those people who were playing ADOM since early-days. I spent countless hours and spent dozens on dozens of characters to their eventual deaths. And that is something you have to get used to in this game. Your characters die. When they die, they're gone for good. Shiny gear. Nifty abilities. Everything. Gone. The only thing you'll have to remember them by is their entry on your personal high score board reminding you that your best character died on level 5 of some hole in the field because he/she died of the black plague because you ate a kobold corpse on the ground. 

I'm resisting the urge to ramble on and on here. ADOM really is a good game! Its wonderfully complex yet simple in its premise. There is no real story involved. 'Go and fight Chaos'. They drop you on the world and wish you good luck. The overworld is always the same. And the dungeons you dive into are always random. But this time, instead of the ASCII characters representing yourself, enemies, and items on the ground, you have a nifty little graphical representation. And in the 'old' game, you had to memorize a LOT of hotkeys, as combinations of letters with alt/shift/ctrl were what you had to press to perform actions and bring up menus. 

But that's the rub. The GUI (that's Graphical User Inferface), in my opinion, is about 75% of what you're buying here. Yes, there are a few different modes you can play in. Yes, you can now play by using the mouse and right-clicking to bring up a menu of things you can do instead of remembering its keystroke to make it more forgiving for newbies learning how to get around - though the game itself can still be brutal. But when you get down to brass tacks, you're buying cosmetics. 

That's why I wavered on the tumbs up and tumbs down. I love ADOM. It's a relic from junior high through college for me. But are you willing to drop more than $10 for what adds up to little more than polish? I did, for the nostaliga. But it might be a touch stiff for others when they could have gotten the original ADOM for free in the past.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006655570', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1687462002}
review: Pinacle of rogue gaming. Own at your peril! You've been warned.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970707677', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 5613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 711, 'last_played': 1614459736}
review:
My four brothers and I have been playing ADOM since about 2000. We have dedicated uncountable hours to this game, improving our talents/skill choices, learning which monsters are dangerous (nearly all of them in their own way, even as food!), how to not starve to death, how to infer properties of unidentified items, how to make your deity happy (very useful), to always eat ogre and blink dog corpses, and that you should never attempt any alchemy as an amateur no matter how innocent appearing (not even mixing water and carrot juice).

Yet not once have any of us beat the game. Some of us have gotten close a couple times, but no cigar.  Unlike the vast majority of all games, beating this game without scum saving is truly a respectable achievement and the journey itself will yield many super-intense close calls.

Despite the difficulty, we still play it and always come back to it. The ADOM world has so much depth, playing the game is really like exploring a new world.

ADOM is probably one of the best RPGs in existence. If you can look past the simple graphics and turn based play, this game will yield many, many hours of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032943425', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1507674530}
review:
I search for traps.
*rolls*
You find no traps.

I search for traps.
*rolls*
You find no traps

I search for traps.
*rolls*
You find no traps

I enter the game.
You find no traps*!

Wait...a game that's fully developed and GOOD?  What kind of dungeon is this?  IT'S ADOM!

Welcome to the only world you'll ever want to live in for the foreseeable future!  Filled with an amazing and detailed story, ADOM is the true definition of Rogue-like.  But unlike many other Roguelikes that you'll find on steam, Ancient Domains of Mystery really does make you worry about losing your character, while simultaneously making you want to start again the second you die.  From exploring caves to finishing quests for unique items, ADOM has something for everyone.  And now with its new (and totally optional) UI, it even has graphics for those who can't stand nethack.

I have been playing ADOM pre 1.0 release and I am SO happy to see this game brought to life.  The Creator Thomas Biskup has been working on this game for so long and each new release has had me crawling around in Ancardia looking at the new changes and updates.   Now that it's on Steam, I am happy to spend my money to support the ADOM crew and continue to keep this jewel alive.

I highly urge users to try to the ASCII version prior to playing with the graphical version.  I say this because it will absolutely help you understand the mechanics and probabilities of this game.  I don't personally care for the graphical version, but being a fan of skyrim and fallout, I can also understand the longing for something more than ASCII characters moving around.

I also highly recommend checking out the wikia.  The world of Ancardia is so full and detailed, that it will help you immensely to look up your class and race to see what fun specialties they afford you!  Many have fun skills you can only have as certain races.  Be prepared to immerse yourself and realize how much fun the game can be! 

*Disclaimer:
There are absolutely traps in this game!  Dr VectorX is in no way responsible for damages caused by in-game traps. Because I like this game so much and I want people to be able to see how good this game is without the unfortunate launch day issues that plague many games (squinty glare at CoD), I want to inform everyone that they may try ADOM for FREE. author: {'steamid': '76561198031619146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 1305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1690719579}
review:
I absolutely recommend this game.

Don't be fooled by my game time, I have played Adom for years, almost since it was first introduced, it's possibly my all time most played game exclude world of warcraft.

While still being extremely deep and complicated game, the current build is lot more fluent and easier to use, specially with mouse being possible for menus negating the need to know all keybinds, as well as the visual representations of the charecters ( although symbols did have their charm back in the day). Making it lot more accessable to new players that it used to be, but I still recommend you to go trough tutorial and using the ? key for help frequently.


So what you can do in adom?

Wanna free roam ? check
Wanna be god ? possible
Wanna be evil? check
Wanna be good ? check
Wanna be troll that eats little children and dogs? check
Wanna build bridges ? check
Can't swim but want to cross rivers ? freeze it with spell.
Can't open door ? kick it down, blow it up so on..
Wanna worship gods and sacrefice to them ? check
Want to kick their altars and piss them off instead ? check
Want to be sacreficed by some dark priest by god ? check
Wanna mountain climb, deep dive ? check
Want to shrink or enlarge? check...

And list goes on.

This game has RIDICULOUS amounts of secrets and contents, it will take half lifetime to find or explore them all and that's with using game guides.

Extremely recommended, definately worth the price. 

Be warned though, this game gets really hard for uninitiated, but it's part of the charm.

Ps : don't get eaten by a grue :D, also do not kill cats, you regret it later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085407770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 5062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1707683886}
review:
Don't let my hours into this game fool you. I've been playing this game exponentially longer than it has been on Steam. I think I first picked this game up in 2003, and can remember when your character was a colored @.

The graphics for this game has come a long way, and even though, compared to other games, it's own graphic detail may seem somewhat lacking, that's not the key feature here. Allow me to start likening it to other games.

In spite of the fact that it takes up about the same amount of space on your Hard Drive as Five Nights At Freddy's, it's story, lore, and gameplay are almost as deep as the land of Tamriel's. Gameplay is smooth, and the controls, while beyond numerous, are simple, and easy to understand. The downside is the difficulty. I have been playing it for years, and I have never beaten it. Namely, this is because I tend to have a Throw-Myself-At-Anything strategy, and if you are not careful, this can lead to you having a bad day really quick. Couple the fact that this game comes standard with PermaDeath, and you really want to be careful how you play. Imagine Dark Souls with the Skyrim Dead is Dead mod installed. Pretty hardcore. In addition, the game has at least six different endings. Multiple quests, endless, randomly generated dungeons, with a few of them literally infinite in size. An expansive, MASSIVE overworld that is bigger than the size of Oblivion. Random encounters in the wild with numerous creatures to face, from bandits to jackals to the Brotherhood of Chaos to hill giants. A simplistic, incredibly fun game with an incredible lore. You have multiple races, and multiple classes to pick from, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. Pray to the gods for assistance, but don't abuse their generosity. And with Talents, you can customize your ratling fencer to be unique from other Ratling Fencers you may create, leading to an admittedly still finite, but very, very, VERY large pool of possible combinations. This is a game 22 years in the making, and it has managed to stay true to it's roots, while at the same time become attractive to a newer audience. I highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087754231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 33828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 556, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1711429378}
review:
As someone who has been playing ADOM since last century, I highly reccomend this game. But be warned, it is not a simple game where you will sit down for five minutes to flick birds at stuff. This game requires time and patience of you, but it gives back as much as you give.

For new players, a few tips: you have a deity, and you should pray when things get tough. Buy food if you didn't start with much, and especially have food for long treks through the wilderness. Anyone can put a madman out of his misery - a true hero will find a way to heal him. Giant inscects have hard shells, and you may need to swing like a berserker to cut through. Your first mindcrafter will be killed by a stone block; do not be angry when this happens. Until you understand how altars work, do not step on black ones.

And keep at it. Yes, you will die a lot. Expect your high scores to fill up with level 1-7 heroes before you really start to master this game. Winning this game is not an eventual certainty. It is a glorious achievement.

Axes high!

author: {'steamid': '76561197979414350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 83087, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4920, 'last_played': 1666475656}
review:
If you've played classic ADOM, this version is that, but with added tile graphics, sound and music, and a more modern UI - all extras which can be turned off, if desired. There's no real ASCII mode anymore, just a tileset emulating one.

If you haven't played ADOM before, well, it's classic roguelike. Bad things are happening in the surreal and dark fantasy land of Drakalor Chain, and it's up to you and your equipment to do something about it. Its learning curve combined with the occasionally-less-than-obvious UI will make for a painful experience, initially. It's a very difficult and unforgiving game with dozens of keyboard commands that you need to memorize, with arguably unfair deaths in the early game.

Item destruction is the hallmark of this game. For instance, taking a step might result in your stuff getting destroyed by an acid trap and kicking a door might activate a rune trap, which is even worse. Your equipped stuff and carried inventory require separate means of protection, and some hazards are impossible to counter, unless you leave your things elsewhere. (It's not all bad, since powerful artifact items cannot be destroyed.)

Early game can be tricky as a spellcaster while later challenges are deadly if you decide to melee everything, and while there are nasty surprises awaiting, there also also positive ones. It gets easier after a while, though, and it won't take too many deaths before a certain confidence sets in; after learning the ropes you're left with addictive gameplay set in a sinister fantasy world with tons of depth, now with music and optional graphics. 

In short, rewarding fantasy RPG with an interesting setting and great flavor text to boot. Not for the impatient.

Special thumbs up for the weekly challenges and Steam achievements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037203540', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 48639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4760, 'last_played': 1685119811}
review:
Already before the resurrection campagne, ADOM was my favorite video game. I am a dedicated fan for almost ten years now and really enjoy the great improvements the game got since team ADOM started their work.

In my eyes the game offers alot of things that can hardly be found in current games:
The randomly generated dungeons offer infinite replayability.
The perma-death feature gives the game a unique rate of tension and makes you really rejoyce and suffer with your character in good and bad moments. 
The big and exciting world with it's many dungeons and quests give ADOM a more intense roleplay-feeling than most other roguelike games.
Last but not least the community features more than just afew truely pleasant, nice and helpful guys that I enjoy spending my time with.

Anything bad? I seriously don't think so. Like I said, this is my favorite game for a whole decade now. If you don't mind a truely challenging game, do yourself a favor, get it and enjoy an endless amount of high quality gaming experience :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198006625266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 3631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1490, 'last_played': 1642178327}
review: superbe !

author: {'steamid': '76561198044114950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 37126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1708794817}
review:
Listen, this is an amazing game.  It was an amazing game two decades ago when it first came out (even before you could "beat it"), and it's amazing now that it has gorgeous tiles and a wide variety of end-game scenarios.  Playstyle is very clearly delineated by the different character types, which isn't always the case in rogue-likes or RPGs.  Resourcefulness - on the part of YOU, the PLAYER - is paramount as you enter the more difficult portions of the game.  And all of these gaming elements are built within a rich world with dozens of optional areas and side quests designed to enhance your character for the trials that await.

RUN, don't walk, and get your copy of ADOM right now!  Show me what you can do with your Gray Elven Elementalist, your Trollish Healer, your Drakish Beastmaster, your Gnomish Monk...can you do better than us?

author: {'steamid': '76561198052596449', 'num_games_owned': 520, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 7070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1619716776}
review:
I'm so excited! I remember playing this game in the early 00's. I was struck by its amazing depth and over the years it became one of my favourites, to which I return constantly. I have only managed to win once though ;)
If you are not a fan of graphics (just as myself), you can still play this game in its original ASCII mode. Pick one of the numerous class & race combinations, wield an array of weapons (you can even throw coins if you so please) or mighty spells, plant herbs (that follow the rules of the Game of Life -- neat), and go onward!
Adventure awaits.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988249826', 'num_games_owned': 755, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 6969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6920, 'last_played': 1678479052}
review:
Approximate amount of time to 100%: 115 hours
Estimated achievement difficulty: 10/10
Minimum number of playthroughs needed: 6+, Features Permadeath, Heavy RNG.

Multiplayer achievements: No
Missable achievements: No
Grinding Achievements: Yes, Level to max in a single location
DLC-Only achievements: No
Time-gated achievements: No
RNG-achievements:Yes, Very. Multiple achievements practically depend on a random 
item spawning.
Does difficulty affect achievements: Yes. Achievements only unlock in Permadeath Mode.
Unobtainable/glitched achievements: No, Past versions had problems with achievements 
unlocking, I did not run into any of these bugs

The game is a modernized classic. Some achievements are bordering Impossible without 
save-scumming or Heavy RNG manipulation. A minimum of 6 Endings are needed despite 
permadeath.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963889594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1603488769}
review:
I love all things rogue, and have been playing ADOM for years but I cannot recommend this reskin based on a couple of things mainly the price and UI.

The tileset is good well drawn and a good overall style, I also like the new music.

The UI on the otherhand is sloppy and barely works, its unintuitive and makes no sense most of the time, I just found myself using keys which defeats the point of me paying a premium for ADOM with a UI.

Seeing as I can get basic ADOM for free paying £11 for a tileset addon with a UI is a joke especially when I can get TOME for a fraction of the price and is a million times more superior in its UI design and function.

While I love ADOM i cant remmond this for the amount there asking untill some major improvements are done to the interface.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027097138', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 8188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2874, 'last_played': 1659556540}
review:
Life is like a game of ADOM. You know you'll die in the end, but it's the journey that counts.

I have been playing ADOM for 20 years, and expect to play it for a good deal longer, especially now that the game is being actively developed again. Roguelike games are easy to come back to, you can always apply the knowledge you gained from your previous attempts to beat the game, and the various playthroughs are very different to one another. I had an easy time picking this game for the "Test of Time" title for Steam award nominations.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994157410', 'num_games_owned': 678, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1489596907}

author: {'steamid': '76561198026509869', 'num_games_owned': 713, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 326, 'last_played': 1578122931}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040884867', 'num_games_owned': 2434, 'num_reviews': 901, 'playtime_forever': 1322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 738, 'last_played': 1448573243}
review:
[b][i]ADOM[/i] by many measures, is one of [i]the few[/i] classic roguelikes that started it all.[/b] In developement since 1994, and by reading over its history, I can say it has come a long way. This title can certainly hold its own right up  there with the best of modern games. Some may have you believe a single person (Thomas Biskup) built this, but as is stated in the credits, the end product is the result of thousands of peoples hard work and ideas. [i]Certainly Mr. Biskup deserves the lion's share of credit, but compared to other indie titles, this is hardly something that came out of someones basement over the weekend.[/i]

[i]Classic roguelikes are nearly infinite in replayability, and possibility.[/i] Sure, there is a certain trade-off between user interface, graphics, and learning curve that pays out with a giant world with metric tons of gameplay and fun. [b]Yes, its difficult. Yes, you will need to read lots (thank you in-game manual). Yes, it is FUN.[/b]

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Timeless game that has been shaped over 20 years, which is reflected by system complexity that goes unmatched in modern games.
+The ability to seemlessly (simply push F10) switch between classic ASCII and tiles.
+Tiles and music are beautifully done.
+Many modes that are all well recieved. In example, Crowd mode alters the difficulty of your game by how many Steam friends you have that play [i]ADOM[/i]. This is fresh and certainly encourages community.
+++Highscores leaderboards!
+++Ghosts of your fallen Steam friends show up in your game lol.
+Both keyboard and mouse support. I find the control scheme very intuitive. The updated user interface is very nice IMO.
+In-depth tutorial.
+Great community.
+Super active developement.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Yeah there is a steep learning curve, but that only applies to people that are new to roguelikes. Get through it, or simply realize these types of games are not your cup of tea.

[b]If you have any interest in PC gaming history at all, this title deserves to be in your library. What a gem.[/b] It amazes me how this classic has evolved over time and can still outcompete modern titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035309581', 'num_games_owned': 908, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 10972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1667773538}

author: {'steamid': '76561198047652120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1613227520}
review:
As an ADOM veteran since 1997, I've played my fair share of the game. It's still essentially the same game as it was way back, but what this new version brings is a pretty sweet graphical tile visualization and a couple of new quests. It's still a great game with enormous depth and endless replayability. The only problem for me is adapting to the newest interface, since I find the top menu quite hard to read compared to the previous Steam beta versions that had the numbers below the tiles in oldschool ASCII. I would quite like the possibility to configure the interface so that I could keep the ASCII numbers but still have the graphical tiles like in the Steam beta versions.

/edit: I figured it out. CTRL+n m does exactly what I want.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992232387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1551440649}
review: Don't let the low gameplay hours fool you, I've invested alot of time into this game over the years, back before version 2 and back before it was on steam. Quite a lot of fun. Just google rogue like games first, to find out if it is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001220728', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 24961, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1620198413}
review:
I *love* this game. I've been playing for almost 20 years and I'm still not bored of it. Massively recommended classic roguelike, now with prettified graphics and sound.

HOWEVER, you should be aware of a few things before you buy:
 - Turn-based (Roguelike)
 - Steep learning curve, including Permadeath (Roguelike)
 - Tile graphics covering up an ASCII system (Roguelike)
 - Somewhat archaic control system (but the best amongst the classic Roguelikes IMO, with decent inventory control)
 - Awkward to play without a numpad - especially if you don't have an actual mouse. Not recommended for any but the biggest laptop keyboards.
 - Just in case it wasn't really obvious, this is very much a thinking gamer's game. It has ZERO twitch.

And probably the worst point:
 - Many new releases thusfar have included a fatal crash bug... although these are generally fixed in about 24 hours.

BUT...
If you're willing to persevere through this, you've got a game of almost unparalleled depth and enjoyment. SO much to learn, SO many different viable strategies, SO many different character builds, and SO much tension and excitement in a turn-based game.

TWENTY. YEARS.

Not bored.

Still reading? Get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198177036386', 'num_games_owned': 265, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1651334663}
review:
ADOM - странная игра. Она не похожа на другие рогалики-прародители (NetHack, Angband и пр.) В ней нет такой детализации и богатства возможностей как в DwarfFortress и ToME. Игра берёт тем, чего в рогаликах, как считается, быть не должно - сюжетом. 

Сюжет здесь себя не навязывает, но не даёт о себе забыть. Забудешь - счётчик коррапта напомнит. ;) Томасу Бискапу удалось крайне скупыми средствами заставить нас сопереживать загнанному в угол "@" отбивающегося от превосходящих сил 'a' (Мерзкие твари, вчера при первом же прохождении не дали довести щенка до поверхности. Ненавижу) Здесь есть свобода - принимать решения и разгребать их последствия самому, никто тебя за ручку водить не будет.

О недостатках нынешнего релиза. В ADOM есть всё, даже они :) Графический режим не самый удачный, некоторые монстры выглядят странно. Местами он скорее мешает, например, очень трудно разглядеть лут и отдельные предметы лежащие в коридорах и "за стенкой" Спасает миникарта и олдскульный ASCII-режим. Анимация - ИМХО, лучше бы её не было.

Всех спасителей и погубителей Анкардии поздравляю с выходом игры на Стиме! Ура!

author: {'steamid': '76561198092431729', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1553677936}
review: Its a good game with horrible Ui, if I gotta pick from yes and no then its a yes but I really want to give a no.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046826709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 706, 'last_played': 1447854692}
review:
Gamebreaking bug.  When I select my character by clicking him, the menu won't pop up, and I will be stuck.  Have to hard reset the game to restart the game.  I've had to hard reset like over a dozen times, and since it is a 'roguelike' game there is no save of my character, and a self save takes me back to the main screen (annoying).

Fun game though w/ tons of characters and classes to play.  Pretty basic like other games like Hammerwatch imo, w/o multiplayer which is a shame.  Typical hack in slash that is strongly keyboard based though.  Game is probably slightly overpriced, and worth probably in the 9.99 for the basic overall quality of the game (there really is no soundtrack for example).

What is cool, is you get to play a combo of tons of races and classes (that should be more previlent in more fantasy genre games like this one), but are not.  For instance I love playing a Troll Barbarian.

This game I guess is a bit old there are some indie strat guides out there to help you select your character and to explain stuff (like selling stuff requires you to go into the merchant shop and drop the item on the shop floor, lol weird), and in that regard, the game seems overall unpolished compared to the price point which it is at imo.

----

After playing more hours and seeing the dev reply to the game, let me expand my review some more.

This is the typical game that falls into "challenging" and tries to prey on perhaps the nostalgic feelings of those who maybe played this game in the past.

Granted I like challenging games, but realistically you will get 3-7 hours of frustrating fun.

I found it extremely difficult to get past the southern dungeon on my way past the map.  

All dungeon maps are always rectangular in nature, vary very little; granted they seem to be using a random seed of some kind, but after 3-4 times it gets stale.  There are torches on the wall, other than that, there is no decor.  Character animations are limited and are only left face and right face.  Also when I equip certain equipment like the helm it is barely visible or not visible at all.

There is no soundtrack, the ambience sound is almost non-existent.  Occasionally I hear the drop of into a puddle in a dungeon.  Again, the atmosphere of the game feels incomplete.

There are TONS of games similar to this, Gauntlet $19.99 (when not on sale, 2015 game) (http://store.steampowered.com/app/258970/ ) is a popular game my friends play that has a multiplayer aspect, which this game does not have.  Also Hammerwatch $9.99 (not on sale) which does exist, unlike what the Dev has said and exists here on Steam:  http://store.steampowered.com/app/239070/


Let me describe a small experience I had playing a Troll Barbarian, which granted is pretty cool since most games fall short of providing the race/class combo which games like this should have (orignally stated above).  I roll this toon, spec into two handed weapons, and I go into the trial dungeon, first door is locked, I can only kick it down, in the process of kicking the door down my huge club is broke, lol wtf ok.  So basically your skill that you used to get the 2hed item is worthless and now you have to punch guys.
Overall sound effects are stale, limited, and lackluster, and could be improved dramatically.
If you are going to bring back a game from 1995 update date, improve it a ton.  Check out Divinity Original Sin (http://store.steampowered.com/app/373420/), a game which was just enhanced w/ over 90+ hours of gameplay and fully AAA voiced acted.
Spell casters feel bulky and there is not hotkey menu like modern games have (again you are paying for a 1995 1st addition D&D type game).  I have to constantly hit he escape menu to break away from the immersion of the game to open a spellbook.  After some casting of the spells they are "forgotton" (no tutorial on this at all btw, to explain this to first time players of ADOM like myself), and I have to relearn them.  Which means you have to worry about carrying 100 stone tombs everywhere you go.  This is a problem if you play a gnome mage (which I tried out), and tried carrying around 5 tombs plus heavy rations.
Certain classes have to eat CONSTANTLY like the game should be renamed “iron ration buffet” as trolls have to eat 1-2 every dungeon level.  Since food weighs a TON certain races are bogged down w/ carrying capacity issues (which only mildly exists as a nuisance in other games).

On the flip side I like rolling a quick character and just smashing through enemies in the dungeons.  But other games have this pleasure of smashing AI units into the ground.
Also initial encounters past the first town can kill you very easily.  You see the theme here?  This game has a HUGE learning curve w/ 8bit graphics.  Time/reward/money do not align that well.

Why are the rations so heavy in this game? And not proportion to the character size, again another design flaw.

This game is geared towards probably ppl who are in the 30s.  Why pay for this game when you can get far superior games for roughly 1-2x the price.  Although if you want to step into a time machine and try to play and relive the sweet memories when you were 8 years old on your Commodore.

I feel like this game is a semi money grab at the nostalgic feels of old time gamers who played this game and who want to shell out $ for these feels.

After being frustrated for the last time, I uninstalled.

Funny, when a long time bud on Steam who saw me playing this game on messaged me:

"2015 >> azbolg still playing shit games"

This game is a solid 4 / 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995633765', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 10426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1787, 'last_played': 1686025062}
review:
0.) Warning! This review mentions several things that may or may not be spoilers. The game is randomized to a degree and also depends greatly on your own choices in-game. There is no right or wrong way to play, but I do mention several things that I consider to be entertaining examples of ADOM's charm. Everything below is optional and nothing below is related to the "main plot" but if the threat of spoilers gives you heart palpitations, just know that I heartily endorse ADOM (whether in ASCII or in the new graphical mode). It's one of my top 10 games of all-time, and I gladly supported it during its indiegogo campaign despite there still being a completely free version available from the developer. It's just that good.

1.) This game has entertained me for well over a decade, and I'm still not tired of it.

2.) Every time you start a new character, make a note of what your first kill is; trust me.

3.) Don't kick a door head-on if you can help it; diagonals are best.

4.) Killing cats is bad.

5.) If you find yourself with a cursed item, you might want to try stripping naked and standing in an acid trap for a few minutes.

6.) Don't touch strange trees you find underground.

7.) Never sell or drop your last Si.

8.) If at first you don't succeed, try playing a hurthling archer.

9.) There is a dedicated hotkey for wiping your face, and you'll need it.

10.) After 1000+ hours, I have never managed to reach even one of the possible endings; the furthest I've reached is character level 43 and it was glorious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091898108', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 138293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3908, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1712410507}
review:
One of the best rogue-likes ever written, this one manages a coherent plot with different endings, multiple dungeons to explore, a decently sized overworld, a host of different races and classes to combine, and the punishing difficulty one expects from any decent rogue-like.  

It will consume your time and eat your life.  In over twenty years of play I've managed to beat it all of twice, and that is one of the proudest gaming achievements of my career.

Ancardia awaits!  Please step up to support this beautiful labor of love.  Just make sure you don't have any big plans for the next year or so when you do.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961738975', 'num_games_owned': 958, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 3864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2615, 'last_played': 1545479281}
review: I've been playing ADOM since 1998, and it is definitely my favorite roguelike. It is great to see the recent growth of the game. The weekly challenge is a welcome addition. and Thomas Biskup definitely deserves my money for the 17 years of enjoyment I've gotten out of this gem of a game. If you like roguelikes, you will love ADOM. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198045556443', 'num_games_owned': 1120, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 28970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3015, 'last_played': 1708638902}

author: {'steamid': '76561198060219701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1483512110}
review:
Hah. How to review ADOM? Well, it's one of the Great Few, an actual roguelike (not roguelikelike or light or anything) that helped define the genre. ADOM's strongest points are a mix of a persistent plot with procedurally generated elements, and a much deeper lore than its kin.

Once again the ultimate evil raises its ugly head and only a single hero can defeat it because fate says so. That hero is you. Or, will be you. Eventually you will defeat evil. But before that, you will die. A lot. And then again, and then some more. And you'll probably love every single death because you learned something, or had the chance to try out a new trick, or just had a brief moment of clarity how something COULD be done, only you didn't do it.

ADOM "Steam" is a pretty huge package. While the original game can be played for free, this version comes with a nice set of "deluxe" options and, seriously, this is a game that has been around for ages. I played it for ages. I think it's fair that at some point someone gets a bit of my money for the entertainment I had, because this is a game made for old dogs like me. A perfect throwback to my teen years, not pimped out until it's no longer the game I learned to love but with a nice, sensible lick of paint and a sleek interface. And I can still have it all in ASCII if I want.

There's just no way not to recommend this game. 
If you already know it, you want to buy it for the same reasons I did: For nostalgia, for running the dungeons again, for feeling the thrill of a fight where each move matters, for smiling at the fact that your Steam Playtime can never, ever, match the hours you already sunk into this monster.
If you never heard of ADOM, you want to try it out because it is a nicely structured, engrossing game that polishes some concepts of the genre to a silky sheen. You'll appreciate the interface, which is readable but doesn't get in your way, you'll start out small and then you'll be hooked.

All this said, it's still a roguelike. As in, one of the games that took care we HAVE roguelikes. There are many things here that are part of the genre but not to everyone's taste- a fairly rocky early game, permadeath, TONS of ways to die yeat another stupid death, and an omnipresent element of randomness that can, and will, screw you up big time at least once per run. ADOM doesn't pull any punches and you need to be aware of that, this is not a recent rogue-light, this is bedrock. If you are just curious what the craze is all about, you may want to try the free version, just to see how it sits with you. 

Because like most old roguelikes, ADOM is a game that rewards patience, planning, developing strategies and preparing for the worst- while still allowing players to improvise and come out of a tight spot with some sweet experience and a new trick in their book. 

15 Euros can buy you more recent, visually impressive, or (to be honest) more streamlined games after all, but ADOM takes time to master, and beating it once is nothing, considering the endless replayability the genre itself has to offer.

Happy dungeon-dwelling, spell-singing and corpse-cursing!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970153763', 'num_games_owned': 944, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 3989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1690406847}

author: {'steamid': '76561197987270895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 6279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1709156704}
review:
After 10 years - give or take - Ancient Domains of Mystery still wakes that primal excitement in this quite cynical gamer. 

ADOM is one of the first true roguelikes among Nethack and the like but was the only one of those that made me sit on my chair, scratching my hair with the decisions the game made me do, or the sheer amount of options it presented. I was stunned that you really needed almost the whole keyboard to play the game and it sure took time to learn most of the quirks. Back then the game was presented in ASCII aka by symbols like letters and numbers. Plain 'g' for goblin and 'k' for kobold.

This new Steam version has graphics in form of a tileset tho, so you don't have to learn how to "read" the game first even though it doesn't remove the fact that you still have to master them buttons. I think the tileset is very decent taking consideration the scale of the game and the amount of classes/races/weapons/etc there is. 

The UI sure feels clunky though and I recommend taking your time to read through everything the first time. After generating few characters and painfully losing them you'll surely get the hang of it and the gameplay get's much smoother and faster. It's not as difficult as Dwarf Fortress but in a whole new level compared to i.e. Dungeons of Dredmor if that helps anything. 

I might add and edit the review if needed but for now I just wanted to welcome my old friend to Steam and give it a nice 9/10 review.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982293787', 'num_games_owned': 2327, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 2343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1395, 'last_played': 1672542220}
review: One of the cornerstone Roguelikes, lovingly enhanced for steam and the modern era. And damn it's such a good one to begin with. It's punnishingly difficult, it has a fully fleshed out and interesting world. The RPG system is so elegant and still ahead of it's time. So happy to see this come to steam and hopefully Ancardia will see some new adventurer's combat chaos!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025593041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 33462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 661, 'last_played': 1708932045}

author: {'steamid': '76561197976419562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1555693330}
review:
I've been waiting years for a way to pay the author for creating ADOM, which I view as the finest procedurally driven RPG ever created. 

ADOM is a game in the tradition of rogue, hack, and nethack. To describe it as "hard" would be both true and misleading: It's actually very easy to play and very easy to make a lot of progress, but actually winning is a delicate and unlikely affair. Dying is practically inevitable and although in the "Deluxe" version it's possible to turn off perma-death it's certainly not in the spirit of the game to do so. I can't even begin to enumerate the number of games I've played but I've saved well over a hundred memorials to "notable" dead characters on this computer alone. I have only approached the approximate half-way point twice, I have never come close to winning... and still I play, because what keeps me coming back is the variety and the challenge.

This is not a game you will win in a weekend, or a month, or a year, but you will enjoy every session (right up to the moment you die). I encourage you, dear reader, to cough up the meager sum that is asked here for this gem and immerse yourself in a wonderful game in which the developer has truly Thought Of Everything. If mud splashes on your face it blinds you until you wipe it away. If it's dark or you're illiterate you can't read books or scrolls; if you're deaf you can't hear what NPCs say to you, but the wail of a banshee will also not affect you. Sometimes kicking things breaks them, sometimes it just hurts your leg. You can eat the raw corpse of a hurthling but it will taste better and sustain you longer if you cook it first.  The texture and depth is incredible and, thanks to randomly generated elements, your choice of race, class and winning strategy it's never quite the same twice.

For new players I recommend three things: Patience, determination, and to avoid standing directly in front of doors when opening them. Your reward: endless fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043290733', 'num_games_owned': 66, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 128733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57798, 'last_played': 1633409354}
review:
I've been playing this game.   For far too long...   16 years.   I'll probably play for 16 more, at least.

Let me break it down:

Imagine Diablo 2, but turnbased. And in hardcore mode by default.   You will never play the same game twice.

This is the pure definition of replayability:  If you buy this game and can look past the fact that it doesn't have beautiful AAA CG graphics or plays best using keyboard commands, then you may never need to buy another game again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118877397', 'num_games_owned': 377, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 20189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 966, 'playtime_at_review': 2260, 'last_played': 1712195450}
review:
Ancient Domains of Mystery (ADOM) is one of the most difficult & addicting roguelike games I've ever played.  Over the thousands of characters generated, only about five have managed to succeed in "beating the game".  I would strongly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys roguelikes or difficult games that can be frustrating, but extremely rewarding.

If you're unsure whether or not to purchase this game, try it out for free on the ADOM website.  There is a steep learning curve to this game, so you should definitely do the tutorial to learn the basics if playing for the first time.  The rest is just trial and error.

Overall, one of my top favorite games of all time (if you can't tell by my username).

author: {'steamid': '76561198062293675', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1448058526}
review:
Ah, ADOM, que de souvenirs ...
Ce jeu est LE Roguelike ultime. Si vous aimez le genre, je veux dire le vrai, celui où l'on se déplace case par case, où l'on meurt facilement et où on en redemande, foncez, vous ne serez pas déçu.
Pour ma part, j'ai acheté le jeu les yeux fermés parce que j'avais gouté la version gratuite il y a quelques années.
La plus-value de cette version payante ?
Les tiles, la musique, les divers modes de jeu, ...
Et surtout, il faut bien remercier l'auteur. Si le jeu est avant tout un projet-passion de sa part, tout travail mérite salaire.
Et ce jeu, développé depuis 1994, même si ce n'est pas à plein temps, mérite bien un paiement en retour.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029790575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 5092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1180, 'last_played': 1568825047}
review: I cannot tell you for sure how many hours I've spent playing ADOM because a) it was not on Steam; b) I was not at Steam. But for sure we are talking about thiusands of hours. It is a legendary game, if you are looking for a classic hardcore rogue-like experience – that's the game to buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960653146', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 20780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1708320666}
review:
ADOM was the first roguelike game I ever played and I've tried many since my first encounter with the game in the early 2000s. I've yet to find another game with similar depth and the ability to suprise me on most playthroughs, it's still my favorite roguelike game ever! 

The facelift with the graphical tiles is a welcome change, but if you enjoy the old-timey ASCII graphics, they're still there for you! 
A word of warning for people who are new to the game or genre; this game is unforgiving at times and reading up about the monsters, dungeons and quests is strongly advisable on any of the player-written guides or wikis. Best of luck to you if you decide to pick up this fantastic game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197973532541', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 13806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 124, 'playtime_at_review': 4197, 'last_played': 1712075956}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999605846', 'num_games_owned': 938, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 30512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4041, 'last_played': 1697824759}
review:
The first RPG I've played, and one I still come back to every now and then. I've been excited ever since the crowdfunding campaing, and been singing praises of this game ever since. It's brutal, hard and random, yes, but such is the nature of TRUE rogue-likes. 

Deluxe version gives you the options to lower the difficulty for more casual of players, so they can get enjoyment out of this game as well. Even giving you option to properly save your game, unlike the normal mode, where your game save is tied to your characters life, once character dies, it's gone. This is something not available in the free version. More on that later.

But the true meat of this game comes from flexibility of the combat... You have your basic Melee, Ranged and Magic attacks, but you also can use Mindcraft, companions, special race/class abilities and alchemy to name a few varied methods of dealing damage. But you can in turn take damage from ridiculous stuff among others, and get killed in many, many ways, including getting crushed by dungeon, whipping yourself to death, getting sacrificed to one of many gods, having too much stuff in your inventory and my personal favorite: Getting eaten by grue. Also, you can get killed before you even move (or take your first step) with certain race/class combinations on certain day.

There are plenty of static elements in game that stay same from game to game, but majority of the dungeons are randomly generated, keeping you on your toes every time. No two games are the same, which makes this game highly replayable.

Deluxe version of ADOM is not only worth your money, but as it gets more features, which will keep coming until the Creator of this game feels this game is complete (and moves onto the Sequel) makes this game truly worthwhile. But if you are not certain of getting the Deluxe version yet, you can always download the Free version of this game from ADOM homepage, and try it out as much you want. The base game is the same regardless, but There are bunch of nifty features that will not be in the free versions ever. But if you so desire, you can run the newest free version of this game on your Amiga or old MS-Dos computers. That's how old-school this game is.

//Additions
- Point based Character creation has been Added to the game, which allows more customization.
- You can now also Choose your starting Starsign, unlike previously
- Majority of Bugs Fixed (Basically, unless you applied to the beta, which you can do if you so desire, you shouldn't encounter any bugs)

//Coming Features
- Animations
- Volcano (A new dungeon, that is completely different from other places currently in game)
- More Quests
- Even more Bugfixes

author: {'steamid': '76561197979399256', 'num_games_owned': 4327, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 9400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3681, 'last_played': 1657756234}
review:
This is, simply put, the greatest game ever made. I have been playing this since 1996. This game will make you rage quit and scream about how you will never play it again and an hour later, there you are playing again. The depth of this game is unrivaled by anything. You will encounter mind boggling scenarios and unimaginable deaths. For instance, I was walking through a dungeon once and I heard a water trap go off. I came around a corner and I was blown to bits by fiery death. As I sat there wondering what in the hell just happened, I came to realize that a goblin had stepped on the water trap that I had heard go off and when he got hit with the water, a potion that he was carrying reacted with the water and exploded. Or how about the time I ate a kobold corpse that made me sick and then promptly got bit by a ghoul that paralyzed me and I choked to death on my own vomit? Yes, this kind of stuff actually happens. It's the kind of stuff that makes you rage quit the game and, oddly enough, it's what keeps you playing the same game going on 20 years.

I will drink from a pool tonight in a toast for ADOM's arrival on Steam. With the first wish I get, I will wish for Thomas Biskup. Oh, the hilarity.

What are you waiting for? Get this now. Andor Drakon, the ElDeR cHaOs GoD awaits!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993930568', 'num_games_owned': 5393, 'num_reviews': 480, 'playtime_forever': 2311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2265, 'last_played': 1630008332}
review:
(TL:DR: great game and it is a finished game but it is not ready for a general steam audience)

I'm putting this as a positive review because I think ADOM is a great game which is lots of fun but there are lots of warnings I have to give to people who haven't played this game or old school roguelikes before.

(I came back to this review and really wanted to tone the review down because I think the dev is a great guy and it's a really fun game but I have to be honest: there are a lot of pretty big annoyances that will make people not used to the game regret buying it, and people do need to realize that development, while always ongoing, is not as rapid as some other games, and patience is required).


The game was greenlit a long time ago and wasn't released on steam until a year and a half later. The explanation for this was polishing the game for the general steam audience rather than the more forgiving hardcore old fans of the game. Despite this, it is not really ready for a general audience despite there being easily enough time to prepare it.

[strike]1. The game can crash: I experienced a crash within my first two hours of play. The game is permadeath but does autosave every 1000 turns. The problem is that in order to recover from a crash you have to know what you are doing and rename a certain file a certain way. The game is not programmed to realize it hasn't shut down cleanly so it can't help you.[/strike]seems fixed

2. There is mouse control but it's not total, meaning you have to press keys sometimes. It's not easy to even predict when you'll have to press a key rather than being able to use the mouse.

3. The default keys are really bad from a HCI point of view (human-computer interaction): For example to rest to regain hp etc. until something disturbs you is w5 or w. That's a two key sequence for something you will be doing all the time. [strike]Even worse is the autoexplore which is w?. That's a two key sequence with the second key requiring shift! This for something you will also be doing constantly. [/strike]auto-explore is now - (minus) (casting spells as shift z, (pick spell letter), direction is bad too although is being changed to non shifted z which is slightly better)

4. It is possible to redefine the keys but unless you are an old player of adom or go looking on forums you wouldn't know how to. You have to go and get the config key file from where the game saves game data to (as in not the base game directory, e.g. for me it's C:\Users\<username>\Documents\ADOM\adom_steam) edit it in a text editor (and you have to know how to) [strike]and then put it in the right directory.[/strike]

5. There are certain features "coming soon". They include things like points-based character creation and being able to choose your star sign. Despite these things really not taking very long at all to program, they have been languishing on todo lists for ages. One of these at least was used by the greenlight campaign as an example of something that would be exclusive to the steam version and yet somehow didn't get programmed in the year and a half between being greenlit and steam release. (It's a couple of hours' work at the most).


---------------
Roguelike Curator "Rougelikes" (sic) https://steamcommunity.com/groups/rougelikes

author: {'steamid': '76561198030915514', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1604682857}
review:
ADOM is the definitive rogue-like experience. If you're a fan of rogue-likes, you've probably played ADOM already. However, this is the first of the classic rogue-likes to make its way into Steam and a wide new audience. People who are interested in rogue-like themes and the so called rogue-lite games might find a lot to like here.

As a rogue-like, ADOM is a turn-based RPG. This means that every time you take an action, all of the other characters in the game do so as well, including enemies. In a sense, it's not really turn-based as all the movement happens at once, meaning you never have to wait for the enemy's movement. Combat is a simple matter at ground level but gets more complex as the game progresses. In its most basic form, you are simply "running" into enemies. This causes you to attack them and they will attack back at you and so on. However, you can influence this combat in many ways. This includes switching your tactics to gain better to-hit chance and damage at the expense of defenses (can be used flexibly and in different ways depending on the situation), casting spells, drinking potions, zapping wands, reading scrolls, firing missiles, using skills and maneuvering around the dungeon to name a few. Trash mobs you can simply run into and destroy with ease, but whenever you encounter a new and unknown, potentially strong monster, you might want to slow down the pace and consider what gear you have to help you. And remember the number one rule of rogue-likes: always have an escape plan in mind!

ADOM is absolutely brutal. Rogue-lite games often mention how they are extremely difficult and will require multiple tries before you beat them. These games also tend to be relatively short, 1-2 hour experiences in various genres from fps to platformers. ADOM on the other hand is a purebred rogue-like through and through; a successful game is likely to take 15+ hours and the hundreds of failures you will suffer on the way will add even more hours on top of that. Now I happen to think this is a strength; there is immense amounts of replayability in the game due to a variety of races and classes you can play as, in addition to a huge amount of procedural generation when it comes to monsters you encounter, loot you find and dungeon layouts you will explore. And once you beat the game normally, guess what! There's several Ultra Endings to attempt as well! These endings are insanely hard to pull off, require EVEN more tries than the normal one and are virtually impossible without some outside information sources.

ADOM's strength in relation to other rogue-likes lies in its structured nature: Terinyo is always in the same place as well as the main dungeons of the game. There are quests that you will undertake in a logical order and once you learn your way around the early game, it is possible to form a strategy. This is absolutely key; where many rogue-likes hinge purely on RNG to get you going, ADOM actually has a very deep strategy layer to its gameplay. The other notable selling point in relation to other rogue-likes is the skill system; every race and class has a set of skills they start off with, and these skills can be improved as you advance in levels. This gives leveling a more meaningful feeling compared to some other rogue-likes where you simply gain more health and magic points.

Now this review could go on forever, but hopefully I've given you some insight into whether or not ADOM is something you might be into. Personally, I love this game. I have beaten it three times the normal way and once I've achieved the Avatar of Order ending. I've played this game over the course of 15 years, two development cycles and who knows how many hours. It is truly something special.

Lastly, some meta-advice:

-Do not play the game in softcore mode! Permadeath is an integral part of the rogue-like experience and you will hate ADOM if you don't have permadeath on. A character is very likely to die; you have to learn to deal with it. The entire premise of the game is that you roll hundreds of characters until finally one of them sticks and gets farther into the game than the others. If you keep struggling with a character who was never even meant to survive the experience will be miserable. Not to mention you will never have that feeling of utter disaster when your best character dies at the final level. Or on the way back after winning the game. And all of those losses will build up to the final success; when you finally, after all that heartbreak, beat the game and leave Drakalor Chain, you look back at the time you've spent and go: "Fuck yes, I actually did it. I beat this son of a bitch of a game. Hell yes."

-Don't be afraid to look up stuff on the wiki: ADOM is a massive game and very cryptic in some areas. However, I would suggest avoiding making a habit out of this. Explore the game freely; you're going to die so many times anyway so what's the point of completely spoiling yourself? But once you get a promising character rolling, you might want to check up on the effects of eating this specific monster's corpse, or how dangerous exactly that Gorgon is ;)

-Give the ASCII version a try! The tilesets are very nicely done and the bare-bones ASCII style might seem clunky and unintuitive at first. But you'd be surprised at the advantages it has. For example, you will easily identify new enemies: a small "g" is always going to be a goblin-like small humanoid, an uppercase "D" is always going to be a dragon or dragon-like huge lizard like drake and so on. Very clear and handy compared to the tilesets imo. Not to mention the ASCII graphics are just so damn charming!

-vesmo

author: {'steamid': '76561198017282544', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 12195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1013, 'last_played': 1594125839}
review:
[b]П[/b]ознакомился с этой игрой ещё в 2001, когда миром онлайн-игр правили [b]текстовые[/b] MUD'ы (multi-user dimension), а пищащие модемы и конские цены на интернет были нормой.
Так что ADOM с ASCII-графикой воспринялся как родной, и мне было обеспечено много сотен часов "залипания" за ним.

[b]П[/b]олная свобода действий, глубочайшие подземелья, дикий рандом, потрясающая реиграбельность, много классов и рас - комбинации могут быть просто адские, сложные квесты, смерть от падения с лестницы при перевесе, жрать трупы орков и драконов, разбивать стены ударом ноги, жечь деревья, быть злым/добрым или балансировать на грани, замораживать воду, проклинать и освящать вещи, приносить мёртвых и живых(!) существ в жертву, строить мосты, выращивать растения, быть проклятым или благословлённым богами, слепота, воровство...!
[b]Ч[/b]ёрт возьми, да что говорить, уверен, что для большинства покупателей этой игры - практически всё будет связано с ностальгией. Вы и сами всё прекрасно помните.

[b]П[/b]ериодически - раз в несколько лет - возвращался в ADOM, и под Windows и под Linux, на десятки часов.
[b]Д[/b]а никакая япон-стайл тайловая фигня, слепленная в RPG-maker или ещё в какой-то ереси - не сравнится с древним хаотическим монстром Roguelike игр - ADOM'ом!

[b]Н[/b]у а теперь ещё и в Steam - ещё и музыка, звуки, наверняка будут и регулярные обновления, фиксы багов, не надо никуда лезть, что-то качать, париться из-за несовместимости сохранений.
[b]5[/b] долларов - не цена, купил не раздумывая.

[b]С[/b]пасибо Томасу за то что поддерживает игру уже более 20 лет!
[b]С[/b]пасибо Valve и лично наше-всё Гейбу за Steam и за правильную ценовую политику для разных валют и регионов мира!

P.S. Локализации на русский и другие языки - не будет, много текста содержится в ядре игры, которому 15-20 лет, переделывать всё под разные языковые особенности не будут.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032225930', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 67860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3955, 'last_played': 1704057775}
{'steamid': '76561198034655959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 766, 'last_played': 1599914347}
review:
Many games these days boast to have vast open worlds, open-ended gameplay and endless replayability - ADOM actually delivers.

- Background -

I first played ADOM in 2003. I've since spent hundreds of hours exploring the mysterious Drakalor Chain. ADOM is one of my all-time favourite games, and certainly the only game originally released in the 90's that I don't play for nostalgia - but because it is still fresh.

ADOM is an RPG in the true sense of the word: it does not impose restrictions on you. The problem I have with most RPGs these days is how they limit the player's actions. The choice between good and evil is often in fact the choice between the good and evil dialogue option. ADOM is different in that you can actually do whatever you want, be anyone you want to be. And doing whatever you want actually means something in ADOM, since the game has a ridiculously large amount of content. Really, it does.

- Gameplay -

In ADOM, first you'll create your character. Your character will be given a starsign that will have some effect on him/her. After that you'll choose your race, profession, talents etc. from a ton of options. These choises will guide you as you start your journey, but won't limit you as (or if) you progress.

As the game begins, you enter Drakalor Chain, a troubled valley with many mysteries to explore. From then on it's all up to you. Go to the nearest village and interact with the townsfolk or find your own path. Battle fierce beasts, learn incredible spells, rob stores, fight for money, make friends, embark on quests, search for artifacts, brew deadly poisons, control minds, barter items, cook food, worship your gods, play instruments, raise the dead, clean your ears...

And of course you'll die. You'll be drowned, burnt and crushed to death. You'll die of hunger and sickness and bloodloss. You'll accidentally kill yourself conducting dangerous magical experiments. You'll die as you are sacrificed to strange and terrible gods. You'll die and return. And maybe, just maybe you'll one day defeat the powers that plague Drakalor Chain. I never did, yet, but I'll keep on trying.

See you in the Caverns of Chaos!

author: {'steamid': '76561197974789406', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 44256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2, 'playtime_at_review': 1160, 'last_played': 1712057936}
review:
Things ADOM taught me about life:

[list]
[*]How to endure loss.
[*]To weigh my options.
[*]To question myself.
[*]To weigh my options.
[*]To reign in my ambition and not get cocky.
[*]To weigh my options.
[*]To bravely march into a very real risk of death and be rewarded for it.
[*]To weigh my options.
[*]The value of cheating and of spoiling onesself--and of not doing so.
[*]To weigh my options.
[*]How to pay full price for a game on Steam instead of waiting for a sale--without weighing my options.
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970668966', 'num_games_owned': 681, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 23833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3047, 'last_played': 1706461766}
review:
One of the most popular roguelikes of all time has finally made it to Steam. There's a reason why ADOM and ToME4 usually fight it out for #1 and #2 on the Roguelike of the Year awards and that's because they are both bloody good and worth your cash.

ADOM is one of the most challenging games I have encountered. The mechanics are deep and rewarding for those that play and discover. Death, like in any real roguelike, is common even for the experienced player and there's a major sense of satisfaction when you discover a new trick, enter a new dungeon or simply cave in the head of some nasty monster that has taken you all of your ammo, your power points and left you barely functional. 

I started my journey back in 1995 on the Amiga playing this game made up of @ signs and & signs and wondering how such a bland, simple looking game could ever hope to hold my attention. 20 years on, new content has been added and colourful tiles presenting a much nicer GUI have arrived.

And one piece of advice.... never EVER eat a kobold... it's like Montezuma's revenge (wait, you might meet him) only worse!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031698017', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1696795542}
review: Awesome game. Played like 500+ hours since i discovered it back in 2002. One of my favourite games of all time, easily top3. ^^.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020430331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 46284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3146, 'last_played': 1703013007}
review:
This is my favourite game ever. What else is there to say?

Ok, so I downloaded ADOM in all its ASCII glory back in the mid-nineties. Since then, I've died a lot. I've been killed by an exploding frog, I've been crushed by my own inventory, I've turned into a pile of chaos goo. I've had my real-life sleep disturbed by nightmares of bright green Hs and dark grey Ls. Eventually I managed a win, then another. I still die a lot.  

There's no other game I could imagine playing for two decades. Adom is deep, challenging, frustrating and addictive. And it's still my favourite game ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998320495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 26349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7138, 'last_played': 1693904742}
